docs.title: Guidance System
docs.text: Verification-first system prompts that guide QE agents to prevent false positives and time waste.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Guidance System provides time-constrained, verification-first prompts for QE agents:

  • Prevents false positives: Agents must verify before claiming success
  • Reduces time waste: Guides agents to get quick feedback first
  • Mode-specific: Different guidance for quick scan vs deep QE
  • Anti-pattern detection: Identifies common QE anti-patterns

docs.title: Verification First
docs.text:
Agents must prove their findings before claiming success:

  • Run tests to verify issues
  • Provide evidence for claims
  • Don't assume without checking

docs.title: Time Optimization
docs.text:
Guidance optimizes for time-constrained sessions:

  • Quick Scan: Fail fast, validate critical paths
  • Deep QE: Explore thoroughly, test edge cases

docs.title: Anti-Pattern Prevention
docs.text:
Guards against common mistakes:

  • Skipping verification
  • Claiming unconditional success
  • Broad exception handling
  • Weakening tests

docs.title: YAML Configuration
docs.text:
superqode:
  qe:
    guidance:
      enabled: true
      require_proof: true

      quick_scan:
        timeout_seconds: 60
        verification_first: true
        fail_fast: true
        exploration_allowed: false
        destructive_testing: false
        focus_areas:
          - "Run smoke tests first"
          - "Validate critical paths"
          - "Check for obvious errors"
        forbidden_actions:
          - "Long-running performance tests"
          - "Extensive code generation"

      deep_qe:
        timeout_seconds: 1800
        verification_first: true
        fail_fast: false
        exploration_allowed: true
        destructive_testing: true
        focus_areas:
          - "Comprehensive test coverage"
          - "Edge case exploration"
          - "Security vulnerability scanning"
        forbidden_actions:
          - "Modifying production code"
          - "Committing changes to git"

      anti_patterns:
        enabled: true
        patterns:
          - skip_verification
          - unconditional_success
          - broad_exception_swallow
          - weaken_tests

docs.title: Quick Scan
docs.text:
Optimized for speed (60 seconds):

quick_scan:
  timeout_seconds: 60
  verification_first: true
  fail_fast: true
  exploration_allowed: false
  destructive_testing: false

Focus Areas: - Run smoke tests first - Validate critical paths - Check for obvious errors - Verify basic functionality

Forbidden: - Long-running performance tests - Extensive code generation - Deep exploration without feedback

docs.title: Deep QE
docs.text:
Comprehensive analysis (30 minutes):

deep_qe:
  timeout_seconds: 1800
  verification_first: true
  fail_fast: false
  exploration_allowed: true
  destructive_testing: true

Focus Areas: - Comprehensive test coverage - Edge case exploration - Security vulnerability scanning - Performance and load testing - Chaos and stress testing

Forbidden: - Modifying production code - Committing changes to git - Accessing external networks without approval

docs.title: Anti-Pattern Detection
docs.text: The guidance system detects and prevents common QE anti-patterns that lead to false positives and unreliable results.

docs.title: What Are Anti-Patterns?
docs.text:
Anti-patterns are behaviors that undermine QE reliability:

  • Claiming success without evidence
  • Weakening tests to make them pass
  • Ignoring errors silently
  • Guessing expected outputs

docs.title: 1. Skip Verification
docs.text:
Pattern: Claiming success without running tests.

# [INCORRECT] Anti-pattern
def check_code():
    return "PASS"  # Never actually runs tests

# [CORRECT] Correct
def check_code():
    result = run_tests()
    return "PASS" if result.success else "FAIL"

Detection: No test execution recorded before success claim.

docs.title: 2. Unconditional Success
docs.text:
Pattern: Always returning success regardless of outcome.

# [INCORRECT] Anti-pattern
pytest || true  # Always succeeds

# [CORRECT] Correct
pytest  # Fails if tests fail

Detection: Exit code manipulation, || true patterns.

docs.title: 3. Weaken Tests
docs.text:
Pattern: Modifying tests to pass instead of fixing code.

# [INCORRECT] Anti-pattern
def test_auth():
    # Changed from assertEqual to assertTrue
    assert True  # Was: assert response.status == 401

# [CORRECT] Correct
def test_auth():
    assert response.status == 401  # Fix the code, not the test

Detection: Test file modifications that remove assertions.

docs.title: 4. Broad Exception Swallow
docs.text:
Pattern: Catching all exceptions and hiding errors.

# [INCORRECT] Anti-pattern
try:
    risky_operation()
except Exception:
    pass  # Silently ignore all errors

# [CORRECT] Correct
try:
    risky_operation()
except SpecificError as e:
    logger.error(f"Operation failed: {e}")
    raise

Detection: Bare except: or except Exception: with no handling.

docs.title: 5. Silent Fallback
docs.text:
Pattern: Returning default values when operations fail.

# [INCORRECT] Anti-pattern
def get_user(id):
    try:
        return database.get(id)
    except:
        return None  # Hide the error

# [CORRECT] Correct
def get_user(id):
    try:
        return database.get(id)
    except DatabaseError as e:
        logger.error(f"Database error: {e}")
        raise UserNotFoundError(id)

Detection: Error suppression with default returns.

docs.title: 6. Guess Expected Output
docs.text:
Pattern: Not verifying actual vs expected output.

# [INCORRECT] Anti-pattern
def test_api():
    response = client.get("/users")
    # Just check status, not content
    assert response.status_code == 200

# [CORRECT] Correct
def test_api():
    response = client.get("/users")
    assert response.status_code == 200
    assert "users" in response.json()
    assert len(response.json()["users"]) > 0

Detection: Assertions that don't verify actual content.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
anti_patterns:
  enabled: true
  patterns:
    - skip_verification
    - unconditional_success
    - weaken_tests
    - broad_exception_swallow
    - silent_fallback
    - guess_expected_output

  # Enforcement level
  enforcement: "strict"  # or "warn"

docs.title: Enforcement Levels
docs.text: Level Behavior strict Block QR generation if anti-patterns detected warn Include warning in QR

docs.title: Detection in Practice
docs.text:
The guidance system includes anti-pattern warnings in system prompts:

ANTI-PATTERNS (FORBIDDEN):
- Skip Verification: Claiming success without running tests
- Unconditional Success: Always passing regardless of outcome
- Weaken Tests: Modifying tests to pass instead of fixing code
- Broad Exception Swallow: Catching all exceptions silently
- Silent Fallback: Hiding errors with default values
- Guess Expected Output: Not verifying actual outputs

docs.title: Red Flags in Output
docs.text:
The guidance system prompts agents to flag anti-patterns:

## Red Flags Detected

- WARNING: No test execution before success claim
- WARNING: Tests modified (3 assertions removed)
- WARNING: Broad exception handler in `src/api.py:42`

docs.title: Adding Custom Anti-Patterns
docs.text:
guidance:
  anti_patterns:
    patterns:
      # Built-in patterns
      - skip_verification
      - unconditional_success

      # Custom patterns (description only)
      - "Hardcoding expected values"
      - "Mocking external services without verification"
      - "Skipping integration tests"

docs.title: Quick Scan Prompt
docs.text:
Generated from configuration:

SYSTEM: SuperQode Quick Scan QE Mode - 60s

FOCUS AREAS:
  - Run smoke tests first
  - Validate critical paths
  - Check for obvious errors

FORBIDDEN ACTIONS:
  - [INCORRECT] Long-running performance tests
  - [INCORRECT] Extensive code generation

ANTI-PATTERNS (FORBIDDEN):
  - Skip Verification
  - Unconditional Success
  ...

docs.title: Deep QE Prompt
docs.text:
Comprehensive guidance:

SYSTEM: SuperQode Deep QE Mode - 1800s

FOCUS AREAS:
  - Comprehensive test coverage
  - Edge case exploration
  - Security vulnerability scanning

FORBIDDEN ACTIONS:
  - [INCORRECT] Modifying production code
  - [INCORRECT] Committing changes to git

ANTI-PATTERNS (FORBIDDEN):
  ...

docs.title: Review Prompts
docs.text: Guidance includes review prompts for self-checking:

docs.title: Verification Checklist
docs.text:
Agents review their work:

  • Did I run tests to verify?
  • Is there evidence for my claims?
  • Did I check for edge cases?
  • Are my findings accurate?

docs.title: With QE Sessions
docs.text:
Guidance automatically applied during QE:

# Quick scan uses quick_scan guidance
superqe run . --mode quick

# Deep QE uses deep_qe guidance
superqe run . --mode deep

docs.title: With CI/CD
docs.text:
Guidance configured in superqode.yaml:

# CI uses quick scan guidance
- run: superqe run . --mode quick

# Nightly uses deep QE guidance
- run: superqe run . --mode deep

docs.title: 1. Enable Verification First
docs.text:
guidance:
  require_proof: true
  quick_scan:
    verification_first: true

docs.title: 2. Configure Focus Areas
docs.text:
Customize for your project:

quick_scan:
  focus_areas:
    - "Your specific focus area"
    - "Another important area"

docs.title: 3. Define Forbidden Actions
docs.text:
Prevent unwanted behavior:

deep_qe:
  forbidden_actions:
    - "Modifying production config"
    - "Changing database schema"

docs.title: 4. Enable Anti-Patterns
docs.text:
anti_patterns:
  enabled: true

docs.title: Project-Specific Guidance
docs.text:
Adapt guidance to your project:

guidance:
  quick_scan:
    focus_areas:
      - "API endpoint validation"
      - "Authentication flow"
      - "Database queries"

    forbidden_actions:
      - "Modifying production database"
      - "Changing authentication logic"

docs.title: Team Preferences
docs.text:
Adjust based on team needs:

deep_qe:
  timeout_seconds: 3600  # Longer for complex projects
  exploration_allowed: true
  destructive_testing: true  # Enable for pre-release

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• QE Features - QE overview
  • Configuration - Config reference
  • Constitution - Quality rules

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Advanced Features Index - All advanced features
  • Harness System - Patch validation

docs.title: Harness System
docs.text: Fast validation for QE-generated patches and changes before they're suggested in QRs.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Harness System validates patches and changes to ensure:

  • Syntactic correctness: Code parses correctly
  • Type safety: Type checking passes
  • Style compliance: Linting rules followed
  • No regressions: Changes don't break existing code

All validation happens before suggestions are included in QRs.

docs.title: Principle
docs.text:
"SuperQode never edits, rewrites, or commits code." "All fixes are suggested, validated, and proven, never auto-applied."

The harness VALIDATES suggestions - it doesn't apply them.

docs.title: Structural Validation
docs.text:
Parsing validation for structured formats:

  • JSON: Valid JSON syntax
  • YAML: Valid YAML syntax
  • TOML: Valid TOML syntax

Runs on: All changes to structured files

docs.title: Language Validation
docs.text:
Language-specific validation:

  • Python: mypy, ruff, pyright
  • JavaScript: eslint, tsc
  • TypeScript: tsc, eslint
  • Go: go vet, golangci-lint
  • Rust: cargo check
  • Shell: shellcheck

Runs on: Code files matching language patterns

docs.title: YAML Configuration
docs.text:
superqode:
  qe:
    harness:
      enabled: true
      timeout_seconds: 30
      fail_on_error: false

      structural:
        enabled: true
        formats: ["json", "yaml", "toml"]

      python:
        enabled: true
        tools:
          - mypy
          - ruff
          - pyright

      javascript:
        enabled: true
        tools:
          - eslint

      typescript:
        enabled: true
        tools:
          - tsc
          - eslint

      go:
        enabled: true
        tools:
          - go vet
          - golangci-lint

      rust:
        enabled: true
        tools:
          - cargo check

      shell:
        enabled: true
        tools:
          - shellcheck

      # Bring Your Own Harness (BYOH)
      custom_steps:
        - name: "project-harness"
          command: "python scripts/harness_check.py"
          timeout: 120
          enabled: true

docs.title: 1. Patch Generation
docs.text: Agent generates a patch/suggestion during QE.

docs.title: 2. Harness Validation
docs.text:
Harness validates the patch:

harness = PatchHarness(project_root)
result = await harness.validate_changes({
    "src/api/users.py": "new code content"
})

docs.title: 3. Validation Result
docs.text:
Result includes:

  • Success: All validations passed
  • Findings: Validation errors/warnings
  • Tools run: Which validators executed
  • Duration: Validation time

docs.title: 4. QR Inclusion
docs.text:
Only validated patches included in QR:

if result.success:
    # Include in QR
    qr.add_suggestion(patch, result)
else:
    # Report validation failures
    qr.add_validation_failures(result.findings)

docs.title: Structural
docs.text:
Parsing validation - ensures files are valid:

{
  "tool": "structural-parse",
  "category": "structural",
  "file": "config.json",
  "message": "Invalid JSON: unexpected token",
  "severity": "error"
}

docs.title: Syntactic
docs.text:
Syntax validation - language syntax:

{
  "tool": "mypy",
  "category": "syntactic",
  "file": "src/api/users.py",
  "line": 42,
  "message": "Missing type annotation",
  "severity": "error"
}

docs.title: Type
docs.text:
Type checking - static type analysis:

{
  "tool": "mypy",
  "category": "type",
  "file": "src/api/users.py",
  "line": 45,
  "message": "Incompatible types: int vs str",
  "severity": "error"
}

docs.title: Stylistic
docs.text:
Code style - formatting and style rules:

{
  "tool": "ruff",
  "category": "stylistic",
  "file": "src/api/users.py",
  "line": 50,
  "message": "Line too long (120 > 100)",
  "severity": "warning"
}

docs.title: Functional
docs.text:
Runtime validation - execution checks:

{
  "tool": "harness",
  "category": "functional",
  "file": null,
  "message": "Harness validation timed out",
  "severity": "warning"
}

docs.title: Tool Detection
docs.text:
Harness automatically detects available tools:

# Checks if tool exists
if shutil.which("mypy"):
    # Run mypy validation
    ...

docs.title: Tool Availability
docs.text:
• Not found: Tool skipped, no error
  • Found: Tool runs validation
  • Timeout: Validation times out gracefully

docs.title: Temporary Workspace
docs.text:
Validation happens in isolated temp workspace:

  1. Create temporary directory
  2. Stage changed files
  3. Run validators
  4. Collect findings
  5. Clean up temp directory

docs.title: Parallel Validation
docs.text:
Multiple validators run in parallel when possible:

  • Structural validation (instant)
  • Language validators (parallel by file)
  • Tool execution (timeout-protected)

docs.title: HarnessResult
docs.text:
@dataclass
class HarnessResult:
    success: bool
    findings: List[HarnessFinding]
    tools_run: List[str]
    duration_seconds: float
    files_validated: int

docs.title: HarnessFinding
docs.text:
@dataclass
class HarnessFinding:
    tool: str
    category: ValidationCategory
    file: Optional[Path]
    message: str
    line: Optional[int]
    column: Optional[int]
    severity: str  # "error", "warning", "info"

docs.title: With QE Sessions
docs.text:
Harness runs automatically during QE:

# During QE session
patch = agent.generate_suggestion()
result = await harness.validate_changes(patch)

if result.success:
    # Include in QR
else:
    # Report validation issues

docs.title: With Suggestions (Enterprise)
docs.text:
All suggestions validated:

# Suggestions already validated
superqe run . --mode deep --allow-suggestions

docs.title: With QR Generation
docs.text:
QR includes validation results:

{
  "suggestions": [
    {
      "patch": "...",
      "validation": {
        "success": true,
        "tools_run": ["mypy", "ruff"],
        "findings": []
      }
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: Python Project
docs.text:
harness:
  python:
    enabled: true
    tools:
      - mypy      # Type checking
      - ruff      # Linting
      - pyright   # Type checking (alternative)

docs.title: TypeScript Project
docs.text:
harness:
  typescript:
    enabled: true
    tools:
      - tsc       # Type checking
      - eslint    # Linting

docs.title: Multi-Language Project
docs.text:
harness:
  python:
    enabled: true
    tools: [mypy, ruff]
  javascript:
    enabled: true
    tools: [eslint]
  typescript:
    enabled: true
    tools: [tsc, eslint]

docs.title: Bring Your Own Harness (BYOH)
docs.text:
Use custom_steps to run project-specific validation commands as part of the harness. Each step runs in the repo root, uses the shell, and a non-zero exit code is reported as a harness error.

harness:
  custom_steps:
    - name: "contracts"
      command: "python scripts/check_contracts.py"
      timeout: 180
    - name: "smoke-tests"
      command: "pytest -q tests/smoke"
      enabled: true

Step fields

  • name: Display name for reporting
  • command: Shell command to run
  • enabled: Toggle the step on/off (default: true)
  • timeout: Timeout in seconds (default: 300)

docs.title: 1. Enable Relevant Validators
docs.text:
Only enable validators for languages in your project:

harness:
  python:
    enabled: true  # If you use Python
  go:
    enabled: false  # If you don't use Go

docs.title: 2. Set Timeouts
docs.text:
Prevent long-running validations:

harness:
  timeout_seconds: 30  # Reasonable timeout

docs.title: 3. Handle Failures Gracefully
docs.text:
harness:
  fail_on_error: false  # Report but don't fail QE

docs.title: 4. Tool Installation
docs.text:
Ensure tools are installed:

# Python tools
pip install mypy ruff pyright

# TypeScript tools
npm install -g typescript eslint

# Go tools
go install github.com/golangci/golangci-lint/cmd/golangci-lint@latest

docs.title: Tools Not Found
docs.text:
Symptom: Validators skipped

Solution: Install required tools:

# Check availability
which mypy
which ruff

# Install if missing
pip install mypy ruff

docs.title: Timeout Errors
docs.text:
Symptom: Validation times out

Solution: Increase timeout or optimize validators:

harness:
  timeout_seconds: 60  # Increase timeout

docs.title: False Positives
docs.text:
Symptom: Validators report issues that don't matter

Solution: Configure validator options or disable specific tools:

harness:
  python:
    tools: [ruff]  # Skip mypy if too strict

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Fix Verifier - Fix verification
  • Suggestions - Suggestion workflow
  • Configuration - Config reference

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Advanced Features Index - All advanced features
  • Guidance System - QE guidance

docs.title: Memory & Learning System
docs.text: SuperQode learns from your feedback to improve over time. The memory system stores project-specific learnings that persist across QE sessions.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Memory & Learning System enables SuperQode to:

  • Remember patterns: Track recurring issues and fixes
  • Learn from feedback: Improve based on your corrections
  • Suppress false positives: Automatically filter known false positives
  • Score file risk: Identify high-risk files based on history
  • Track role effectiveness: Measure which QE roles work best for your project

docs.title: MemoryStore
docs.text:
Persistent storage for project learnings:

  • User-local memory: ~/.superqode/memory/project-{hash}.json
  • Team-shared memory: .superqode/memory.json (in repo)

Memory is merged with user-local taking precedence.

docs.title: FeedbackCollector
docs.text:
Collects and processes user feedback on findings:

  • Marks findings as valid/false positive
  • Records fix patterns
  • Updates role metrics
  • Integrates with ML predictor

docs.title: Issue Patterns
docs.text:
Recurring issues detected across sessions:

{
  "fingerprint": "abc123",
  "title": "SQL injection vulnerability",
  "category": "security",
  "severity": "critical",
  "occurrences": 5,
  "first_seen": "2025-01-10T10:00:00",
  "last_seen": "2025-01-15T14:30:00",
  "files_affected": ["src/api/users.py", "src/api/orders.py"],
  "avg_confidence": 0.85
}

docs.title: Suppressions
docs.text:
False positive suppression rules:

{
  "pattern": "legacy authentication code",
  "pattern_type": "fingerprint",
  "scope": "project",
  "created_at": "2025-01-10T10:00:00",
  "created_by": "user",
  "expires_in_days": null
}

docs.title: Fix Patterns
docs.text:
Successful fix patterns:

{
  "finding_type": "sql_injection",
  "fix_approach": "parameterized_queries",
  "success_rate": 0.95,
  "times_used": 10,
  "files_fixed": ["src/api/users.py", ...]
}

docs.title: File Risk Scores
docs.text:
Risk scores per file based on finding history:

{
  "src/api/users.py": 0.85,
  "src/auth/login.py": 0.92,
  "src/utils/helpers.py": 0.15
}

docs.title: Role Metrics
docs.text:
Effectiveness tracking per QE role:

{
  "security_tester": {
    "total_findings": 45,
    "confirmed_findings": 40,
    "false_positives": 5,
    "accuracy_rate": 0.89
  }
}

docs.title: Mark Finding as Valid
docs.text:
superqe feedback finding-001 --valid

Updates: - Role metrics (increases confirmed findings) - Issue patterns (tracks recurring issues) - ML training data (if ML enabled)

docs.title: Mark as False Positive
docs.text:
superqe feedback finding-002 --false-positive -r "Intentional for testing"

Creates: - Suppression rule - Updates role metrics - Adds to ML training data

docs.title: Mark as Fixed
docs.text:
superqe feedback finding-003 --fixed -r "Applied suggested patch"

Records: - Fix pattern (approach used) - File risk score adjustment - Role effectiveness update

docs.title: User-Local Memory
docs.text:
Location: ~/.superqode/memory/project-{hash}.json

  • Per-user, per-project storage
  • Not committed to repo
  • Takes precedence over team memory

docs.title: Team-Shared Memory
docs.text:
Location: .superqode/memory.json

  • Committed to repository
  • Shared across team
  • Merged with user-local memory

docs.title: Merging Strategy
docs.text: When both exist: 1. Load user-local memory 2. Load team-shared memory 3. Merge (user-local takes precedence) 4. Use merged result

docs.title: Pattern Detection
docs.text:
The system automatically detects patterns:

  • Recurring issues: Same issue in multiple files
  • Common fixes: Successful fixes applied repeatedly
  • False positive patterns: Frequently suppressed findings

docs.title: Risk Scoring
docs.text:
File risk scores update automatically:

  • Finding detected → increase risk
  • Fix applied → decrease risk
  • Multiple findings → higher risk

docs.title: Role Metrics
docs.text:
Role effectiveness tracked automatically:

  • Finding confirmed → increase accuracy
  • False positive → decrease accuracy
  • Tracks over time

docs.title: Load Memory
docs.text:
from superqode.memory import MemoryStore

store = MemoryStore(project_root)
memory = store.load()

# Access data
issue_patterns = memory.issue_patterns
suppressions = memory.suppressions
file_risk = memory.file_risk_map

docs.title: Collect Feedback
docs.text:
from superqode.memory import FeedbackCollector

collector = FeedbackCollector(project_root)

# Mark as valid
collector.mark_valid(
    finding_id="sec-001",
    finding_title="SQL injection",
    category="security",
    severity="critical",
    role_name="security_tester"
)

# Mark as false positive
collector.mark_false_positive(
    finding_id="sec-002",
    finding_title="False positive",
    finding_fingerprint="abc123",
    role_name="security_tester",
    reason="Intentional for testing"
)

docs.title: Update File Risk
docs.text:
memory = store.load()
memory.update_file_risk("src/api/users.py", "critical")
store.save()

docs.title: 1. Reduce False Positives
docs.text:
# First time: mark as false positive
superqe feedback finding-001 --false-positive -r "Known pattern"

# Future sessions: automatically suppressed

docs.title: 2. Track Recurring Issues
docs.text:
The system tracks issues that appear multiple times:

Issue Pattern: SQL injection in user input
Occurrences: 5
Files: users.py, orders.py, products.py

docs.title: 3. Identify High-Risk Files
docs.text:
Files with high risk scores get more attention:

# Check file risk
memory = store.load()
risk = memory.file_risk_map.get("src/api/users.py", 0.0)
if risk > 0.8:
    print("High-risk file - focus testing here")

docs.title: 4. Measure Role Effectiveness
docs.text:
See which roles work best:

metrics = memory.role_metrics.get("security_tester")
print(f"Accuracy: {metrics.accuracy_rate:.2%}")
print(f"Confirmed: {metrics.confirmed_findings}")

docs.title: 1. Provide Regular Feedback
docs.text:
# After each QE session
superqe feedback finding-001 --valid
superqe feedback finding-002 --false-positive -r "reason"

docs.title: 2. Share Team Memory
docs.text:
Commit .superqode/memory.json to repository:

git add .superqode/memory.json
git commit -m "Update team memory"

docs.title: 3. Review Suppressions
docs.text:
Periodically review suppressions:

superqe suppressions

docs.title: 4. Monitor Role Metrics
docs.text:
Check which roles are most effective:

# High accuracy = role works well for your project
# Low accuracy = may need different approach

docs.title: Memory Not Persisting
docs.text: Check storage location: - User-local: ~/.superqode/memory/ - Team-shared: .superqode/memory.json

docs.title: Suppressions Not Working
docs.text: Verify pattern matching: - Pattern type (fingerprint vs. title) - Scope (project vs. file) - Expiration (if set)

docs.title: Risk Scores Not Updating
docs.text:
Ensure feedback collected: 

superqe feedback finding-001 --valid

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• QE Feedback Commands - Feedback workflow
  • Noise Filtering - Filtering false positives

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Advanced Features Index - All advanced features
  • Configuration - Memory configuration

docs.title: Safety & Permissions
docs.text: SuperQode implements a comprehensive safety model to ensure secure operation while allowing agents to perform effective quality engineering. This document describes the security architecture, permission system, and safety guarantees.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
SuperQode's safety model is built on these principles:

  1. Sandbox-First - All testing happens in isolated environments
  2. Least Privilege - Agents only get permissions they need
  3. Human-in-the-Loop - Dangerous operations require approval
  4. Revert Guarantee - Original code is always preserved
  5. Audit Trail - All actions are logged and traceable

docs.title: Permission Levels
docs.text:
SuperQode defines four permission levels for tool operations:

Level Description Approval Required Safe Read-only operations No Moderate Limited modifications in sandbox No Dangerous Significant changes or external access Yes Blocked Never allowed N/A

docs.title: Safe Operations
docs.text:
Operations that cannot cause harm:

  • Reading files
  • Searching code
  • Listing directories
  • Viewing git history
  • Running linters (read-only)

docs.title: Moderate Operations
docs.text:
Operations limited to the sandbox:

  • Editing files (in workspace)
  • Creating new files (in workspace)
  • Running tests
  • Installing dev dependencies

docs.title: Dangerous Operations
docs.text:
Operations requiring explicit approval:

  • Executing shell commands
  • Network requests to external URLs
  • Modifying configuration files
  • Git operations (commit, push)
  • Package installation
  • System file access

docs.title: Blocked Operations
docs.text:
Operations that are never allowed:

  • Accessing credentials/secrets
  • Modifying files outside workspace
  • Executing as root/admin
  • Network access to internal services
  • Deleting critical system files

docs.title: Permission Rules Engine
docs.text:
The permission rules engine (permissions/rules.py) evaluates each tool call:

Tool Call Request
       │
       ▼
┌──────────────────┐
│ Permission Rules │
│     Engine       │
└────────┬─────────┘
         │
    ┌────┴────┐
    │         │
    ▼         ▼
 Allowed   Requires
           Approval
              │
              ▼
       ┌──────────────┐
       │ User Prompt  │
       │  (Y/N/Always)│
       └──────────────┘

docs.title: Rule Configuration
docs.text:
Permission rules can be configured in superqode.yaml:

permissions:
  # Default permission level
  default_level: moderate

  # Tool-specific overrides
  tools:
    shell:
      level: dangerous
      require_approval: true
      allowed_commands:
        - pytest
        - npm test
        - cargo test
      blocked_commands:
        - rm -rf
        - sudo
        - curl | bash

    file_write:
      level: moderate
      allowed_paths:
        - "**/*.py"
        - "**/*.js"
        - "**/*.ts"
      blocked_paths:
        - ".env*"
        - "**/*.pem"
        - "**/*.key"

    network:
      level: dangerous
      allowed_domains:
        - github.com
        - pypi.org
      blocked_domains:
        - localhost
        - "*.internal"

docs.title: Dangerous Operation Detection
docs.text: The danger detection system (danger.py) identifies potentially harmful operations:

docs.title: Detection Categories
docs.text: Category Examples Action Destructive Commands rm -rf, git reset --hard Block or warn Credential Access Reading .env, credentials.json Block System Modification /etc/, /usr/ access Block Network Exfiltration POST to unknown domains Require approval Privilege Escalation sudo, chmod 777 Block

docs.title: Detection Rules
docs.text:
# Example danger patterns
DANGEROUS_PATTERNS = [
    r"rm\s+-rf\s+/",           # Recursive delete from root
    r"sudo\s+",                 # Privilege escalation
    r">\s*/etc/",               # Write to system config
    r"curl.*\|\s*bash",         # Pipe to shell
    r"chmod\s+777",             # World-writable
    r"eval\s*\(",               # Dynamic code execution
]

docs.title: Approval Workflow
docs.text:
When a dangerous operation is detected, SuperQode prompts for approval:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  ⚠️  Dangerous Operation Detected                           │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                              │
│  Tool: shell                                                 │
│  Command: npm install axios                                  │
│  Reason: Package installation may modify dependencies       │
│                                                              │
│  [Y] Allow once                                             │
│  [A] Always allow for this session                          │
│  [N] Deny                                                    │
│  [?] Show more details                                       │
│                                                              │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Approval Options
docs.text: Option Effect Scope Y (Yes) Allow this specific operation Once A (Always) Allow similar operations Session N (No) Deny and continue Once ! (Abort) Stop QE session Immediate

docs.title: Approval Memory
docs.text:
Approved operations are remembered for the session:

# Session approval state
approvals:
  shell:
    - pattern: "npm test"
      approved: true
    - pattern: "pytest"
      approved: true
  file_write:
    - pattern: "tests/**/*.py"
      approved: true

docs.title: Sandbox Isolation
docs.text: The sandbox system (safety/sandbox.py) provides isolation:

docs.title: Isolation Mechanisms
docs.text: Mechanism Description Use Case Git Worktree Separate git working directory Optional for git repos File Snapshot Copy of files to temp directory Non-git directories Docker Container Full container isolation CI/CD environments

docs.title: Sandbox Guarantees
docs.text:
1. File Isolation - Changes only affect the sandbox copy
  2. Git Protection - Cannot commit/push from sandbox
  3. Process Isolation - Subprocesses inherit restrictions
  4. Network Isolation - Optional network restrictions

docs.title: Sandbox Configuration
docs.text:
sandbox:
  # Isolation mode: worktree, snapshot
  mode: snapshot

  # Preserve sandbox on error for debugging
  preserve_on_error: false

  # Network restrictions
  network:
    enabled: true
    allow_localhost: true
    allowed_hosts:
      - "*.github.com"
      - "*.pypi.org"

docs.title: Safety Warnings
docs.text: The warning system (safety/warnings.py) alerts users to potential issues:

docs.title: Warning Levels
docs.text: Level Display Action Info Blue message Continue Warning Yellow banner Continue with notice Critical Red blocking dialog Require acknowledgment

docs.title: Common Warnings
docs.text:
• Large File Changes - Modifying files over 1000 lines
  • Binary Files - Attempting to edit binary files
  • Test Failures - Tests failing after modifications
  • Resource Usage - High memory/CPU consumption
  • Long Running - Session exceeding time limits

docs.title: Audit Trail
docs.text:
All operations are logged for audit:

{
  "timestamp": "2024-01-15T10:30:45Z",
  "session_id": "qe-abc123",
  "operation": "shell",
  "command": "pytest tests/",
  "permission_level": "moderate",
  "approved": true,
  "approved_by": "auto",
  "duration_ms": 1234,
  "result": "success"
}

docs.title: Audit Log Location
docs.text:
.superqode/
├── audit/
│   ├── session-abc123.jsonl
│   └── session-def456.jsonl
└── qe-artifacts/

docs.title: For Users
docs.text:
1. Review Approvals - Don't blindly approve all operations
  2. Use Quick Mode First - Start with limited scope
  3. Check Artifacts - Review suggested changes before applying
  4. Set Allowed Lists - Configure allowed commands/paths

docs.title: For CI/CD
docs.text:
1. Use worktree isolation - Full isolation in pipelines
  2. Disable Approvals - Use --no-interactive with pre-approved lists
  3. Set Time Limits - Prevent runaway sessions
  4. Audit Logs - Archive audit trails for compliance

docs.title: Configuration Example
docs.text:
# Production-safe configuration
permissions:
  default_level: moderate

  tools:
    shell:
      require_approval: true
      allowed_commands:
        - pytest
        - npm test
        - cargo test
        - go test
      blocked_patterns:
        - "rm -rf"
        - "curl | bash"
        - sudo

    file_write:
      blocked_paths:
        - ".env*"
        - "*.pem"
        - "*.key"
        - "secrets/**"

sandbox:
  mode: worktree
  network:
    enabled: true
    allowed_hosts:
      - "github.com"
      - "pypi.org"

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Architecture Overview - System architecture
  • Workspace Internals - Isolation details
  • Configuration Reference - Full config options

docs.title: Session Management
docs.text: Persistent session storage, sharing, and coordination for QE sessions and conversations.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Session Management provides:

  • Persistence: Save and resume QE sessions
  • Sharing: Share sessions with team members
  • Forking: Create branches from shared sessions
  • Snapshots: Undo/redo with session snapshots
  • History: Track conversation history and tool executions

docs.title: Storage Location
docs.text:
Sessions stored in: ~/.superqode/sessions/

  • Compressed JSON files (.json.gz)
  • Index file for fast listing (index.json)
  • Share directory for shared sessions (shares/)

docs.title: Session Format
docs.text:
{
  "id": "session-123",
  "title": "Fix SQL injection",
  "created_at": "2025-01-15T10:00:00",
  "updated_at": "2025-01-15T10:30:00",
  "project_path": "/path/to/project",
  "messages": [...],
  "tool_executions": [...],
  "files_modified": ["src/api/users.py"],
  "files_created": [],
  "agents_used": ["security_tester"],
  "tags": ["security", "bug-fix"],
  "snapshots": [...]
}

docs.title: Create Session
docs.text:
from superqode.session import SessionStore, Session, MessageRole

store = SessionStore()

session = Session(
    id="session-123",
    title="Fix SQL injection",
    project_path="/path/to/project"
)

session.add_message(
    role=MessageRole.USER,
    content="Fix the SQL injection vulnerability"
)

store.save(session)

docs.title: Load Session
docs.text:
# Load by ID
session = store.load("session-123")

# Load latest
session = store.load_latest()

# List all sessions
sessions = store.list_sessions()

docs.title: Update Session
docs.text:
session = store.load("session-123")
session.add_message(MessageRole.ASSISTANT, "I'll fix that...")
store.save(session)

docs.title: Message Types
docs.text: Role Description user User input assistant Agent response system System messages

docs.title: Message Format
docs.text:
message = session.add_message(
    role=MessageRole.USER,
    content="Fix the bug",
    agent_name="security_tester",
    tool_calls=[...],
    tool_call_id="call-123"
)

docs.title: Tool Execution Tracking
docs.text:
Track all tool executions:

execution = session.add_tool_execution(
    tool_name="read_file",
    arguments={"path": "src/api/users.py"},
    result="file content...",
    success=True,
    duration_ms=45,
    agent_name="security_tester"
)

docs.title: Execution History
docs.text:
# Get all tool executions
executions = session.tool_executions

# Filter by tool
file_reads = [e for e in executions if e.tool_name == "read_file"]

# Filter by agent
agent_tools = [e for e in executions if e.agent_name == "security_tester"]

docs.title: File Tracking
docs.text:
Track modified and created files:

# Automatically tracked
session.files_modified  # ["src/api/users.py"]
session.files_created   # ["tests/test_users.py"]

docs.title: Snapshots
docs.text: Undo/redo support with snapshots:

docs.title: Create Snapshot
docs.text:
snapshot = session.create_snapshot("Before fix")
# session.snapshots now includes snapshot

docs.title: Restore Snapshot
docs.text:
# Restore to previous state
session.restore_snapshot(snapshot.id)

docs.title: Snapshot Format
docs.text:
{
  "id": "snapshot-123",
  "created_at": "2025-01-15T10:15:00",
  "description": "Before SQL fix",
  "state": {
    "files_modified": [...],
    "messages": [...],
    "tool_executions": [...]
  }
}

docs.title: Create Share
docs.text:
from superqode.session import SessionSharingManager, ShareConfig

sharing = SessionSharingManager(store)

share_config = ShareConfig(
    visibility="public",  # or "unlisted", "private"
    allow_fork=True,
    allow_view_history=True,
    expires_in=timedelta(days=7),  # Optional
    password="optional-password"  # Optional
)

share = sharing.create_share("session-123", share_config)
print(f"Share URL: {share.share_url}")

docs.title: Access Share
docs.text:
# Get shared session
shared_session = sharing.get_session_for_share(
    share_token="abc123",
    password="optional-password"
)

docs.title: Fork Session
docs.text:
# Create fork from shared session
forked = await sharing.fork_session(
    share_token="abc123",
    title="My Fork"
)

docs.title: Export Session
docs.text:
from superqode.session import ExportedSession

# Export to JSON
exported = sharing.export_session("session-123")
with open("session.json", "w") as f:
    f.write(exported.to_json())

# Export to base64 (for sharing)
b64 = exported.to_base64()

docs.title: Import Session
docs.text:
# Import from JSON
with open("session.json") as f:
    exported = ExportedSession.from_json(f.read())

# Import from base64
exported = ExportedSession.from_base64(b64_str)

# Restore session
session = exported.to_session()
store.save(session)

docs.title: Visibility
docs.text: Level Description public Anyone with link can access unlisted Accessible via link, not in lists private Password-protected access

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
ShareConfig(
    visibility="public",
    allow_fork=True,           # Allow forking
    allow_view_history=True,   # Show conversation history
    expires_in=timedelta(days=7),  # Auto-expire
    password="secret"          # Optional password
)

docs.title: Tags
docs.text:
Organize sessions with tags:

session.tags = ["security", "bug-fix", "urgent"]

docs.title: Agents Used
docs.text:
Track which agents participated:

session.agents_used  # ["security_tester", "api_tester"]

docs.title: Parent Session
docs.text:
Track session relationships:

# Forked session
forked.parent_session_id = "session-123"

docs.title: 1. Regular Saves
docs.text:
Save sessions regularly:

# Auto-save after each message
session.add_message(...)
store.save(session)

docs.title: 2. Meaningful Titles
docs.text:
Use descriptive titles:

session.title = "Fix SQL injection in users.py"  # Good
session.title = "Session 1"  # Bad

docs.title: 3. Create Snapshots
docs.text:
Snapshot before major changes:

session.create_snapshot("Before refactoring")
# ... make changes ...

docs.title: 4. Clean Up Old Sessions
docs.text:
# Delete old sessions
store.delete("old-session-id")

docs.title: 5. Secure Sharing
docs.text:
Use passwords for sensitive sessions:

ShareConfig(
    visibility="private",
    password="strong-password"
)

docs.title: 1. Resume Work
docs.text:
# Continue from last session
session = store.load_latest()
# Resume work...

docs.title: 2. Share Solutions
docs.text:
# Share successful fix with team
share = sharing.create_share("session-123", ShareConfig(visibility="public"))
# Share URL with team

docs.title: 3. Fork and Experiment
docs.text:
# Fork shared session to experiment
forked = await sharing.fork_session(share_token, "My experiment")
# Experiment without affecting original

docs.title: 4. Session History
docs.text:
# Review what was done
session = store.load("session-123")
for execution in session.tool_executions:
    print(f"{execution.tool_name}: {execution.result}")

docs.title: With QE Sessions
docs.text:
Sessions automatically saved during QE:

# QE session automatically creates/updates session
qe_session = QESession(...)
# Session saved to store automatically

docs.title: With TUI
docs.text:
TUI uses sessions for persistence:

  • Auto-save after each interaction
  • Resume last session on startup
  • Session history in TUI

docs.title: Session Not Found
docs.text:
Solution: Check session ID:

# List all sessions
sessions = store.list_sessions()

docs.title: Share Expired
docs.text:
Solution: Create new share:

# Shares expire based on config
share = sharing.create_share(session_id, ShareConfig(expires_in=None))

docs.title: Import Failed
docs.text:
Solution: Check export format:

# Ensure valid JSON
exported = ExportedSession.from_json(json_string)

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Memory & Learning - Persistent learnings
  • QE Features - QE workflows

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Advanced Features Index - All advanced features
  • Session Persistence - Source code

docs.title: Tools System
docs.text: Comprehensive tool system providing 20+ tools for AI coding agents in SuperQode.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
SuperQode provides a complete tool system for AI agents:

  • 20+ tools: File operations, editing, search, shell, network, diagnostics
  • Transparent: No hidden prompts or context injection
  • Standard format: OpenAI-compatible tool definitions
  • Extensible: Easy to add custom tools
  • Permission system: Fine-grained access control

docs.title: File Operations
docs.text: Tool Description read_file Read file contents write_file Write/create file list_directory List directory contents

docs.title: Editing
docs.text: Tool Description edit_file Edit file with diff-style changes insert_text Insert text at position patch Apply unified diff patch multi_edit Apply multiple edits atomically

docs.title: Search
docs.text: Tool Description grep Text search with regex glob File pattern matching code_search Semantic code search

docs.title: Shell
docs.text: Tool Description bash Execute shell commands (with streaming)

docs.title: Network
docs.text: Tool Description fetch HTTP GET request download Download file from URL web_search Web search capability web_fetch Enhanced HTTP fetch

docs.title: Diagnostics
docs.text: Tool Description diagnostics LSP diagnostics (linting errors)

docs.title: LSP
docs.text: Tool Description lsp Language Server Protocol operations

docs.title: Agent Tools
docs.text: Tool Description sub_agent Spawn sub-agent for parallel work task_coordinator Coordinate multiple agents

docs.title: Interactive
docs.text: Tool Description question Ask user question during execution confirm Request user confirmation

docs.title: TODO Management
docs.text: Tool Description todo_write Write TODO item todo_read Read TODO items

docs.title: Batch Operations
docs.text: Tool Description batch Execute multiple tools in parallel

docs.title: Default Registry
docs.text:
Minimal set of essential tools:

from superqode.tools import ToolRegistry

registry = ToolRegistry.default()
# Includes: read_file, write_file, edit_file, insert_text, bash, grep, glob

docs.title: Full Registry
docs.text:
All available tools:

registry = ToolRegistry.full()
# Includes all 20+ tools

docs.title: Custom Registry
docs.text:
Create custom tool sets:

registry = ToolRegistry()
registry.register(ReadFileTool())
registry.register(WriteFileTool())
# ... add tools as needed

docs.title: Tool Format
docs.text:
All tools use OpenAI-compatible format:

{
  "type": "function",
  "function": {
    "name": "read_file",
    "description": "Read contents of a file",
    "parameters": {
      "type": "object",
      "properties": {
        "path": {
          "type": "string",
          "description": "Path to file"
        }
      },
      "required": ["path"]
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Permission System
docs.text: Fine-grained permission control:

docs.title: Permission Levels
docs.text: Level Description ALLOW Always allow execution DENY Block execution ASK Prompt user for confirmation

docs.title: Tool Groups
docs.text:
Tools organized into groups:

  • READ: read_file, list_directory, grep, glob
  • WRITE: write_file, edit_file, insert_text, patch
  • SHELL: bash
  • NETWORK: fetch, download, web_search
  • DIAGNOSTICS: diagnostics
  • SEARCH: code_search
  • AGENT: sub_agent, task_coordinator

docs.title: Permission Configuration
docs.text:
tools:
  permissions:
    read: allow
    write: ask
    shell: ask
    network: deny

docs.title: Tool Result
docs.text:
Every tool returns a ToolResult:

class ToolResult:
    success: bool
    content: str
    error: Optional[str] = None
    metadata: Dict[str, Any] = {}

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Tools handle errors gracefully:

  • File not found: Returns error in result
  • Permission denied: Returns error (no exception)
  • Invalid input: Validates before execution

docs.title: Caching
docs.text:
Tool results can be cached:

@cacheable(ttl=300.0)
def read_file(self, path: str) -> ToolResult:
    # Results cached for 5 minutes
    ...

docs.title: Metrics Tracking
docs.text:
Track tool usage:

registry.get_execution_history(limit=100)
registry.get_tool_metrics()

docs.title: Batch Execution
docs.text:
Execute multiple tools in parallel:

result = await batch_tool.execute([
    {"tool": "read_file", "args": {"path": "file1.py"}},
    {"tool": "read_file", "args": {"path": "file2.py"}},
])

docs.title: Read File
docs.text:
result = read_file_tool.execute({
    "path": "src/api/users.py"
})

if result.success:
    content = result.content

docs.title: Edit File
docs.text:
result = edit_file_tool.execute({
    "path": "src/api/users.py",
    "old_string": "def get_user(id):",
    "new_string": "def get_user(user_id: int):"
})

docs.title: Grep Search
docs.text:
result = grep_tool.execute({
    "pattern": "def get_user",
    "path": "src/",
    "recursive": True
})

# Returns: List of matches with file paths and line numbers

docs.title: Bash Command
docs.text:
result = bash_tool.execute({
    "command": "python -m pytest tests/",
    "cwd": "/path/to/project"
})

# Supports streaming output

docs.title: Diagnostics
docs.text:
result = diagnostics_tool.execute({
    "path": "src/api/users.py"
})

# Returns: LSP diagnostics (errors, warnings)

docs.title: Creating a Tool
docs.text:
from superqode.tools import Tool, ToolResult

class CustomTool(Tool):
    name = "custom_tool"
    description = "Custom tool description"

    def execute(self, args: Dict[str, Any], context: ToolContext) -> ToolResult:
        # Implementation
        return ToolResult(
            success=True,
            content="Result"
        )

docs.title: Registering a Tool
docs.text:
registry = ToolRegistry()
registry.register(CustomTool())

docs.title: 1. Use Appropriate Tools
docs.text:
• Read-only tasks: Use read_file, grep, list_directory
  • File edits: Use edit_file or patch (not write_file)
  • Search: Use grep for text, code_search for semantic

docs.title: 2. Handle Errors
docs.text:
Always check ToolResult.success:

result = tool.execute(args)
if not result.success:
    print(f"Error: {result.error}")

docs.title: 3. Use Permissions
docs.text:
Configure permissions for safety:

tools:
  permissions:
    write: ask  # Confirm before file edits
    shell: ask  # Confirm before shell commands

docs.title: 4. Batch When Possible
docs.text:
Use batch tool for parallel operations:

# Faster than sequential execution
batch_tool.execute([tool1, tool2, tool3])

docs.title: Tool Not Found
docs.text:
Symptom: Tool not in registry

Solution: Use ToolRegistry.full() or register manually

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
Symptom: Tool execution blocked

Solution: Check permission configuration:

tools:
  permissions:
    write: allow  # Or 'ask' for confirmation

docs.title: Tool Errors
docs.text:
Symptom: Tool returns error

Solution: Check ToolResult.error for details

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text: • QE Features - QE tool usage

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Advanced Features Index - All advanced features
  • Tool Reference - Tool source code

docs.title: Terminal User Interface (TUI)
docs.text: SuperQode includes a rich Terminal User Interface (TUI) for interactive QE sessions.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Rich Output: Colored, formatted terminal output
  • Progress Tracking: Real-time progress indicators
  • Interactive Prompts: User input with completion
  • File Browser: Navigate project files
  • Agent Switcher: Switch between QE roles
  • Command Palette: Quick actions
  • Status Bar: Session status at a glance

docs.title: Launching the TUI
docs.text:
# Start TUI mode
superqode

# Start with specific role
superqode --role qe.security_tester

docs.title: Key Bindings
docs.text: Key Action Ctrl+K Open command palette Ctrl+F Toggle file browser Ctrl+A Switch agent/role Ctrl+S Save session Ctrl+Q Quit Escape Close modal/cancel Enter Submit input Tab Next widget Shift+Tab Previous widget : Command mode (for commands like :connect, :qe, etc.)

docs.title: Quick Actions
docs.text:
Access via Command Palette (Ctrl+K) or Command Mode (:) in TUI:

  • :connect - Connect to provider/agent
  • :qe <role> - Switch to QE role mode (e.g., :qe security_tester)
  • :view <file> - View file content
  • :help - Show all available commands

Note: QE analysis sessions are run via CLI, not TUI commands. Use superqe run . in your terminal to start QE sessions.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
TUI configuration in superqode.yaml:

superqode:
  tui:
    sidebar_width: 30
    show_line_numbers: true
    syntax_highlighting: true

docs.title: Available Widgets
docs.text: Widget Purpose Prompt User input with completion FileBrowser Navigate project files AgentSwitcher Switch QE roles CommandPalette Quick actions StatusBar Session status Throbber Loading indicator Toast Notifications DiffView Show file diffs FileViewer View files with syntax highlighting

docs.title: Example Usage
docs.text:
from superqode.widgets import FileBrowser, AgentSwitcher

# File browser
browser = FileBrowser(root=project_root)
file = await browser.select_file()

# Agent switcher
roles = [
    ("qe.security_tester", "Security Testing"),
    ("qe.performance_tester", "Performance Testing"),
]
switcher = AgentSwitcher(roles)
selected = await switcher.select()

docs.title: Integration with QE
docs.text:
The TUI allows you to interact with agents in QE roles, while QE analysis sessions are run separately via CLI:

# Start TUI
superqode

# In TUI, switch to QE role
:qe security_tester

# Run QE analysis via CLI (in separate terminal)
superqe run . --mode quick
superqe run . --mode deep

# View QE artifacts (via CLI)
superqe artifacts .
superqe dashboard

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
The TUI requires:

pip install superqode[tui]
# or
pip install textual rich

docs.title: TUI Not Starting
docs.text:
If the TUI fails to start:

  1. Check Textual installation: 

    python -c "import textual; print('Textual OK')"

  2. Verify terminal compatibility:

  3. Terminal must support ANSI escape codes

  4. Recommended: iTerm2, Alacritty, Windows Terminal

  5. Check terminal size:

  6. Minimum: 80x24
  7. Recommended: 120x40

docs.title: Performance Issues
docs.text:
For slow TUI performance:

  1. Reduce terminal size
  2. Disable syntax highlighting
  3. Use quick mode instead of deep mode

docs.title: Workspace Internals
docs.text:
The workspace system is the foundation of SuperQode's sandbox-first approach. This document explains how ephemeral workspaces provide safe, isolated environments for quality engineering.

Note: Workspace management commands shown in this document are available in SuperQode Enterprise only.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The workspace manager creates isolated environments where agents can freely modify, test, and break code without affecting your original files. All changes are tracked and reverted after the session completes.

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                    WORKSPACE LIFECYCLE                       │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                              │
│  Original Code ──► Create Snapshot ──► Run QE Session       │
│        │                                      │              │
│        │                                      ▼              │
│        │                              Agents Modify Code     │
│        │                                      │              │
│        │                                      ▼              │
│        │                              Track All Changes      │
│        │                                      │              │
│        │                                      ▼              │
│        │                              Generate Reports       │
│        │                                      │              │
│        │                                      ▼              │
│        └───────────────────────────── Revert Changes         │
│                                              │              │
│                                              ▼              │
│                                      Preserve Artifacts      │
│                                                              │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Isolation Modes
docs.text: SuperQode supports three isolation modes:

docs.title: 1. Git Worktree Mode (Optional)
docs.text:
Uses Git's worktree feature to create a separate working directory:

# SuperQode creates:
.git/worktrees/superqode-qe-abc123/
├── HEAD
├── index
└── ...

# And a working directory:
~/.superqode/working/<repo>/qe/<session-id>/
├── src/
├── tests/
└── ...

Advantages: - Fast creation (no file copying) - Full git history available - True isolation from main working tree - Efficient disk usage

When Used: - Enabled with superqe run . --worktree - Project is a git repository - Git version >= 2.15

docs.title: 2. Snapshot Mode
docs.text:
Creates a complete copy of the project directory:

# Original:
/path/to/project/
├── src/
├── tests/
└── ...

# Snapshot:
/tmp/superqode-snapshot-abc123/
├── src/
├── tests/
└── ...

Advantages: - Works with non-git projects - Simple and reliable - Complete isolation

When Used: - Not a git repository - Git worktree unavailable - Explicitly requested

docs.title: 3. Git Snapshot Mode
docs.text:
Uses git stash to save and restore state:

# Before QE:
git stash push -m "superqode-backup-abc123"

# After QE:
git stash pop

Advantages: - Lightweight - Fast - Preserves uncommitted changes

When Used: - Simple QE sessions - Quick rollback needed

docs.title: Workspace Manager
docs.text:
The manager (workspace/manager.py) orchestrates the workspace lifecycle:

class WorkspaceManager:
    def create_workspace(self, mode: str) -> Workspace:
        """Create isolated workspace."""

    def enter_workspace(self) -> None:
        """Switch to workspace context."""

    def exit_workspace(self, preserve: bool = False) -> None:
        """Exit and optionally preserve workspace."""

    def revert(self) -> None:
        """Revert all changes."""

    def get_artifacts(self) -> list[Artifact]:
        """Get generated artifacts."""

docs.title: Snapshot System
docs.text:
The snapshot system (workspace/snapshot.py) handles file copying:

Method Description create_snapshot() Copy project to temp directory restore_snapshot() Restore original state get_diff() Get changes since snapshot cleanup() Remove snapshot directory

docs.title: Git Worktree System
docs.text:
The worktree system (workspace/worktree.py) manages git worktrees:

Method Description create_worktree() Create new git worktree remove_worktree() Remove worktree sync_changes() Sync changes to main tree get_worktree_path() Get worktree directory path

docs.title: Git Guard
docs.text: The Git Guard (workspace/git_guard.py) prevents accidental git operations:

docs.title: Protected Operations
docs.text: Operation Behavior git commit Blocked with warning git push Blocked with warning git checkout Allowed (read-only) git stash Blocked (managed by SuperQode) git reset --hard Blocked

docs.title: Implementation
docs.text:
class GitGuard:
    def __init__(self, workspace_path: str):
        self.workspace_path = workspace_path
        self._install_hooks()

    def _install_hooks(self):
        """Install pre-commit/pre-push hooks."""
        # Hooks block dangerous operations

    def allow_operation(self, operation: str) -> bool:
        """Check if git operation is allowed."""

docs.title: Bypass for Advanced Users
docs.text:
# Force allow git operations (use with caution)
superqe run . --allow-git-operations

docs.title: Diff Tracking
docs.text: The diff tracker (workspace/diff_tracker.py) monitors all file changes:

docs.title: Tracked Information
docs.text: Field Description file_path Relative path to file change_type created, modified, deleted original_content Content before change new_content Content after change timestamp When change occurred agent_id Which agent made the change

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
tracker = DiffTracker(workspace)

# Track a change
tracker.record_change(
    file_path="src/api.py",
    change_type="modified",
    original=original_content,
    new=new_content
)

# Get all changes
changes = tracker.get_all_changes()

# Generate unified diff
diff = tracker.generate_unified_diff()

docs.title: Artifact Storage
docs.text:
Artifacts are stored in .superqode/qe-artifacts/:

.superqode/qe-artifacts/
├── manifest.json
├── qr/
│   ├── qr-<date>-<session>.json    # Quality Report (JSON)
│   └── qr-<date>-<session>.md      # Quality Report (Markdown)
├── patches/
│   └── ...                         # Suggested patch files (when available)
├── generated-tests/
│   └── ...                         # Generated tests (when available)
├── logs/
│   └── ...                         # Execution logs / work logs (if enabled)
└── evidence/
    └── ...                         # Screenshots, traces, captured outputs

docs.title: Artifact Types
docs.text: Type Extension Description Quality Report .json Structured findings Markdown Report .md Human-readable report Patches .patch Suggested fixes (when available) Generated Tests .py, .js New test files (when available) Logs / Evidence varies Captured outputs, traces, logs (if enabled) Manifest .json Artifact index (manifest.json)

docs.title: Coordinator
docs.text: The coordinator (workspace/coordinator.py) manages multi-agent sessions:

docs.title: Responsibilities
docs.text:
• Prevent conflicting file edits
  • Serialize access to shared resources
  • Merge changes from multiple agents
  • Resolve conflicts

docs.title: Conflict Resolution
docs.text:
Agent A: Edit src/api.py (lines 10-20)
Agent B: Edit src/api.py (lines 50-60)
         ──► No conflict, both allowed

Agent A: Edit src/api.py (lines 10-20)
Agent B: Edit src/api.py (lines 15-25)
         ──► Conflict detected!
         ──► Agent B must wait or merge

docs.title: File Watcher
docs.text: The watcher (workspace/watcher.py) monitors filesystem changes:

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Real-time change detection
  • Debounced notifications
  • Ignore patterns (node_modules, .git)
  • Event types: created, modified, deleted, moved

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
workspace:
  watcher:
    enabled: true
    debounce_ms: 100
    ignore_patterns:
      - "node_modules/**"
      - ".git/**"
      - "*.pyc"
      - "__pycache__/**"

docs.title: Revert Guarantees
docs.text: SuperQode guarantees original code is preserved:

docs.title: Revert Process
docs.text:
1. Session Ends - QE session completes (success or error)
  2. Artifacts Saved - All findings/patches stored
  3. Changes Reverted - Workspace changes undone
  4. Worktree Removed - Temporary worktree deleted
  5. Original Restored - Main working tree unchanged

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Session Error
     │
     ▼
Save Artifacts (if possible)
     │
     ▼
Attempt Revert
     │
     ├──► Success: Clean state
     │
     └──► Failure: Preserve workspace for debugging
                   Log recovery instructions

docs.title: Manual Recovery
docs.text:
If automatic revert fails:

# List preserved workspaces
superqode workspace list

# Manually revert a workspace
superqode workspace revert --session abc123

# Force cleanup (dangerous)
superqode workspace cleanup --force

docs.title: Preserve Workspace
docs.text:
Keep the workspace after session for debugging:

superqe run . --preserve-workspace

docs.title: Skip Revert
docs.text:
Don't revert changes (for applying fixes):

superqe run . --no-revert

docs.title: Workspace Info
docs.text:
Inspect current workspace state:

superqode workspace info

# Output:
# Workspace: /tmp/superqode-qe-abc123
# Mode: worktree
# Created: 2024-01-15 10:30:45
# Changes: 5 files modified
# Status: active

docs.title: View Changes
docs.text:
See all changes made in workspace:

superqode workspace diff

# Or for specific session
superqode workspace diff --session abc123

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
workspace:
  # Default isolation mode: snapshot, worktree, git_snapshot
  default_mode: snapshot

  # Preserve on error for debugging
  preserve_on_error: true

  # Cleanup old workspaces after N hours
  cleanup_after_hours: 24

  # Maximum workspace size (MB)
  max_size_mb: 1000

  # Files to exclude from snapshot
  exclude_patterns:
    - "node_modules/**"
    - ".git/**"
    - "*.pyc"
    - "venv/**"
    - ".venv/**"

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Architecture Overview - System architecture
  • Safety & Permissions - Security model
  • Ephemeral Workspace Concept - User guide
  • Session Management - Session handling

docs.title: API Reference
docs.text: Programmatic access to SuperQode functionality through Python SDK and JSONL events.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The SuperQode API provides two main interfaces:

  1. Python SDK: High-level Python APIs for orchestrating QE sessions
  2. JSONL Events: Machine-readable event stream for CI/CD integration

docs.title: Python SDK
docs.text:
from pathlib import Path
from superqode.superqe import QEOrchestrator

orchestrator = QEOrchestrator(Path("."))
result = await orchestrator.quick_scan()

print(f"Verdict: {result.verdict}")
print(f"Findings: {len(result.findings)}")

docs.title: JSONL Events
docs.text:
# Stream events to stdout
superqe run . --jsonl

# Stream to file
superqe run . --jsonl > events.jsonl

docs.title: Python SDK
docs.text:
Complete Python API reference:

  • QEOrchestrator: High-level QE session orchestration
  • QESession: Lower-level session management
  • WorkspaceManager: Ephemeral workspace control
  • Event Handling: Subscribe to QE events

Use for: - Custom Python scripts - CI/CD integrations - Automated quality gates - Programmatic QE workflows

docs.title: JSONL Events
docs.text:
Event streaming API:

  • Event Types: Complete event catalog
  • Event Format: JSON structure and fields
  • CI/CD Integration: GitHub Actions, GitLab CI, Jenkins
  • Event Parsing: Python, JavaScript, jq examples

Use for: - CI/CD pipeline integration - Real-time monitoring - Custom reporting tools - Event-driven workflows

docs.title: CI/CD Quality Gate
docs.text:
from superqode.superqe import QEOrchestrator

orchestrator = QEOrchestrator(Path("."))
result = await orchestrator.quick_scan()

if result.verdict == "fail":
    exit(1)

docs.title: Custom QE Workflow
docs.text:
from superqode.superqe import QESession, QESessionConfig, QEMode

config = QESessionConfig(
    mode=QEMode.DEEP_QE,
    agent_roles=["security_tester"],
    generate_patches=True
)

session = QESession(Path("."), config)
result = await session.run()

docs.title: Event Monitoring
docs.text:
from superqode.superqe.events import QEEventCollector

collector = QEEventCollector()
emitter.add_handler(collector.collect)

# After QE
summary = collector.get_summary()

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text: See JSONL Events - CI/CD Integration for complete examples.

docs.title: Custom Script
docs.text:
import asyncio
from pathlib import Path
from superqode.superqe import QEOrchestrator

async def main():
    orchestrator = QEOrchestrator(Path("."))
    result = await orchestrator.quick_scan()

    # Process results
    print(f"Verdict: {result.verdict}")
    for finding in result.findings:
        print(f"- {finding['severity']}: {finding['title']}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Concepts - Core concepts and architecture
  • CLI Reference - Command-line interface
  • Integration - CI/CD and tool integration

docs.title: JSONL Events API
docs.text: SuperQode emits structured JSONL (JSON Lines) events during QE sessions for CI/CD integration, real-time monitoring, and programmatic access to QE results.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
JSONL events provide a machine-readable stream of all QE activities:

  • CI-friendly: Pipe directly to CI/CD pipelines
  • Real-time: Stream events as they occur
  • Structured: Consistent JSON format for easy parsing
  • Complete: Covers all aspects of QE sessions

docs.title: Event Format
docs.text:
Each event is a single JSON object on one line:

{"type":"qe.started","session_id":"qe-20250115-143022","mode":"quick","timestamp":"2025-01-15T14:30:22Z","project_root":"/path/to/project","roles":["api_tester"]}

Structure: - type: Event type identifier - timestamp: ISO 8601 timestamp - Additional fields depend on event type

docs.title: qe.started
docs.text:
QE session started.

{
  "type": "qe.started",
  "timestamp": "2025-01-15T14:30:22Z",
  "session_id": "qe-20250115-143022",
  "mode": "quick",
  "project_root": "/path/to/project",
  "roles": ["api_tester", "security_tester"]
}

docs.title: qe.completed
docs.text:
QE session completed successfully.

{
  "type": "qe.completed",
  "timestamp": "2025-01-15T14:31:45Z",
  "session_id": "qe-20250115-143022",
  "verdict": "pass",
  "findings_count": 3,
  "duration_seconds": 83.5,
  "tests_generated": 2,
  "patches_generated": 1
}

Verdicts: - pass: No critical findings - warning: Medium/low severity findings - fail: Critical/high severity findings

docs.title: qe.failed
docs.text:
QE session failed with error.

{
  "type": "qe.failed",
  "timestamp": "2025-01-15T14:32:10Z",
  "session_id": "qe-20250115-143022",
  "error": "Timeout after 60 seconds",
  "duration_seconds": 60.0
}

docs.title: turn.started
docs.text:
A new turn/phase started.

{
  "type": "turn.started",
  "timestamp": "2025-01-15T14:30:25Z",
  "turn_number": 1,
  "phase": "test_execution"
}

docs.title: turn.completed
docs.text:
Turn/phase completed.

{
  "type": "turn.completed",
  "timestamp": "2025-01-15T14:30:45Z",
  "turn_number": 1,
  "phase": "test_execution",
  "duration_seconds": 20.5
}

docs.title: test.suite.started
docs.text:
Test suite execution started.

{
  "type": "test.suite.started",
  "timestamp": "2025-01-15T14:30:30Z",
  "suite": "smoke",
  "test_count": 15
}

Suite types: - smoke: Smoke tests - sanity: Sanity tests - regression: Regression tests

docs.title: test.suite.completed
docs.text:
Test suite completed.

{
  "type": "test.suite.completed",
  "timestamp": "2025-01-15T14:30:50Z",
  "suite": "smoke",
  "passed": 14,
  "failed": 1,
  "skipped": 0,
  "duration_seconds": 20.0
}

docs.title: test.started
docs.text:
Individual test started.

{
  "type": "test.started",
  "timestamp": "2025-01-15T14:30:35Z",
  "name": "test_user_authentication",
  "suite": "smoke"
}

docs.title: test.completed
docs.text:

docs.title: Basic Streaming
docs.text:
Stream events to stdout:

superqe run . --jsonl

Stream to file:

superqe run . --jsonl > events.jsonl

docs.title: Programmatic Usage
docs.text:
from superqode.superqe.events import QEEventEmitter
import sys

# Stream to stdout
emitter = QEEventEmitter(sys.stdout)

emitter.emit_qe_started(
    session_id="qe-001",
    mode="quick",
    project_root="/path/to/project",
    roles=["api_tester"]
)

docs.title: Collecting Events
docs.text:
Collect events in memory:

from superqode.superqe.events import QEEventCollector

collector = QEEventCollector()

# Register with emitter
emitter.add_handler(collector.collect)

# After QE session
findings = collector.get_findings()
tests = collector.get_tests()
summary = collector.get_summary()

# Export to JSONL
jsonl_data = collector.to_jsonl()
collector.save(Path("events.jsonl"))

docs.title: Event Handlers
docs.text:
Register custom event handlers:

def handle_finding(event: QEEvent):
    if event.type == "finding.detected":
        finding = event.data
        if finding["severity"] == "critical":
            send_alert(finding)

emitter.add_handler(handle_finding)

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
- name: Run SuperQode
  run: |
    superqe run . --jsonl > qe-events.jsonl

- name: Parse Results
  run: |
    # Count critical findings
    critical_count=$(jq -r 'select(.type=="finding.detected" and .severity=="critical") | .id' qe-events.jsonl | wc -l)
    if [ "$critical_count" -gt 0 ]; then
      echo "[INCORRECT] Found $critical_count critical findings"
      exit 1
    fi

docs.title: Jenkins
docs.text:
stage('Quality Engineering') {
    sh 'superqe run . --jsonl > qe-events.jsonl'

    def events = readJSON file: 'qe-events.jsonl'
    def findings = events.findAll { it.type == 'finding.detected' }

    if (findings.any { it.severity == 'critical' }) {
        error('Critical findings detected')
    }
}

docs.title: Python
docs.text:
import json
from pathlib import Path

def parse_events(jsonl_path: Path):
    findings = []
    tests = []

    with open(jsonl_path) as f:
        for line in f:
            event = json.loads(line)

            if event["type"] == "finding.detected":
                findings.append(event)
            elif event["type"] in ["test.completed", "test.failed"]:
                tests.append(event)

    return findings, tests

docs.title: JavaScript/Node.js
docs.text:
const fs = require('fs');

function parseEvents(jsonlPath) {
    const events = fs.readFileSync(jsonlPath, 'utf-8')
        .split('\n')
        .filter(line => line.trim())
        .map(line => JSON.parse(line));

    const findings = events.filter(e => e.type === 'finding.detected');
    const tests = events.filter(e =>
        ['test.completed', 'test.failed'].includes(e.type)
    );

    return { findings, tests };
}

docs.title: jq (Command-line)
docs.text:
# Get all critical findings
jq -r 'select(.type=="finding.detected" and .severity=="critical")' events.jsonl

# Get test summary
jq -r 'select(.type=="test.suite.completed") | "\(.suite): \(.passed)/\(.total) passed"' events.jsonl

# Get session summary
jq -r 'select(.type=="qe.completed") | "Verdict: \(.verdict), Findings: \(.findings_count)"' events.jsonl

docs.title: 1. Filter by Event Type
docs.text:
Only process relevant events:

relevant_types = {
    "finding.detected",
    "test.failed",
    "qe.completed"
}

for event in events:
    if event["type"] in relevant_types:
        process(event)

docs.title: 2. Handle Timestamps
docs.text:
Parse ISO 8601 timestamps:

from datetime import datetime

timestamp = datetime.fromisoformat(event["timestamp"].replace('Z', '+00:00'))

docs.title: 3. Aggregate Results
docs.text:
Build summary from events:

def summarize_events(events):
    summary = {
        "findings": {"critical": 0, "high": 0, "medium": 0},
        "tests": {"passed": 0, "failed": 0, "total": 0},
        "duration": 0
    }

    for event in events:
        if event["type"] == "finding.detected":
            severity = event["severity"]
            summary["findings"][severity] = summary["findings"].get(severity, 0) + 1
        elif event["type"] == "test.completed":
            summary["tests"]["passed"] += 1
            summary["tests"]["total"] += 1
        elif event["type"] == "qe.completed":
            summary["duration"] = event["duration_seconds"]

    return summary

docs.title: Event Flow Example
docs.text:
Typical event sequence for a QE session:

qe.started
  ├─ workspace.snapshot
  ├─ test.suite.started (smoke)
  │   ├─ test.started
  │   ├─ test.completed
  │   └─ test.suite.completed
  ├─ turn.started (agent_analysis)
  │   ├─ agent.started
  │   ├─ finding.detected (multiple)
  │   └─ agent.completed
  ├─ artifact.generated (patches)
  ├─ workspace.reverted
  └─ qe.completed
