docs.title: Parsing Errors
docs.text:
Ensure valid JSONL format:

# Validate JSONL
while IFS= read -r line; do
    echo "$line" | jq . > /dev/null || echo "Invalid JSON: $line"
done < events.jsonl

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Python SDK - Programmatic API access
  • CI/CD Integration - CI/CD workflows
  • QE Commands - CLI options

docs.title: Python SDK
docs.text: Programmatic API for SuperQode, enabling integration into Python applications, scripts, and CI/CD pipelines.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The SuperQode Python SDK provides high-level interfaces for:

  • QE Orchestration: Run Quick Scan and Deep QE sessions
  • Session Management: Create, manage, and monitor QE sessions
  • Workspace Control: Manage ephemeral workspaces and snapshots
  • Event Handling: Subscribe to JSONL events
  • Result Processing: Access findings, test results, and artifacts

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
The SDK is included with SuperQode:

pip install superqode

Import the SDK:

from superqode.superqe import QEOrchestrator, QESession, QESessionConfig
from superqode.workspace import WorkspaceManager, GitWorktreeManager

docs.title: QE Orchestrator
docs.text: High-level interface for running QE sessions.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
from pathlib import Path
from superqode.superqe import QEOrchestrator

# Initialize orchestrator
orchestrator = QEOrchestrator(
    project_root=Path("."),
    verbose=True,
    output_format="rich",  # or "json", "jsonl", "plain"
    use_worktree=False,
    allow_suggestions=False
)

# Quick Scan
result = await orchestrator.quick_scan()

# Deep QE
result = await orchestrator.deep_qe()

# Run specific roles
result = await orchestrator.run_roles(["api_tester", "security_tester"])

docs.title: Quick Scan
docs.text:
Time-boxed, shallow analysis:

result = await orchestrator.quick_scan(
    on_progress=lambda msg: print(f"Progress: {msg}")
)

print(f"Verdict: {result.verdict}")
print(f"Findings: {len(result.findings)}")
print(f"Duration: {result.duration_seconds:.1f}s")

Characteristics: - Fast (60 seconds default) - Shallow exploration - High-risk paths only - Minimal QR

Best for: Pre-commit, developer laptop, fast CI feedback

docs.title: Deep QE
docs.text:
Comprehensive analysis:

result = await orchestrator.deep_qe(
    on_progress=lambda msg: print(f"Progress: {msg}")
)

# Access detailed results
for finding in result.findings:
    print(f"{finding['severity']}: {finding['title']}")
    print(f"  Location: {finding['file_path']}:{finding.get('line_number')}")

Characteristics: - Full sandbox - Destructive testing allowed - Comprehensive QR - Multi-agent analysis

Best for: Pre-release, nightly CI, compliance evidence

docs.title: Custom Configuration
docs.text:
from superqode.superqe import QESessionConfig, QEMode

config = QESessionConfig(
    mode=QEMode.QUICK_SCAN,
    timeout_seconds=120,
    run_smoke=True,
    run_sanity=True,
    run_regression=False,
    run_agent_analysis=True,
    agent_roles=["security_tester", "api_tester"],
    generate_patches=True,
    generate_tests=True,
    generate_qr=True,
    verbose=True
)

result = await orchestrator.run(config)

docs.title: Running Specific Roles
docs.text:
result = await orchestrator.run_roles(
    role_names=["api_tester", "security_tester"],
    on_progress=lambda msg: print(msg)
)

# Access aggregated results
print(f"Total findings: {len(result.findings)}")
print(f"Tests: {result.tests_passed}/{result.total_tests} passed")

docs.title: QE Session
docs.text: Lower-level session management for fine-grained control.

docs.title: Session Lifecycle
docs.text:
from superqode.superqe import QESession, QESessionConfig, QEMode

config = QESessionConfig(
    mode=QEMode.DEEP_QE,
    timeout_seconds=300,
    run_agent_analysis=True,
    agent_roles=["security_tester"]
)

session = QESession(
    project_root=Path("."),
    config=config
)

# Run session
result = await session.run()

# Access session ID
print(f"Session ID: {session.session_id}")

# Access result
print(f"Status: {result.status}")
print(f"Verdict: {result.verdict}")

docs.title: Session Result
docs.text:
QESessionResult provides comprehensive session data:

result: QESessionResult

# Basic info
result.session_id
result.mode  # QEMode.QUICK_SCAN or QEMode.DEEP_QE
result.status  # QEStatus enum
result.verdict  # "pass", "warning", "fail"
result.duration_seconds

# Test results
result.total_tests
result.tests_passed
result.tests_failed
result.tests_skipped
result.smoke_result  # TestSuiteResult
result.sanity_result  # TestSuiteResult
result.regression_result  # TestSuiteResult

# Findings
result.findings  # List[Dict[str, Any]]

# Artifacts
result.patches_generated
result.tests_generated
result.qr_path  # Path to QR JSON

# Errors
result.errors  # List[str]

# Suggestions (if allow_suggestions enabled)
result.verified_fixes  # List[Dict[str, Any]]
result.allow_suggestions_enabled

docs.title: Accessing Test Results
docs.text:
# Smoke tests
if result.smoke_result:
    smoke = result.smoke_result
    print(f"Smoke: {smoke.passed}/{smoke.total_tests} passed")

# Sanity tests
if result.sanity_result:
    sanity = result.sanity_result
    print(f"Sanity: {sanity.passed}/{sanity.total_tests} passed")

# Regression tests
if result.regression_result:
    regression = result.regression_result
    print(f"Regression: {regression.passed}/{regression.total_tests} passed")

docs.title: Accessing Findings
docs.text:
for finding in result.findings:
    print(f"ID: {finding['id']}")
    print(f"Severity: {finding['severity']}")
    print(f"Title: {finding['title']}")
    print(f"Description: {finding.get('description')}")
    print(f"Location: {finding.get('file_path')}:{finding.get('line_number')}")
    print(f"Confidence: {finding.get('confidence', 1.0)}")

    # Suggested fix (if available)
    if finding.get('suggested_fix'):
        print(f"Fix: {finding['suggested_fix']}")

    # Agent info
    if finding.get('agent'):
        print(f"Found by: {finding['agent']}")

    # Tool calls (if available)
    if finding.get('tool_calls'):
        print(f"Tools: {', '.join(finding['tool_calls'])}")

docs.title: Workspace Manager
docs.text:
Manage ephemeral workspaces:

from superqode.workspace import WorkspaceManager, WorkspaceState

manager = WorkspaceManager(project_root=Path("."))

# Initialize workspace
manager.initialize()

# Start session
session_id = manager.start_session()

# Check state
print(f"State: {manager.state}")  # WorkspaceState enum
print(f"Active: {manager.is_active}")

# Add findings
manager.add_finding(
    severity="high",
    title="Security issue",
    description="Potential SQL injection",
    file_path="src/api/users.py",
    line_number=42
)

# End session (reverts changes, generates QR)
ws_result = manager.end_session(generate_qr=True)
print(f"Patches: {ws_result.patches_generated}")
print(f"Tests: {ws_result.tests_generated}")

docs.title: Git Worktree Manager
docs.text:
Create isolated worktrees:

from superqode.workspace import GitWorktreeManager

worktree_manager = GitWorktreeManager(project_root=Path("."))

# Create QE worktree
worktree = await worktree_manager.create_qe_worktree(
    session_id="qe-20250115",
    base_ref="HEAD",
    copy_uncommitted=True,
    keep_gitignored=True
)

print(f"Worktree path: {worktree.path}")
print(f"Base commit: {worktree.base_commit}")

# ... run QE in worktree ...

# Remove worktree
await worktree_manager.remove_worktree(worktree)

docs.title: Git Snapshot Manager
docs.text:
Create and restore snapshots:

from superqode.workspace import GitSnapshotManager

snapshot_manager = GitSnapshotManager(project_root=Path("."))

# Create snapshot
snapshot_id = await snapshot_manager.create_snapshot(
    message="Before QE session"
)

# ... modify files ...

# Get changes
changes = await snapshot_manager.get_changes(snapshot_id)
for change in changes:
    print(f"{change.status}: {change.path}")

# Restore snapshot
await snapshot_manager.restore_snapshot(snapshot_id)

docs.title: Event Emitter
docs.text:
Subscribe to JSONL events:

from superqode.superqe.events import QEEventEmitter, EventType
import sys

emitter = QEEventEmitter(sys.stdout)

# Custom handler
def handle_finding(event):
    if event.type == EventType.FINDING_DETECTED.value:
        finding = event.data
        if finding["severity"] == "critical":
            send_alert(finding)

emitter.add_handler(handle_finding)

# Use with orchestrator
# Events will be emitted automatically during QE sessions

docs.title: Example: Custom CI Script
docs.text:
import asyncio
from pathlib import Path
from superqode.superqe import QEOrchestrator

async def run_qe_in_ci():
    orchestrator = QEOrchestrator(
        project_root=Path("."),
        verbose=False,
        output_format="plain"
    )

    # Run quick scan
    result = await orchestrator.quick_scan()

    # Check verdict
    if result.verdict == "fail":
        critical = [f for f in result.findings if f["severity"] == "critical"]
        if critical:
            print(f"[INCORRECT] Found {len(critical)} critical findings")
            for f in critical:
                print(f"  - {f['title']} ({f['file_path']})")
            exit(1)

    # Check test failures
    if result.tests_failed > 0:
        print(f"[INCORRECT] {result.tests_failed} tests failed")
        exit(1)

    print("[CORRECT] All checks passed")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(run_qe_in_ci())

docs.title: Example: Custom QE Workflow
docs.text:
import asyncio
from pathlib import Path
from superqode.superqe import QESession, QESessionConfig, QEMode
from superqode.workspace import GitWorktreeManager

async def custom_qe_workflow():
    project_root = Path(".")

    # Create worktree
    worktree_manager = GitWorktreeManager(project_root)
    worktree = await worktree_manager.create_qe_worktree(
        session_id="custom-qe-001",
        base_ref="HEAD"
    )

    try:
        # Configure session
        config = QESessionConfig(
            mode=QEMode.DEEP_QE,
            run_agent_analysis=True,
            agent_roles=["security_tester"],
            generate_patches=True
        )

        # Run session in worktree
        session = QESession(worktree.path, config)
        result = await session.run()

        # Process results
        for finding in result.findings:
            if finding["severity"] in ["critical", "high"]:
                print(f"WARNING: {finding['severity']}: {finding['title']}")

        # Access QR
        if result.qr_path:
            print(f"QR: {result.qr_path}")

    finally:
        # Cleanup worktree
        await worktree_manager.remove_worktree(worktree)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(custom_qe_workflow())

docs.title: Example: Event Monitoring
docs.text:
import asyncio
from pathlib import Path
from superqode.superqe import QEOrchestrator
from superqode.superqe.events import QEEventCollector, EventType

async def monitor_qe_session():
    # Create collector
    collector = QEEventCollector()

    # Set up orchestrator with event handler
    orchestrator = QEOrchestrator(Path("."))

    # Register collector (if using global emitter)
    from superqode.superqe.events import get_event_emitter
    emitter = get_event_emitter()
    if emitter:
        emitter.add_handler(collector.collect)

    # Run QE
    result = await orchestrator.quick_scan()

    # Analyze events
    findings = collector.get_findings()
    tests = collector.get_tests()
    summary = collector.get_summary()

    print(f"Events collected: {summary['total_events']}")
    print(f"Findings: {summary['findings']['total']}")
    print(f"Tests: {summary['tests']['total']}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(monitor_qe_session())

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
from superqode.superqe import QESession, QEStatus

try:
    session = QESession(Path("."))
    result = await session.run()

    if result.status == QEStatus.FAILED:
        print("QE session failed:")
        for error in result.errors:
            print(f"  - {error}")

    elif result.status == QEStatus.COMPLETED:
        print(f"[CORRECT] Session completed: {result.verdict}")

except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error: {e}")

docs.title: 1. Use Async/Await
docs.text:
All QE operations are async:

# [CORRECT] Correct
result = await orchestrator.quick_scan()

# [INCORRECT] Incorrect
result = orchestrator.quick_scan()  # Returns coroutine

docs.title: 2. Handle Errors
docs.text:
Always check result status:

result = await session.run()

if result.status == QEStatus.FAILED:
    handle_failure(result.errors)
elif result.status == QEStatus.COMPLETED:
    process_results(result)

docs.title: 3. Resource Cleanup
docs.text:
Use context managers or try/finally:

worktree = await worktree_manager.create_qe_worktree(...)
try:
    # ... use worktree ...
finally:
    await worktree_manager.remove_worktree(worktree)

docs.title: 4. Progress Reporting
docs.text:
Use progress callbacks for long-running operations:

def on_progress(msg: str):
    logger.info(f"QE Progress: {msg}")

result = await orchestrator.deep_qe(on_progress=on_progress)

docs.title: QEOrchestrator
docs.text: Methods: - quick_scan(on_progress=None) -> QESessionResult - deep_qe(on_progress=None) -> QESessionResult - run(config, on_progress=None) -> QESessionResult - run_roles(role_names, on_progress=None) -> QESessionResult

docs.title: QESession
docs.text:
Methods: - run() -> QESessionResult - validate_patches(changes) -> HarnessResult

Properties: - session_id: Optional[str] - result: Optional[QESessionResult]

docs.title: QESessionConfig
docs.text: Fields: - mode: QEMode - timeout_seconds: int - run_smoke: bool - run_sanity: bool - run_regression: bool - run_agent_analysis: bool - agent_roles: List[str] - generate_patches: bool - generate_tests: bool - generate_qr: bool - verbose: bool

docs.title: WorkspaceManager
docs.text: Methods: - initialize() -> None - start_session(config) -> str - end_session(generate_qr=True) -> WorkspaceResult - add_finding(...) -> None - get_findings() -> List[Finding]

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• JSONL Events - Event streaming API
  • Workspace Concepts - Workspace details
  • QE Modes - Quick Scan vs Deep QE

docs.title: CLI Reference
docs.text: SuperQE provides the automation CLI for quality engineering tasks. SuperQode focuses on the developer TUI and includes helper commands for agents, providers, and configuration. This reference documents the available commands, options, and usage patterns.

docs.title: Command Structure
docs.text:
superqe [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...
superqe advanced [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...
superqode [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

docs.title: Global Options
docs.text: Option CLI Description --version superqe, superqode Show version and exit --help superqe, superqode Show help message and exit --tui superqode Force the Textual TUI (default)

docs.title: Command Groups
docs.text:
• QE Commands (superqe)

    Quality engineering commands for running QE sessions, viewing reports, and managing artifacts.

    QE Commands

  • SuperQE Advanced (superqe advanced)

    Advanced quality engineering with CodeOptiX integration - AI-powered evaluation capabilities.

    SuperQE Commands

  • Config Commands (superqode config)

    Configuration management commands for viewing, validating, and modifying settings.

    Config Commands

  • Provider Commands (superqode providers)

    Commands for managing BYOK providers, testing connections, and listing available models.

    Provider Commands

  • Suggestion Commands (superqode suggestions)

    Commands for reviewing and applying verified fix suggestions from QE sessions.

    Suggestion Commands

  • Agents Commands (superqode agents)

    Commands for listing, showing, and managing ACP coding agents.

    Agents Commands

  • Auth Commands (superqode auth)

    Show authentication and security information for providers and agents.

    Auth Commands

  • Roles Commands

    Commands for viewing and inspecting team roles and their configuration.

    Roles Commands

  • Serve Commands

    Start LSP and web servers for IDE and browser integration.

    Serve Commands

  • Init Commands

    Initialize SuperQode configuration for a project.

    Init Commands

docs.title: QE Commands
docs.text: Command Description superqe run . Run QE session on current directory superqe run . --mode quick Quick 60-second scan superqe run . --mode deep Deep 30-minute analysis superqe run . -r security_tester Run specific role superqe roles List available QE roles superqe status Show workspace status superqe artifacts List QE artifacts superqe report View latest QR superqe logs View agent work logs superqe dashboard Open QR in web browser superqe feedback Provide feedback on findings superqe suppressions Manage finding suppressions

docs.title: SuperQE Advanced Commands
docs.text: Command Description superqe advanced run . Enhanced evaluation with CodeOptiX superqe advanced run . --behaviors security-vulnerabilities Security-focused SuperQE superqe advanced behaviors List SuperQE enhanced behaviors superqe advanced agent-eval . --agents claude-code,codex Compare AI agents superqe advanced scenarios generate . --behavior security Generate Bloom scenarios

docs.title: Config Commands
docs.text: Command Description superqe init Create superqode.yaml in the current directory (recommended) superqode config init --force Initialize config (overwrite if present) superqode config list-modes List configured modes and roles superqode config set-model MODE.ROLE MODEL Set model for a mode/role superqode config set-agent MODE.ROLE AGENT Set ACP agent for a mode/role superqode config enable-role MODE.ROLE Enable a role superqode config disable-role MODE.ROLE Disable a role

docs.title: Provider Commands
docs.text: Command Description superqode providers list List available providers superqode providers show PROVIDER Show provider details superqode providers test PROVIDER Test provider connection superqode providers mlx ACTION Manage MLX models

docs.title: Suggestion Commands
docs.text: Command Description superqode suggestions list List verified fix suggestions superqode suggestions show ID Show suggestion details superqode suggestions apply ID Apply a suggestion superqode suggestions reject ID Reject a suggestion

docs.title: TUI Commands
docs.text:
When running the interactive TUI (superqode), prefix commands with ::

TUI Command Description :connect or :c Interactive connection picker (recommended) :connect acp opencode Connect directly to ACP agent :connect byok <provider> <model> Connect directly to BYOK provider :connect local <provider> <model> Connect directly to local model :qe <role> Switch to QE role mode (e.g., :qe security_tester) :superqe run . --behaviors security Run SuperQE enhanced evaluation :superqe behaviors List SuperQE enhanced behaviors :disconnect Disconnect current session :status Show session status :help Show help :quit Exit SuperQode

docs.title: Exit Codes
docs.text: Code Meaning 0 Success 1 Error or findings detected 130 Interrupted (Ctrl+C)

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Description SUPERQODE_CONFIG Path to configuration file SUPERQODE_OUTPUT_DIR Default output directory SUPERQODE_LOG_LEVEL Logging level (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR) ANTHROPIC_API_KEY Anthropic API key OPENAI_API_KEY OpenAI API key GOOGLE_API_KEY Google AI API key DEEPSEEK_API_KEY Deepseek API key GROQ_API_KEY Groq API key OPENROUTER_API_KEY OpenRouter API key

docs.title: Detailed Command Reference
docs.text:
For detailed documentation of each command group:

  • QE Commands - Quality engineering operations
  • SuperQE Commands - Advanced quality engineering with CodeOptiX
  • Config Commands - Configuration management
  • Provider Commands - Provider management
  • Suggestion Commands - Fix suggestion handling
  • Agents Commands - ACP agent management
  • Auth Commands - Authentication and security
  • Roles Commands - Team roles management
  • Serve Commands - Server commands for IDE/web
  • Init Commands - Project initialization

docs.title: Agents Commands
docs.text: Manage ACP (Agent Client Protocol) coding agents for SuperQode.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The superqode agents command group provides commands for discovering, installing, and managing ACP coding agents. ACP agents are external coding assistants that integrate with SuperQode via the Agent Client Protocol.

docs.title: agents list
docs.text:
List all available coding agents.

superqode agents list [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --protocol Filter by protocol: acp or external --supported Show only supported agents

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# List all agents
superqode agents list

# List only ACP agents
superqode agents list --protocol acp

# List only supported agents
superqode agents list --supported

docs.title: Output
docs.text: Shows a table with: - Agent: Agent identifier - Name: Full agent name - Protocol: ACP or EXTERNAL - Status: [CORRECT] Supported, 🔜 Coming Soon, or Experimental - Description: Brief agent description

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
Coding Agents
┌───────────┬──────────────────┬──────────┬─────────────────────┬────────────────────────────┐
│ Agent     │ Name             │ Protocol │ Status              │ Description                │
├───────────┼──────────────────┼──────────┼─────────────────────┼────────────────────────────┤
│ opencode  │ OpenCode         │ ACP      │ [CORRECT] Supported        │ Full-featured coding agent │
│ codex     │ Codex            │ ACP      │ Experimental         │ OpenAI ACP adapter         │
└───────────┴──────────────────┴──────────┴─────────────────────┴────────────────────────────┘

Total: 15 agents, 8 supported

The actual list is generated from built-in agent cards plus any local agent definitions on your machine.

docs.title: agents show
docs.text:
Show detailed information about a specific agent.

superqode agents show AGENT_ID

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description AGENT_ID Agent identifier (e.g., opencode, claude)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Show OpenCode agent details
superqode agents show opencode

# Show Claude Code agent details
superqode agents show claude

docs.title: Output
docs.text: Displays detailed agent information including: - Agent name and identifier - Protocol type - Status (Supported/Coming Soon/Experimental) - Connection type - Description - Capabilities - Authentication requirements - Setup instructions - Configuration example

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
Agent: SST OpenCode
ID: opencode
Protocol: ACP
Status: [CORRECT] Supported
Connection: stdio

Description:
  Full-featured coding agent with file editing, shell access, MCP support

Capabilities:
  • File editing
  • Shell command execution
  • MCP tool integration
  • Git operations

Authentication:
  Managed by OpenCode CLI (run `opencode /connect`)

Setup:
  npm i -g opencode-ai

Usage in superqode.yaml:
  team:
    dev:
      roles:
        my-role:
          mode: "acp"
          agent: "opencode"
          agent_config:
            provider: "anthropic"
            model: "claude-sonnet-4-20250514"
          job_description: |
            Your job description here...

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text:
• superqode connect acp <agent> - Connect to an ACP agent
  • superqode providers list - List BYOK providers
  • superqode config list-modes - View configured modes and roles

docs.title: Agent Status Types
docs.text: Status Description [CORRECT] Supported Fully tested and ready for production use 🔜 Coming Soon Planned for future release ** Experimental** Available but may have limitations

docs.title: Discover Available Agents
docs.text:
# See all available agents
superqode agents list

# Filter to only supported ACP agents
superqode agents list --protocol acp --supported

docs.title: Get Agent Details
docs.text:
# View details for a specific agent
superqode agents show opencode

docs.title: Configure Agent in Team
docs.text:
After finding an agent, add it to your superqode.yaml:

team:
  dev:
    roles:
      coding_assistant:
        mode: "acp"
        agent: "opencode"  # From agents list
        agent_config:
          provider: "anthropic"
          model: "claude-sonnet-4-20250514"
        job_description: |
          You are a coding assistant...

docs.title: Agent Not Found
docs.text:
Error: Agent 'unknown-agent' not found

Solution: Use superqode agents list to see available agents.

docs.title: Agent Installation
docs.text:
Some agents require installation before use. Check the agent's setup instructions:

superqode agents show <agent-id>

The output includes setup commands and prerequisites.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Provider Commands - BYOK provider management
  • Config Commands - Configuration management
  • Team Configuration - Team and role setup

docs.title: Auth Commands
docs.text: Show authentication and security information for SuperQode.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The superqode auth command group provides commands for inspecting authentication status, checking API key configuration, and understanding security practices. SuperQode NEVER stores API keys - this command shows where keys are stored and who controls them.

docs.title: Security Principle
docs.text:
SuperQode NEVER stores API keys

All credentials are read from YOUR environment at runtime. You control where and how your keys are stored.

docs.title: auth info
docs.text:
Show comprehensive authentication information for all providers and agents.

superqode auth info

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Show all auth information
superqode auth info

docs.title: Output
docs.text: Displays three sections:

docs.title: 1. BYOK Mode (Direct LLM)
docs.text: Shows status for common providers: - Provider: Provider identifier - Env Variable: Environment variable name for API key - Status: [CORRECT] Set or [INCORRECT] Not set - Source: Where the env var is detected (e.g., ~/.zshrc, .env, environment)

docs.title: 2. ACP Mode (Coding Agents)
docs.text: Shows authentication status for ACP agents: - Agent: Agent identifier - Auth Location: Where the agent stores its credentials - Status: [CORRECT] Configured or WARNING: Check agent

docs.title: 3. Data Flow
docs.text: Shows how data flows through the system: - BYOK: You → SuperQode → LiteLLM → Provider API - ACP: You → SuperQode → Agent (e.g., opencode) → Provider API

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
SuperQode Auth Information

🔒 SECURITY PRINCIPLE: SuperQode NEVER stores your API keys.

All credentials are read from YOUR environment at runtime.
You control where and how your keys are stored.

═══ BYOK MODE (Direct LLM) ═══

Your API keys are read from YOUR environment variables:

┌─────────────┬──────────────────┬───────────┬─────────────┐
│ Provider    │ Env Variable     │ Status    │ Source      │
├─────────────┼──────────────────┼───────────┼─────────────┤
│ anthropic   │ ANTHROPIC_API_KEY│ [CORRECT] Set    │ ~/.zshrc    │
│ openai      │ OPENAI_API_KEY   │ [INCORRECT] Not set│ -           │
│ google      │ GOOGLE_API_KEY   │ [CORRECT] Set    │ .env        │
│ ollama      │ (none)           │  Local  │ localhost   │
└─────────────┴──────────────────┴───────────┴─────────────┘

 Keys are read at runtime, never stored by SuperQode

═══ ACP MODE (Coding Agents) ═══

Agent authentication is managed by each agent, not SuperQode:

┌───────────┬──────────────────────────┬───────────┐
│ Agent     │ Auth Location            │ Status    │
├───────────┼──────────────────────────┼───────────┤
│ opencode  │ ~/.local/share/opencode/ │ [CORRECT] Config │
│           │   auth.json              │           │
└───────────┴──────────────────────────┴───────────┘

 Agent auth is managed by the agent itself, not SuperQode
 Run the agent directly to configure: e.g., 'opencode' → /connect

═══ DATA FLOW ═══

BYOK:  You → SuperQode → LiteLLM → Provider API
ACP:   You → SuperQode → Agent (e.g., opencode) → Provider API

SuperQode is a pass-through orchestrator. Your data goes directly
to the LLM provider or agent. We don't intercept or store anything.

docs.title: auth check
docs.text:
Check authentication status for a specific provider or agent.

superqode auth check PROVIDER_OR_AGENT

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description PROVIDER_OR_AGENT Provider ID (e.g., anthropic) or Agent ID (e.g., opencode)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Check Anthropic provider
superqode auth check anthropic

# Check OpenCode agent
superqode auth check opencode

# Check OpenAI provider
superqode auth check openai

docs.title: For Providers
docs.text:
Shows: - Provider name and details - Environment variable status - Masked API key (first 8 and last 4 characters) - Source location of env var - Setup instructions if not configured

Example Output (Configured):

Provider: Anthropic

[CORRECT] ANTHROPIC_API_KEY = sk-ant-api03-...
   Source: ~/.zshrc

Example Output (Not Configured):

Provider: Anthropic

[INCORRECT] ANTHROPIC_API_KEY = (not set)

To configure:
  export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="your-api-key"

  Get your key at: https://console.anthropic.com/

docs.title: For Agents
docs.text:
Shows: - Agent name and authentication method - Auth file location and existence - Setup instructions if not configured

Example Output (Configured):

Agent: SST OpenCode

Auth managed by: SST OpenCode (not SuperQode)
Auth location: Managed by OpenCode CLI (run `opencode /connect`)

[CORRECT] Auth file exists: /home/user/.local/share/opencode/auth.json

Example Output (Not Configured):

Agent: SST OpenCode

Auth managed by: SST OpenCode (not SuperQode)
Auth location: Managed by OpenCode CLI (run `opencode /connect`)

WARNING: Auth file not found: /home/user/.local/share/opencode/auth.json

To configure:
  opencode /connect

docs.title: For Local Providers
docs.text:
Shows that no API key is required:

Provider: Ollama

 Local provider - no API key required
Default URL: http://localhost:11434

docs.title: Understanding Auth Sources
docs.text:
SuperQode detects where environment variables are set by checking:

  1. Shell configuration files: ~/.zshrc, ~/.bashrc, ~/.bash_profile, ~/.profile
  2. Project .env file: .env in current directory
  3. Environment: System environment (e.g., exported in current shell)

The auth info command shows the detected source for each configured variable.

docs.title: BYOK Providers
docs.text:
1. Get your API key from the provider:
  2. Anthropic: https://console.anthropic.com/
  3. OpenAI: https://platform.openai.com/api-keys

  4. Google AI: https://aistudio.google.com/app/apikey

  5. Set the environment variable:

# In shell config file (~/.zshrc, ~/.bashrc, etc.)
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="sk-ant-api03-..."

# Or in project .env file
echo 'ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=sk-ant-api03-...' >> .env
  1. Verify:
superqode auth check anthropic

docs.title: ACP Agents
docs.text:
Each agent manages its own authentication:

# OpenCode example
opencode /connect
# Follow prompts to authenticate

# Verify
superqode auth check opencode

docs.title: Local Providers
docs.text:
No authentication required. Just ensure the service is running:

# Ollama example
ollama serve

# Verify
superqode auth check ollama

docs.title: 1. Never Commit API Keys
docs.text:
# Add to .gitignore
echo ".env" >> .gitignore
echo "*_api_key*" >> .gitignore

docs.title: 2. Use Environment Variables
docs.text:
# Good: Set in environment
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="sk-ant-..."

# Bad: Hardcode in config files
# ANTHROPIC_API_KEY: "sk-ant-..."  # [INCORRECT] DON'T DO THIS

docs.title: 3. Use Different Keys for Different Environments
docs.text:
# Development
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="sk-ant-dev-..."

# Production (in CI/CD)
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="${{ secrets.ANTHROPIC_API_KEY }}"

docs.title: 4. Rotate Keys Regularly
docs.text: If a key is compromised: 1. Generate a new key from the provider dashboard 2. Update the environment variable 3. Revoke the old key

docs.title: Key Not Detected
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] ANTHROPIC_API_KEY = (not set)

Solution: 

# 1. Verify key is exported
echo $ANTHROPIC_API_KEY

# 2. If empty, set it
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="your-key"

# 3. For persistence, add to shell config
echo 'export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="your-key"' >> ~/.zshrc
source ~/.zshrc

# 4. Verify again
superqode auth check anthropic

docs.title: Agent Auth Not Found
docs.text:
WARNING: Auth file not found: /home/user/.local/share/opencode/auth.json

Solution: 

# Run the agent's authentication command
opencode /connect

# Or follow agent-specific setup
superqode agents show opencode  # Check setup instructions

docs.title: Multiple Keys Set
docs.text:
If multiple environment variables are set for the same provider, SuperQode uses the first one found in this order: 1. Shell environment 2. .env file 3. Shell config files

To use a specific key, export it explicitly: 

export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="desired-key"

docs.title: BYOK Mode
docs.text:
You (API Key) → SuperQode CLI → LiteLLM Gateway → Provider API
                   ↑
                   No storage, pass-through only
  • SuperQode reads keys from your environment
  • Keys are passed to LiteLLM (local process)
  • LiteLLM makes API calls to providers
  • SuperQode never writes keys to disk

docs.title: ACP Mode
docs.text:
You → SuperQode CLI → Agent Process → Agent's Auth → Provider API
                      ↑
                      Agent manages its own auth
  • SuperQode connects to agent subprocess
  • Agent handles its own authentication
  • Agent makes API calls using its credentials
  • SuperQode doesn't see agent credentials

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text:
• superqode providers list - List available providers
  • superqode providers test - Test provider connection
  • superqode agents show - Show agent authentication info
  • superqode roles check - Check role readiness (includes auth check)

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Provider Commands - Provider management
  • Agents Commands - Agent management
  • Configuration - Config file structure

docs.title: Config Commands
docs.text: Commands for creating and adjusting your superqode.yaml.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
SuperQode looks for configuration in this order:

  1. ./superqode.yaml (project)
  2. ~/.superqode.yaml (user)
  3. /etc/superqode/superqode.yaml (system)

For most teams, use project config: superqe init.

docs.title: init
docs.text:
Create superqode.yaml in the current directory from the comprehensive role catalog template.

superqe init [--force] [--guided]

Examples:

superqe init
superqe init --force

docs.title: config init
docs.text:
Initialize a default config (alternative to superqe init).

superqode config init [--force]

docs.title: config list-modes
docs.text:
List configured modes and roles (as defined in superqode.yaml).

superqode config list-modes

docs.title: config set-model
docs.text:
Set the model for a specific MODE.ROLE.

superqode config set-model MODE.ROLE MODEL

Example:

superqode config set-model qe.security_tester gemini-2.5-flash

Note: ACP agents manage their own models; use this for non-ACP roles.

docs.title: config set-agent
docs.text:
Set the ACP agent for a specific MODE.ROLE.

superqode config set-agent MODE.ROLE AGENT [--provider PROVIDER]

Example:

superqode config set-agent qe.fullstack opencode

docs.title: config enable-role / disable-role
docs.text:
Enable or disable a role in superqode.yaml.

superqode config enable-role MODE.ROLE
superqode config disable-role MODE.ROLE

docs.title: Init Commands
docs.text: Initialize SuperQE configuration in a repository (creates superqode.yaml).

docs.title: init
docs.text:
Create superqode.yaml in the current directory from the comprehensive role catalog template.

superqe init [--force] [--guided]

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
• Creates/overwrites ./superqode.yaml
  • Uses the comprehensive role catalog template (disable or remove roles you don’t need)
  • Creates .superqode/ runtime directory (artifacts, history, temp)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Initialize current directory
superqe init

# Guided, interactive setup
superqe init --guided

# Overwrite existing config
superqe init --force

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
# Inspect configuration
cat superqode.yaml

# List configured modes/roles (SuperQode CLI)
superqode config list-modes

# Run a quick scan
superqe run . --mode quick

# View the latest QR
superqe report

docs.title: Provider Commands
docs.text: Commands for managing BYOK (Bring Your Own Key) providers, testing connections, and listing available models.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The superqode providers command group manages provider connections:

superqode providers COMMAND [OPTIONS] [ARGS]

docs.title: providers list
docs.text:
List available BYOK providers.

superqode providers list [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --category Filter by category: us, china, other-labs, model-hosts, local, free --tier Filter by tier: 1, 2, local --configured Show only configured providers

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# List all providers
superqode providers list

# List only US lab providers
superqode providers list --category us

# List only configured providers
superqode providers list --configured

# List free tier providers
superqode providers list --category free

# List local providers
superqode providers list --category local

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
BYOK Providers
┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃ Provider    ┃ Name          ┃ Tier   ┃ Category    ┃ Status           ┃ Env Var               ┃
┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩
│ anthropic   │ Anthropic     │ Tier 1 │ US Labs     │ [CORRECT] Configured    │ ANTHROPIC_API_KEY     │
│ openai      │ OpenAI        │ Tier 1 │ US Labs     │ [CORRECT] Configured    │ OPENAI_API_KEY        │
│ google      │ Google AI     │ Tier 1 │ US Labs     │ [INCORRECT] Not configured│ GOOGLE_API_KEY        │
│ ollama      │ Ollama        │ Local  │ Local       │  Local         │ (none)                │
└─────────────┴───────────────┴────────┴─────────────┴──────────────────┴───────────────────────┘

Total: 15 providers, 2 configured

docs.text:
Show details for a specific provider.

superqode providers show PROVIDER_ID

docs.title: Arguments

docs.title: providers test
docs.text:
Test connection to a provider.

superqode providers test PROVIDER_ID [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description PROVIDER_ID Provider identifier

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --model, -m Model to test with (uses default if not specified)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Test with default model
superqode providers test anthropic

# Test with specific model
superqode providers test anthropic -m claude-sonnet-4

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Testing Anthropic with model claude-sonnet-4...

[CORRECT] Success!
  Provider: anthropic
  Model: claude-sonnet-4
  Tokens used: 15

docs.title: providers mlx
docs.text:
Manage MLX (Apple Silicon) models and servers.

superqode providers mlx ACTION [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Actions
docs.text: Action Description list List available MLX models (cached and server) server Show command to start MLX server models Show suggested MLX models check Check if mlx_lm is installed setup Complete setup guide for MLX

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# List available MLX models
superqode providers mlx list

# Show server start command
superqode providers mlx server --model mlx-community/Qwen2.5-Coder-3B-4bit

# Show suggested models
superqode providers mlx models

# Check installation
superqode providers mlx check

# Full setup guide
superqode providers mlx setup

docs.title: MLX Server Options
docs.text: Option Description --model, -m Model for server command --host Server host (default: localhost) --port Server port (default: 8080)

docs.title: connect byok
docs.text:
Connect to a BYOK (cloud) provider.

superqode connect byok PROVIDER MODEL

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description PROVIDER Provider ID (e.g., anthropic, openai) MODEL Model ID (e.g., claude-sonnet-4, gpt-4o)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Connect to Anthropic
superqode connect byok anthropic claude-sonnet-4

# Connect to OpenAI
superqode connect byok openai gpt-4o

# Connect to Google AI
superqode connect byok google gemini-2.5-pro

docs.title: connect acp
docs.text:
Connect to an ACP (Agent Client Protocol) agent.

superqode connect acp AGENT

Note: This command launches a simple CLI interactive session. For the full TUI experience, run superqode and use :connect acp <agent> inside the TUI.

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description AGENT Agent ID (e.g., opencode)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Connect to OpenCode (requires ZHIPUAI_API_KEY environment variable)
export ZHIPUAI_API_KEY=your-api-key-here
superqode connect acp opencode

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Agent must be installed (e.g., npm i -g opencode-ai for OpenCode)
  • Required API keys must be set as environment variables
  • Agent must pass health checks

docs.title: connect local
docs.text:
Connect to a local/self-hosted provider.

superqode connect local PROVIDER MODEL

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description PROVIDER Local provider ID (e.g., ollama, lmstudio, mlx) MODEL Model ID

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Connect to Ollama
superqode connect local ollama qwen3:8b

# Connect to LM Studio
superqode connect local lmstudio local-model

# Connect to MLX
superqode connect local mlx mlx-community/Qwen2.5-Coder-3B-4bit

docs.title: US Labs (Tier 1)
docs.text: Provider API Key Variable anthropic ANTHROPIC_API_KEY openai OPENAI_API_KEY google GOOGLE_API_KEY xai XAI_API_KEY mistral MISTRAL_API_KEY

docs.title: China Labs
docs.text: Provider API Key Variable deepseek DEEPSEEK_API_KEY zhipu ZHIPU_API_KEY alibaba ALIBABA_API_KEY

docs.title: Model Hosts
docs.text: Provider API Key Variable openrouter OPENROUTER_API_KEY together TOGETHER_API_KEY groq GROQ_API_KEY fireworks FIREWORKS_API_KEY

docs.title: Local Providers
docs.text: Provider Default Port Notes ollama 11434 Easy local deployment lmstudio 1234 GUI-based local models mlx 8080 Apple Silicon optimized vllm 8000 High-performance inference

docs.title: Cloud Providers
docs.text:
# 1. Set API key
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=sk-ant-...

# 2. Verify configuration
superqode providers test anthropic

# 3. Connect
superqode connect byok anthropic claude-sonnet-4

docs.title: Local Providers (Ollama)
docs.text:
# 1. Start Ollama
ollama serve

# 2. Pull a model
ollama pull qwen3:8b

# 3. Connect
superqode connect local ollama qwen3:8b

docs.title: Local Providers (MLX)
docs.text:
# 1. Install MLX
pip install mlx-lm

# 2. Download model
mlx_lm.download mlx-community/Qwen2.5-Coder-3B-4bit

# 3. Start server (in separate terminal)
mlx_lm.server --model mlx-community/Qwen2.5-Coder-3B-4bit

# 4. Connect
superqode connect local mlx mlx-community/Qwen2.5-Coder-3B-4bit

docs.title: Provider Not Configured
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] Provider 'anthropic' is not configured

Set: ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=your-api-key
Get your API key at: https://docs.anthropic.com/

Solution: Set the required environment variable.

docs.title: Connection Failed
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] Connection failed: Connection refused

Solution for local providers: Ensure the server is running.

# For Ollama
ollama serve

# For MLX
mlx_lm.server --model <model-id>

docs.title: Model Not Found
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] Error: Model 'unknown-model' not found

Solution: Check available models for the provider.

superqode providers show anthropic

docs.title: QE Commands
docs.text: Quality Engineering commands for running QE sessions, viewing reports, and managing artifacts.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The superqe command group provides all quality engineering functionality:

superqe COMMAND [OPTIONS] [ARGS]

docs.title: OSS vs Enterprise
docs.text:
OSS supports: run, roles, quick, deep.

Enterprise commands: status, artifacts, show, clean, report, logs, dashboard, feedback, suppressions.

Enterprise options: --generate, --allow-suggestions, --jsonl, --junit.

docs.title: run
docs.text:
Run a QE session on the specified path.

superqe run [PATH] [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description Default PATH Directory to analyze . (current directory)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --mode, -m QE mode: quick (60s) or deep (30min) --role, -r QE role(s) to run (can specify multiple) --timeout, -t Timeout in seconds --no-revert Don't revert changes (for debugging) --output, -o Output directory for artifacts --json Output results as JSON --jsonl Stream events as JSONL (Enterprise) --junit PATH Export JUnit XML to file (Enterprise) --worktree Use git worktree isolation (writes .git/worktrees) --generate, -g Generate tests for detected issues (Enterprise) --allow-suggestions Enable suggestion mode (Enterprise) --verbose, -v Show detailed progress

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Quick scan current directory
superqe run .

# Quick scan with 60s timeout
superqe run . --mode quick

# Deep analysis with verbose output
superqe run . --mode deep --verbose

# Run specific roles
superqe run . -r security_tester -r api_tester

# Run with suggestions enabled
superqe run . --mode deep --allow-suggestions --generate

# Export for CI
superqe run . --junit results.xml

# Stream JSONL events
superqe run . --jsonl

# Use worktree isolation
superqe run . --worktree

docs.title: quick
docs.text:
Alias for run --mode quick.

superqe quick [PATH]

Fast, time-boxed QE for pre-commit and developer feedback.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: superqe quick .

docs.title: deep
docs.text:
Alias for run --mode deep.

superqe deep [PATH]

Full investigation for pre-release and nightly CI.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: superqe deep .

docs.title: roles
docs.text:
List all available QE roles.

superqe roles

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Shows roles grouped by type:

  • Execution Roles: Run existing tests deterministically
  • Detection Roles: AI-powered issue discovery
  • Heuristic Roles: Senior QE comprehensive review

The list is pulled from your superqode.yaml. The default template includes a comprehensive role catalog, but only roles with implementations can actually run.

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
Available QE Roles

Execution Roles (run existing tests)
  smoke_tester: Fast critical path validation
  sanity_tester: Quick core functionality verification
  regression_tester: Full test suite execution
  lint_tester: Fast static linting across languages

Detection Roles (AI-powered issue detection)
  security_tester: Security vulnerability detection
    Focus: injection, auth, secrets, OWASP
  api_tester: API contract and security testing
    Focus: schema, validation, rate limiting
  unit_tester: Test coverage and unit test gaps
  e2e_tester: End-to-end workflow testing
  performance_tester: Performance bottleneck detection

Heuristic Roles (senior QE review)
  fullstack: Senior QE comprehensive review

docs.title: status
docs.text:
Show current QE workspace status.

superqe status [PATH]

docs.title: Output
docs.text: Shows: - Workspace state (idle, active, etc.) - Current session ID - Session start time - Artifact counts - Recent session history

docs.title: artifacts
docs.text:
List QE artifacts from previous sessions.

superqe artifacts [PATH] [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --type, -t Filter by type (patch, test_unit, qr, etc.)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# List all artifacts
superqe artifacts

# List only patches
superqe artifacts --type patch

docs.title: show
docs.text:
Show content of a specific artifact.

superqe show ARTIFACT_ID [PATH]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description ARTIFACT_ID The artifact ID to display

docs.title: Example
docs.text: superqe show patch-001

docs.title: report
docs.text:
View or export the latest QR.

superqe report [PATH] [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --format, -f Output format: md, json, html --output, -o Output file path

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# View latest QR in terminal
superqe report

# Export as JSON
superqe report --format json --output report.json

docs.title: logs
docs.text:
Show detailed agent work logs for QE sessions.

superqe logs [SESSION_ID] [PATH]

Shows the actual agent interaction logs, including: - Connection attempts and responses - Prompts sent to the AI agent - Analysis steps and reasoning - Tool calls and their results - Final findings extraction

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description SESSION_ID Optional session ID (defaults to latest)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Show logs for latest session
superqe logs

# Show logs for specific session
superqe logs qe-20240118-143022

docs.title: dashboard
docs.text:
Open QR dashboard in web browser.

superqe dashboard [PATH] [OPTIONS]

Provides an interactive web interface for viewing Quality Reports.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --port, -p Port for web server (default: 8765) --no-open Don't open browser automatically --export, -e Export as standalone HTML file

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Open latest QR in browser
superqe dashboard

# Use custom port
superqe dashboard --port 9000

# Export as HTML file
superqe dashboard --export report.html

docs.title: clean
docs.text:
Clean up QE artifacts.

superqe clean [PATH] [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --keep-qrs Keep QR files (default: true) --all Remove all including QRs

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Clean artifacts but keep QRs
superqe clean

# Remove everything
superqe clean --all

docs.title: feedback
docs.text:
Provide feedback on a finding to improve future QE runs.

superqe feedback FINDING_ID [OPTIONS] [PATH]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description FINDING_ID The finding ID to provide feedback on

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --valid Mark finding as valid (true positive) --false-positive, -fp Mark as false positive (suppress in future) --fixed Mark finding as fixed --wont-fix Mark finding as won't fix --reason, -r Reason for the feedback --scope, -s Scope for suppression: project or team --expires, -e Suppression expires in N days

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Mark as valid
superqe feedback sec-001 --valid

# Mark as false positive
superqe feedback sec-002 --false-positive -r "Intentional for testing"

# Mark as false positive with team scope
superqe feedback sec-003 --false-positive --scope team -r "Known limitation"

# Mark as fixed
superqe feedback perf-001 --fixed -r "Optimized query"

docs.title: suppressions
docs.text:
List or manage finding suppressions.

superqe suppressions [PATH] [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --remove, -r Remove suppression by ID

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# List active suppressions
superqe suppressions

# Remove a suppression
superqe suppressions -r abc123

docs.title: Pre-Commit Check
docs.text: superqe run . --mode quick -r security_tester

docs.title: Pre-Release Validation
docs.text: superqe run . --mode deep --allow-suggestions --generate

docs.title: CI/CD Integration
docs.text:
# JSONL output for streaming
superqe run . --jsonl

# JUnit XML for test reporting
superqe run . --junit results.xml

docs.title: Review Findings
docs.text:
# View report
superqe report

# View agent work logs
superqe logs

# Open dashboard
superqe dashboard

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Config Commands - Configuration management
  • Provider Commands - Provider management
  • CI/CD Integration - Automated quality gates

docs.title: Roles Commands
docs.text: Manage team roles and their execution configuration in SuperQode.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The superqode roles command group provides commands for viewing and inspecting team roles, their execution modes (BYOK or ACP), and configuration details.

docs.title: roles list
docs.text:
List all configured roles with their execution mode and status.

superqode roles list [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --mode, -m Filter by mode (e.g., dev, qe, devops) --enabled-only Show only enabled roles

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# List all roles
superqode roles list

# List only dev mode roles
superqode roles list --mode dev

# List only enabled roles
superqode roles list --enabled-only

# Filter to enabled qe roles
superqode roles list --mode qe --enabled-only

docs.title: Output
docs.text: Shows a table with: - Role: Role identifier (format: mode.role) - Mode: Execution mode name - Exec Mode: BYOK (direct LLM) or ACP (coding agent) - Provider/Agent: Provider ID (BYOK) or Agent ID (ACP) - Model: Model name (BYOK) or "(agent-managed)" (ACP) - Status: [CORRECT] Enabled or [INCORRECT] Disabled

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
Team Roles
┌───────────────┬──────┬──────────┬───────────┬───────────────┬──────────────┐
│ Role          │ Mode │ Exec Mode│ Provider  │ Model         │ Status       │
├───────────────┼──────┼──────────┼───────────┼───────────────┼──────────────┤
│ dev.fullstack │ dev  │ BYOK     │ anthropic │ claude-sonnet │ [CORRECT] Enabled   │
│ qe.api_tester │ qe   │ ACP      │ opencode  │ (agent-managed)│ [CORRECT] Enabled   │
└───────────────┴──────┴──────────┴───────────┴───────────────┴──────────────┘

Execution Modes:
  BYOK = Bring Your Own Key (direct LLM API via gateway)
  ACP  = Agent Client Protocol (full coding agent)

docs.title: roles info
docs.text:
Show detailed execution information for a specific role.

superqode roles info MODE.ROLE

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description MODE.ROLE Role path in format mode.role (e.g., dev.fullstack, qe.api_tester)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Show dev.fullstack role details
superqode roles info dev.fullstack

# Show qe.api_tester role details
superqode roles info qe.api_tester

# Show qe mode role (if using direct role config)
superqode roles info qe

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Displays comprehensive role information including:

BYOK Mode Roles: - Role name and description - Provider and model configuration - Provider status and API key configuration - Capabilities (chat completion, streaming, tool calling) - Limitations (no file editing, no shell commands, no MCP)

ACP Mode Roles: - Agent identifier and status - Protocol type - Authentication method - Agent LLM configuration (provider/model) - Capabilities (file editing, shell commands, MCP tools, etc.) - Setup instructions (if not supported)

Common Information: - MCP servers (if configured) - Job description (truncated if long) - Security information

docs.title: Example Output (BYOK)
docs.text:
Role: dev.fullstack
Description: Full-stack development assistant
Enabled: Yes

═══ BYOK MODE (Direct LLM) ═══

Provider: anthropic
Model: claude-sonnet-4-20250514
Gateway: LiteLLM

Provider Status: [CORRECT] Configured
Required Env: ANTHROPIC_API_KEY

Capabilities:
  • Chat completion
  • Streaming responses
  • Tool calling (if model supports)

Limitations:
  • No file editing
  • No shell commands
  • No MCP tools

Job Description:
  You are a full-stack development assistant...

═══ SECURITY ═══

🔒 API key read from YOUR environment variables
🔒 SuperQode NEVER stores your keys
🔒 Data flows: You → SuperQode → LiteLLM → Provider

docs.title: Example Output (ACP)
docs.text:
Role: qe.api_tester
Description: API testing specialist
Enabled: Yes

═══ ACP MODE (Coding Agent) ═══

Agent: opencode
Agent Status: [CORRECT] Supported
Protocol: ACP
Auth: Managed by OpenCode CLI (run `opencode /connect`)

Agent LLM Config:
  Provider: anthropic
  Model: claude-sonnet-4-20250514

Capabilities:
  • File editing
  • Shell command execution
  • MCP tool integration
  • Git operations

MCP Servers:
  • filesystem
  • github

Job Description:
  You are an API testing specialist...

═══ SECURITY ═══

🔒 Auth managed by the agent (not SuperQode)
🔒 Agent stores its own credentials
🔒 Data flows: You → SuperQode → Agent → Provider

docs.title: roles check
docs.text:
Check if a role is ready to run (auth configured, dependencies available).

superqode roles check MODE.ROLE

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description MODE.ROLE Role path in format mode.role

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Check if dev.fullstack is ready
superqode roles check dev.fullstack

# Check if qe.api_tester is ready
superqode roles check qe.api_tester

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Reports issues and warnings:

  • Issues: Must be fixed before role can run
  • Missing API keys
  • Missing provider/model configuration

  • Unsupported agents

  • Warnings: May cause problems but won't prevent execution

  • Provider/agent not in registry (may still work)
  • Configuration inconsistencies

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
Checking role: dev.fullstack

[INCORRECT] Issues found:
  • API key not set. Set ANTHROPIC_API_KEY

To configure: export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="your-key"
Get key at: https://console.anthropic.com/

docs.title: Success Output
docs.text:
Checking role: dev.fullstack

[CORRECT] Role is ready to run!

docs.title: BYOK Mode (Bring Your Own Key)
docs.text:
Capabilities: - Direct LLM API access via LiteLLM - Chat completion and streaming - Tool calling (if model supports)

Limitations: - No file editing - No shell command execution - No MCP tool integration

Requirements: - Provider must be configured in providers section - API key must be set in environment variable - Model must be specified

docs.title: ACP Mode (Agent Client Protocol)
docs.text:
Capabilities: - Full file editing and creation - Shell command execution - MCP tool integration - Git operations - Advanced coding workflows

Requirements: - Agent must be installed on system - Agent must be in agent registry - Agent authentication must be configured

docs.title: List All Roles
docs.text:
# See all configured roles
superqode roles list

# See only enabled roles
superqode roles list --enabled-only

docs.title: Inspect Role Configuration
docs.text:
# Get detailed info about a role
superqode roles info dev.fullstack

docs.title: Verify Role Readiness
docs.text:
# Check if role is ready before use
superqode roles check qe.api_tester

# Fix any issues shown
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="your-key"

docs.title: Troubleshoot Role Issues
docs.text:
# 1. List roles to see current state
superqode roles list

# 2. Get detailed info
superqode roles info dev.fullstack

# 3. Check for issues
superqode roles check dev.fullstack

# 4. Fix issues (e.g., set API key)
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="sk-ant-..."

# 5. Verify again
superqode roles check dev.fullstack

docs.title: Role Not Found
docs.text:
Error: Role 'dev.unknown' not found or disabled

Solution: - Use superqode roles list to see available roles - Check role name spelling (format: mode.role) - Verify role is enabled in configuration

docs.title: Provider Not Configured
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] Issues found:
  • API key not set. Set ANTHROPIC_API_KEY

Solution: 

# Set the API key
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="your-key"

# Verify
superqode roles check dev.fullstack

docs.title: Agent Not Supported
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] Issues found:
  • Agent 'experimental-agent' is not yet supported

Solution: - Check superqode agents list --supported for supported agents - Update role configuration to use a supported agent - Or wait for agent to be marked as supported

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text:
• superqode agents list - List available ACP agents
  • superqode agents show - Show agent details
  • superqode config list-modes - View configured modes and roles
  • superqode providers list - List BYOK providers

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Config Commands - Configuration management
  • Agents Commands - ACP agent management
  • Provider Commands - BYOK provider management
  • Team Configuration - Role configuration guide

docs.title: Serve Commands
docs.text: Start various SuperQode servers for IDE and web integration.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The superqode serve command group provides commands for running SuperQode servers:

  • LSP Server: Language Server Protocol server for IDE integration
  • Web Server: Browser-based TUI interface
  • Status: Check running server status

Note: superqode serve is an enterprise feature.

docs.title: serve lsp
docs.text:
Start the Language Server Protocol (LSP) server for IDE integration.

superqode serve lsp [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description Default --transport, -t Transport mode: stdio or tcp stdio --port, -p Port for TCP transport 9000 --project Project root directory . (current directory) --verbose, -v Enable verbose logging false

docs.title: stdio Mode (Default)
docs.text:
For editor integration. The server communicates via stdin/stdout.

# Start LSP in stdio mode (for editors)
superqode serve lsp

Use case: When launched by your editor/IDE (VSCode, Neovim, etc.)

docs.title: TCP Mode
docs.text:
For debugging and manual connection. The server listens on a TCP port.

# Start LSP on TCP port 9000
superqode serve lsp --transport tcp --port 9000

Use case: Debugging, testing, or manual editor configuration

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Start in stdio mode (default, for editors)
superqode serve lsp

# Start in TCP mode for debugging
superqode serve lsp -t tcp -p 9000

# Start with verbose logging
superqode serve lsp --verbose

# Start for specific project
superqode serve lsp --project ./myproject

docs.title: VSCode Setup
docs.text:
1. Install the SuperQode VSCode extension
  2. The extension automatically connects to the LSP server
  3. QE findings appear as diagnostics in the Problems panel

Configuration: The extension launches superqode serve lsp automatically.

docs.title: Neovim Setup
docs.text:
Using nvim-lspconfig:

require('lspconfig.configs').superqode = {
    default_config = {
        cmd = { 'superqode', 'serve', 'lsp' },
        filetypes = { '*' },
        root_dir = function(fname)
            return vim.fn.getcwd()
        end,
    },
}
require('lspconfig').superqode.setup{}

docs.title: Other LSP Clients
docs.text:
Any LSP-compatible editor can connect:

# stdio mode (launched by editor)
superqode serve lsp

# TCP mode (manual connection)
superqode serve lsp -t tcp -p 9000

Then configure your LSP client to connect to localhost:9000.

docs.title: serve web
docs.text:
Start the web server for browser-based TUI.

superqode serve web [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description Default --port, -p Port for web server 8080 --host, -h Host to bind to 127.0.0.1 --project Project root directory . --no-open Don't open browser automatically false

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Start on default port (8080)
superqode serve web

# Use custom port
superqode serve web -p 3000

# Allow external connections
superqode serve web -h 0.0.0.0

# Start without opening browser
superqode serve web --no-open

# Start for specific project
superqode serve web --project ./myproject

docs.title: Access
docs.text:
Once started, open your browser to:

http://localhost:8080

(or the port you specified)

The web interface provides the same TUI experience as the terminal version.

docs.title: serve status
docs.text:
Show status of running servers.

superqode serve status [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description Default --project Project directory .

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Check server status
superqode serve status

docs.title: Output
docs.text: Shows status for: - LSP Server: Running status (TCP mode only; stdio mode doesn't show) - Web Server: Running status on port 8080

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
SuperQode Server Status

LSP Server: Not running (stdio mode doesn't show here)
Web Server: Running on port 8080

Note: LSP servers in stdio mode don't appear in status because they're process-to-process connections, not network services.

docs.title: IDE Integration (LSP)
docs.text:
# Start LSP server for editor
superqode serve lsp

# Or let your editor start it automatically
# (VSCode extension does this)

docs.title: Web Interface
docs.text:
# Start web server
superqode serve web

# Browser opens automatically at http://localhost:8080

docs.title: Debugging LSP
docs.text:
# Start in TCP mode for debugging
superqode serve lsp -t tcp -p 9000 --verbose

# Connect with LSP client or test manually

docs.title: Check Running Servers
docs.text:
# See what's running
superqode serve status

docs.title: LSP Server Features
docs.text:
• Diagnostics: QE findings appear as editor diagnostics
  • Code Actions: Quick fixes and suggestions
  • Documentation: Hover information for findings
  • Workspace: Full project context awareness

docs.title: Web Server Features
docs.text:
• Full TUI: Complete SuperQode TUI in browser
  • Interactive: All TUI commands and features
  • Accessible: Use from any device on network
  • No Installation: Just a browser needed

docs.title: Port Already in Use
docs.text:
Error: Address already in use

Solution: 

# Use a different port
superqode serve web -p 3000
superqode serve lsp -t tcp -p 9001

docs.title: LSP Not Connecting
docs.text:
For stdio mode: Ensure your editor is launching the command correctly.

For TCP mode: 

# Verify server is running
superqode serve status

# Check port accessibility
curl http://localhost:9000/health

docs.title: Web Server Not Accessible
docs.text:
Local only (default): 

# Default (localhost only)
superqode serve web

# Allow external access
superqode serve web -h 0.0.0.0

Firewall: Ensure port 8080 (or your port) is open.

docs.title: LSP Diagnostics Not Showing
docs.text: Check: 1. LSP server is running (superqode serve status) 2. Editor LSP client is configured correctly 3. Project has QE findings (run superqe run . first)

docs.title: LSP Server
docs.text:
• stdio mode: Process-to-process, no network exposure
  • TCP mode: Only bind to 127.0.0.1 by default (localhost only)

docs.title: Web Server
docs.text:
• Default: Binds to 127.0.0.1 (localhost only)
  • External access: Use --host 0.0.0.0 only in trusted networks
  • Authentication: Not included (add reverse proxy for production)

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Development: Use default localhost binding
  2. Team Access: Use reverse proxy with authentication
  3. CI/CD: Don't expose servers externally

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text:
• superqe run - Generate QE findings for LSP diagnostics
  • superqe dashboard - Alternative web interface for QRs

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• IDE Integration - Detailed IDE setup guides
  • QE Commands - Quality engineering workflows

docs.title: Suggestion Commands
docs.text:
Commands for reviewing and applying verified fix suggestions from QE sessions.

Note: Suggestion commands are available in SuperQode Enterprise only.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The superqode suggestions command group manages fix suggestions:

superqode suggestions COMMAND [OPTIONS] [ARGS]

Suggestions are generated when running QE with --allow-suggestions enabled.

docs.title: suggestions list
docs.text:
List all verified fix suggestions from QE sessions.

superqode suggestions list [PROJECT_ROOT] [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description PROJECT_ROOT Project directory (default: .)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --all, -a Show all suggestions, not just improvements

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# List verified improvements
superqode suggestions list

# List all suggestions
superqode suggestions list --all

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Verified Fix Suggestions
┏━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃ #  ┃ Finding                             ┃ Status       ┃ Confidence   ┃
┡━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩
│ 1  │ SQL Injection Fix                   │ [CORRECT] Verified ⬆️│ 95%          │
│ 2  │ Auth Bypass Fix                     │ [CORRECT] Verified ⬆️│ 92%          │
│ 3  │ Rate Limiting Added                 │ [CORRECT] Verified ⬆️│ 88%          │
└────┴─────────────────────────────────────┴──────────────┴──────────────┘

Total: 3 verified fix suggestions
Use 'superqe logs' to see detailed agent work logs

docs.title: suggestions show
docs.text:
Show details of a specific suggestion.

superqode suggestions show FINDING_ID [PROJECT_ROOT]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description FINDING_ID The finding ID to display PROJECT_ROOT Project directory (default: .)

docs.title: Example
docs.text: superqode suggestions show finding-001

docs.title: Output
docs.text: Shows: - Original issue description - Fix details - Verification results - Patch preview - Before/after proof

docs.title: suggestions apply
docs.text:
Apply a verified fix suggestion.

superqode suggestions apply FINDING_ID [PROJECT_ROOT]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description FINDING_ID The finding ID to apply PROJECT_ROOT Project directory (default: .)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Apply a suggestion
superqode suggestions apply finding-001

docs.title: What Happens
docs.text:
1. The patch file is located in .superqode/qe-artifacts/patches/
  2. The patch is applied to your codebase
  3. You should run tests to verify the fix works in your environment

docs.title: Manual Application
docs.text:
You can also apply patches manually:

# Preview the patch
cat .superqode/qe-artifacts/patches/fix-sql-injection.patch

# Dry-run apply
git apply --check .superqode/qe-artifacts/patches/fix-sql-injection.patch

# Apply the patch
git apply .superqode/qe-artifacts/patches/fix-sql-injection.patch

docs.title: suggestions reject
docs.text:
Reject a suggestion with a reason.

superqode suggestions reject FINDING_ID [OPTIONS] [PROJECT_ROOT]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description FINDING_ID The finding ID to reject PROJECT_ROOT Project directory (default: .)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --reason, -r Reason for rejection

docs.title: Example
docs.text: superqode suggestions reject finding-003 -r "Intentional design choice"

docs.title: Complete Workflow
docs.text:
# 1. Run QE with suggestions enabled
superqe run . --mode deep --allow-suggestions

# 2. List available suggestions
superqode suggestions list

# 3. Review a suggestion
superqode suggestions show finding-001

# 4. Preview the patch
cat .superqode/qe-artifacts/patches/fix-sql-injection.patch

# 5. Apply the suggestion
superqode suggestions apply finding-001

# 6. Run tests to verify
pytest

# 7. Commit if satisfied
git add -A
git commit -m "Fix SQL injection vulnerability"

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Always review patches before applying
  2. Run tests after applying suggestions
  3. Use version control to track changes
  4. Provide feedback to improve future suggestions

docs.title: Location
docs.text:
Patches are saved to:

.superqode/qe-artifacts/
├── patches/
│   ├── fix-sql-injection.patch
│   ├── fix-auth-bypass.patch
│   └── fix-rate-limiting.patch
└── reports/
    └── qr-*.json

docs.title: Format
docs.text:
Patches use unified diff format:

--- a/src/api/users.py
+++ b/src/api/users.py
@@ -40,7 +40,9 @@ def search_users(query: str):
     """Search for users by name."""
     conn = get_db_connection()
     cursor = conn.cursor()
-    sql = f"SELECT * FROM users WHERE name LIKE '%{query}%'"
+    sql = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE name LIKE ?"
+    params = (f"%{query}%",)
-    cursor.execute(sql)
+    cursor.execute(sql, params)
     return cursor.fetchall()

docs.title: Verification Status
docs.text: Status Meaning [CORRECT] Verified Fix passed all verification checks [INCORRECT] Failed Fix failed verification ⬆️ Improvement Fix is proven to improve the code ➖ Neutral Fix works but improvement not measured

docs.title: Providing Feedback
docs.text:
After reviewing suggestions, provide feedback to improve future QE runs:

# If the suggestion was helpful
superqe feedback finding-001 --valid

# If the suggestion was wrong
superqe feedback finding-001 --false-positive -r "This is expected behavior"

# If you applied the fix
superqe feedback finding-001 --fixed -r "Applied suggested patch"

docs.title: No Suggestions Found
docs.text:
No verified fixes found.
Run 'superqe run . --mode deep --allow-suggestions' to generate fix suggestions.

Solution: Run QE with --allow-suggestions flag.

docs.title: Patch Doesn't Apply
docs.text:
error: patch failed: src/api/users.py:42

Solution: The code may have changed since the QE session. Try:

  1. Check if the file was modified
  2. Apply the patch manually with context
  3. Run a new QE session

docs.title: Applied Wrong Suggestion
docs.text:
Solution: Use git to revert:

git checkout -- src/api/users.py

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Allow Suggestions - Understand the suggestion workflow
  • QR Documentation - Quality Reports
  • QE Commands - Full QE command reference

docs.title: SuperQE Advanced Commands
docs.text: Advanced Quality Engineering with CodeOptiX integration - AI-powered evaluation capabilities.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The superqe advanced command group provides advanced quality engineering features powered by CodeOptiX:

superqe advanced COMMAND [OPTIONS] [ARGS]

Requirements: Any supported LLM provider (Ollama, OpenAI, Anthropic, Google) with proper authentication.

docs.title: run
docs.text:
Run SuperQE enhanced evaluation with CodeOptiX.

superqe advanced run [PATH] [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description Default PATH Directory to analyze . (current directory)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --behaviors Comma-separated behaviors: security-vulnerabilities,test-quality,plan-adherence --use-bloom Use Bloom scenario generation for intelligent testing --agent Specific agent to evaluate (claude-code, codex, gemini-cli) --output, -o Output directory for enhanced results --json Output enhanced results as JSON --verbose, -v Show detailed SuperQE analysis logs

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: SuperQE requires an LLM provider to be configured. You can use any supported provider:

docs.title: Option 1: Ollama (Local, Free)
docs.text:
# Install Ollama
curl -fsSL https://ollama.ai/install.sh | sh

# Start Ollama
ollama serve

# Pull a model (in another terminal)
ollama pull llama3.1

docs.title: Option 2: OpenAI (Cloud)
docs.text:
# Set API key
export OPENAI_API_KEY="your-api-key-here"

docs.title: Option 3: Anthropic (Cloud)
docs.text:
# Set API key
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="your-api-key-here"

docs.title: Option 4: Google (Cloud)
docs.text:
# Set API key
export GOOGLE_API_KEY="your-api-key-here"

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Basic SuperQE evaluation
superqe advanced run .

# Security-focused evaluation
superqe advanced run . --behaviors security-vulnerabilities

# Multiple behaviors with Bloom scenarios
superqe advanced run . --behaviors security-vulnerabilities,test-quality --use-bloom

# Focus on specific agent
superqe advanced run . --agent claude-code --behaviors all

# Export results
superqe advanced run . --output ./superqe-results --json

docs.title: What SuperQE Provides
docs.text:
SuperQE enhances basic QE with:

  • 🔬 Deep Behavioral Evaluation: Beyond basic checks, analyzes code patterns and security vulnerabilities
  • 🧬 GEPA Evolution Engine: Agent optimization for better testing strategies
  • 🌸 Bloom Scenario Generation: Intelligent test case creation based on code analysis
  • 🛡️ Advanced Security Analysis: Comprehensive vulnerability detection

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
SuperQE generates enhanced results including:

  • Detailed behavioral analysis
  • Security vulnerability reports
  • Test quality assessments
  • Plan adherence verification
  • Scenario-based testing results

docs.title: behaviors
docs.text:
List all available SuperQE enhanced behaviors.

superqe advanced behaviors

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Shows CodeOptiX-powered behaviors:

Enhanced Behaviors (CodeOptiX-powered):
  🔬 security-vulnerabilities: Detects hardcoded secrets, SQL injection, XSS vulnerabilities
  🔬 test-quality: Evaluates test completeness, assertion quality, and coverage
  🔬 plan-adherence: Checks if implementation matches requirements and plans

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Requires CodeOptiX to be available (automatically installed with SuperQode).

docs.title: agent-eval
docs.text:
Compare multiple AI agents using SuperQE evaluation.

superqe advanced agent-eval [PATH] [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description Default PATH Directory to analyze . (current directory)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --agents Comma-separated list: claude-code,codex,gemini-cli (required) --behaviors Behaviors to evaluate (default: security-vulnerabilities,test-quality) --output, -o Output directory for comparison results

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Compare Claude Code and Codex
superqe advanced agent-eval . --agents claude-code,codex

# Compare all agents with comprehensive evaluation
superqe advanced agent-eval . --agents claude-code,codex,gemini-cli --behaviors all

# Save comparison results
superqe advanced agent-eval . --agents claude-code,gemini-cli --output ./comparisons

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Generates agent comparison reports showing:

  • Performance metrics across behaviors
  • Strengths and weaknesses of each agent
  • Recommendations for agent selection
  • Detailed analysis of evaluation results

docs.title: scenarios
docs.text:
Manage Bloom scenario generation for SuperQE.

superqe advanced scenarios ACTION [PATH] [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Actions
docs.text: Action Description generate Generate scenarios for a behavior list List available scenarios

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --behavior Behavior to generate scenarios for --count Number of scenarios to generate (default: 5) --output, -o Output file for scenarios

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Generate security scenarios
superqe advanced scenarios generate . --behavior security-vulnerabilities --count 10

# Generate test quality scenarios
superqe advanced scenarios generate . --behavior test-quality --output scenarios.json

# List available scenarios
superqe advanced scenarios list

docs.title: What are Bloom Scenarios?
docs.text:
Bloom scenarios are intelligently generated test cases that:

  • Analyze code patterns and potential vulnerabilities
  • Create targeted test scenarios based on code structure
  • Provide comprehensive coverage beyond basic testing
  • Adapt to code changes and new patterns

docs.title: LLM Provider Configuration
docs.text: SuperQE requires an LLM provider to be configured. Choose any supported provider:

docs.title: Ollama (Recommended for Local Usage)
docs.text:
# Install Ollama
curl -fsSL https://ollama.ai/install.sh | sh

# Start Ollama (background)
ollama serve &

# Pull required models
ollama pull llama3.1
ollama pull llama3.2:3b  # Optional: lighter model

docs.title: Cloud Providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, Google)
docs.text:
SuperQE works with all major cloud LLM providers. Configure your API keys:

# OpenAI
export OPENAI_API_KEY="your-openai-key"

# Anthropic
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="your-anthropic-key"

# Google
export GOOGLE_API_KEY="your-google-key"

docs.title: CodeOptiX Integration
docs.text:
CodeOptiX is automatically included with SuperQode:

# CodeOptiX is installed as part of SuperQode
pip install superqode  # Includes CodeOptiX integration

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
# Check if SuperQE is ready
superqe advanced behaviors

# Test basic functionality
superqe advanced run . --behaviors security-vulnerabilities

docs.title: SuperQE vs Basic QE
