docs.title: IDE Integration
docs.text:
Integrate SuperQode into your IDE for real-time quality feedback, inline diagnostics, and quick fixes directly in your editor.

Note: IDE integrations are an enterprise feature.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
SuperQode provides IDE integration through:

  • LSP Server: Language Server Protocol for editor-agnostic integration
  • VSCode Extension: Native VSCode extension with diagnostics and commands
  • Diagnostics: QE findings shown as inline errors/warnings
  • Quick Fixes: Apply QE-suggested fixes directly from the editor
  • Commands: Run QE sessions from within your IDE

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Install the SuperQode extension from the VSCode Marketplace:

  1. Open VSCode
  2. Go to Extensions (Ctrl+Shift+X / Cmd+Shift+X)
  3. Search for "SuperQode"
  4. Click Install

Or install from command line:

code --install-extension superqode.superqode

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
The VSCode extension provides:

  • Real-time Diagnostics: QE findings shown as problems in Problems panel
  • Inline Warnings: Findings highlighted directly in code
  • Quick Fixes: Apply patches from QE sessions
  • Status Bar: QE status indicator
  • Commands: Run QE sessions from Command Palette

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Add to your VSCode settings.json:

{
  "superqode.enable": true,
  "superqode.showStatusBar": true,
  "superqode.serverPath": "superqode",
  "superqode.autoRunOnSave": false,
  "superqode.diagnosticSeverity": {
    "critical": "error",
    "high": "error",
    "medium": "warning",
    "low": "info",
    "info": "hint"
  }
}

Settings:

Setting Description Default superqode.enable Enable SuperQode true superqode.showStatusBar Show status bar item true superqode.serverPath Path to superqode CLI "superqode" superqode.autoRunOnSave Run QE on file save false superqode.diagnosticSeverity Map QE severity to diagnostic level (see above)

docs.title: Run QE Session
docs.text:
1. Open Command Palette (Ctrl+Shift+P / Cmd+Shift+P)
  2. Type "SuperQode: Run QE"
  3. Select mode (Quick Scan or Deep QE)

Or use the status bar: - Click the SuperQode status bar item - Select "Run Quick Scan" or "Run Deep QE"

docs.title: View Findings
docs.text:
Findings appear in:

  • Problems Panel: All findings listed
  • Editor: Inline warnings/errors
  • Hover: Details on hover over underlined code

docs.title: Apply Quick Fixes
docs.text:
1. Hover over a finding in the editor
  2. Click "Quick Fix" or press Ctrl+. (Cmd+. on Mac)
  3. Select "Apply QE Fix" from suggestions

docs.title: LSP Server
docs.text: The LSP server provides editor-agnostic integration for any LSP-compatible editor.

docs.title: Starting the Server
docs.text:
# Stdio mode (for editors)
superqode serve lsp

# TCP mode (for debugging)
superqode serve lsp --transport tcp --port 9000

docs.title: Supported Editors
docs.text:
• VSCode: Via extension (automatic)
  • Neovim: Via nvim-lspconfig
  • Vim: Via vim-lsp or coc.nvim
  • Emacs: Via lsp-mode
  • Sublime Text: Via LSP package
  • Atom: Via atom-languageclient

docs.title: Using nvim-lspconfig
docs.text:
-- Add to your Neovim config (init.lua or init.vim)

-- Register SuperQode LSP server
require('lspconfig.configs').superqode = {
  default_config = {
    cmd = { 'superqode', 'serve', 'lsp' },
    filetypes = { '*' },  -- All file types
    root_dir = function(fname)
      return vim.fn.getcwd()
    end,
    settings = {},
  },
}

-- Setup the server
require('lspconfig').superqode.setup({
  on_attach = function(client, bufnr)
    -- Key mappings
    vim.api.nvim_buf_set_keymap(bufnr, 'n', 'gD', '<cmd>lua vim.lsp.buf.declaration()<CR>', opts)
    vim.api.nvim_buf_set_keymap(bufnr, 'n', 'gd', '<cmd>lua vim.lsp.buf.definition()<CR>', opts)
    vim.api.nvim_buf_set_keymap(bufnr, 'n', 'K', '<cmd>lua vim.lsp.buf.hover()<CR>', opts)
  end,
})

docs.title: Using lazy.nvim
docs.text:
-- In your plugins configuration

{
  "neovim/nvim-lspconfig",
  config = function()
    local lspconfig = require("lspconfig")

    lspconfig.superqode.setup({
      cmd = { "superqode", "serve", "lsp" },
      filetypes = { "*" },
      root_dir = lspconfig.util.root_pattern("superqode.yaml", ".git"),
    })
  end,
}

docs.title: Using lsp-mode
docs.text:
;; Add to your Emacs config

(use-package lsp-mode
  :init
  (setq lsp-superqode-server-command '("superqode" "serve" "lsp"))

  :config
  (lsp-register-client
   (make-lsp-client :new-connection (lsp-stdio-connection "superqode serve lsp")
                    :major-modes '(prog-mode)
                    :server-id 'superqode)))

docs.title: Diagnostics
docs.text:
QE findings are exposed as LSP diagnostics:

{
  "range": {
    "start": {"line": 41, "character": 10},
    "end": {"line": 41, "character": 45}
  },
  "severity": 2,
  "message": "SQL Injection Vulnerability: Unsanitized user input in SQL query",
  "source": "SuperQode",
  "code": "F001"
}

Severity Mapping:

QE Severity LSP Severity Description critical 1 (Error) Red underline high 1 (Error) Red underline medium 2 (Warning) Yellow underline low 3 (Information) Blue underline info 4 (Hint) Gray underline

docs.title: Code Actions
docs.text:
Apply QE fixes via code actions:

{
  "title": "Apply QE Fix: Sanitize SQL query",
  "kind": "quickfix",
  "edit": {
    "changes": {
      "file:///path/to/file.py": [{
        "range": {"start": {"line": 41}, "end": {"line": 42}},
        "newText": "sql = \"SELECT * FROM users WHERE name LIKE ?\"\nparams = (f\"%{query}%\",)"
      }]
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Hover Information
docs.text:
Hover over findings for details:

{
  "contents": {
    "kind": "markdown",
    "value": "## SQL Injection Vulnerability

**Severity:** High

**Location:** src/api/users.py:42

**Description:** User input is directly interpolated into SQL query without sanitization.

**Suggested Fix:** Use parameterized queries with placeholders."
  }
}

docs.title: LSP Server Options
docs.text:
superqode serve lsp --help

Options:
  --transport, -t  Transport mode: stdio or tcp
  --port, -p       Port for TCP transport (default: 9000)
  --project        Project root directory (default: current directory)
  --verbose, -v    Enable verbose logging

docs.title: Project Configuration
docs.text:
The LSP server reads your superqode.yaml configuration:

# superqode.yaml
superqode:
  version: "2.0"

# LSP-specific settings
lsp:
  auto_refresh: true        # Refresh diagnostics on file changes
  refresh_delay: 500        # Delay in ms before refreshing
  max_diagnostics: 100      # Maximum diagnostics per file

docs.title: LSP Server Not Starting
docs.text:
Problem: Extension can't connect to LSP server

Solution: 1. Verify superqode is in PATH: 

which superqode

  1. Test LSP server manually: 

    superqode serve lsp --transport tcp --port 9000

  2. Check VSCode output:

  3. Open Output panel (View → Output)
  4. Select "SuperQode" from dropdown
  5. Look for error messages

docs.title: Diagnostics Not Showing
docs.text:
Problem: QE findings not appearing as diagnostics

Solution: 1. Run a QE session first: 

superqe run . --mode quick

  1. Check if QR was generated: 

    ls -la .superqode/qe-artifacts/

  2. Restart LSP server:

  3. VSCode: Reload window (Ctrl+Shift+P → "Reload Window")
  4. Neovim: Restart LSP client

docs.title: Slow Performance
docs.text:
Problem: LSP server is slow or unresponsive

Solution: 1. Reduce max_diagnostics in config 2. Use --mode quick for faster QE 3. Exclude large directories: 

qe:
  workspace:
    exclude:
      - node_modules
      - .venv
      - build

docs.title: VSCode Commands
docs.text:
Available in Command Palette:

  • SuperQode: Run Quick Scan: Run quick QE analysis
  • SuperQode: Run Deep QE: Run comprehensive QE analysis
  • SuperQode: Show Findings: Open findings panel
  • SuperQode: Clear Findings: Clear current diagnostics
  • SuperQode: Refresh Diagnostics: Reload findings from latest QR

docs.title: Key Bindings
docs.text:
Default key bindings (can be customized):

Action Windows/Linux macOS Show Quick Fix Ctrl+. Cmd+. Show Hover Ctrl+K Ctrl+I Cmd+K Cmd+I Go to Problem F8 F8

docs.title: 1. Install Extension
docs.text: code --install-extension superqode.superqode

docs.title: 2. Open Project
docs.text:
cd /path/to/project
code .

docs.title: 3. Run QE
docs.text:
• Press Ctrl+Shift+P (Cmd+Shift+P on Mac)
  • Type "SuperQode: Run Quick Scan"
  • Wait for analysis to complete

docs.title: 4. Review Findings
docs.text:
• Open Problems panel (View → Problems)
  • Click on findings to jump to code
  • Hover over underlined code for details

docs.title: 5. Apply Fixes
docs.text:
• Place cursor on finding
  • Press Ctrl+. (Cmd+. on Mac)
  • Select "Apply QE Fix"

docs.title: Custom LSP Configuration
docs.text:
For advanced editors, configure LSP directly:

{
  "lsp": {
    "superqode": {
      "command": ["superqode", "serve", "lsp"],
      "args": ["--transport", "stdio"],
      "rootPatterns": ["superqode.yaml", ".git"],
      "filetypes": ["*"],
      "initializationOptions": {},
      "settings": {}
    }
  }
}

docs.title: WebSocket Transport
docs.text:
Some editors support WebSocket (if added to LSP server):

# Future feature
superqode serve lsp --transport websocket --port 9000

docs.title: 1. Run QE Before Reviewing
docs.text:
Always run QE session before expecting diagnostics:

superqe run . --mode quick

docs.title: 2. Use Quick Mode for Development
docs.text:
Quick mode is faster and suitable for development:

# In VSCode command
SuperQode: Run Quick Scan

docs.title: 3. Review Before Applying Fixes
docs.text:
Don't auto-apply fixes. Review them first:

  • Hover to see suggested fix
  • Check the patch in Problems panel
  • Apply manually if needed

docs.title: 4. Exclude Build Artifacts
docs.text:
Configure excludes for better performance:

qe:
  workspace:
    exclude:
      - node_modules
      - dist
      - build

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• CI/CD Integration - Pipeline integration
  • QE Features - Understanding QE capabilities

docs.title: Providers
docs.text: SuperQode supports multiple provider types for connecting to AI models and agents.

docs.title: Provider Types
docs.text:
• BYOK Providers

    Bring Your Own Key - connect to cloud AI providers using your API keys.

    BYOK Providers

  • ACP Agents

    Agent Client Protocol - connect to coding agents like OpenCode.

    ACP Agents

  • Local Providers

    Run models locally with Ollama, LM Studio, MLX, or vLLM.

    Local Providers

  • OpenResponses

    Use the OpenResponses gateway for enhanced capabilities.

    OpenResponses

docs.title: Execution Modes
docs.text:
SuperQode supports three execution modes:

Mode Description Use Case BYOK Cloud AI providers with your API key Production, team use ACP Coding agents with full capabilities Complex tasks Local Self-hosted models Privacy, cost savings

docs.title: BYOK (Cloud Providers)
docs.text:
# Set API key
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=sk-ant-...

# Connect
superqode connect byok anthropic claude-sonnet-4

docs.title: ACP (Coding Agents)
docs.text:
# Connect to OpenCode
superqode connect acp opencode

docs.title: Local (Self-Hosted)
docs.text:
# Start Ollama
ollama serve

# Connect
superqode connect local ollama qwen3:8b

docs.title: Tier 1 (First-Class Support)
docs.text:
Full support with optimized prompts (Enterprise adds prompt packs):

Provider Models Anthropic Claude Opus 4.5, Sonnet 4, Haiku 4 OpenAI GPT-4o, o1 Google Gemini 2.5 Pro/Flash

docs.title: Tier 2 (Supported)
docs.text:
Tested and supported:

Provider Models Deepseek Deepseek V3, R1 Mistral Mistral Large xAI Grok

docs.title: Local Tier
docs.text:
Self-hosted options:

Provider Description Ollama Easy local deployment LM Studio GUI-based local models MLX Apple Silicon optimized vLLM High-performance inference

docs.title: Listing Providers
docs.text:
# List all providers
superqode providers list

# List by category
superqode providers list --category us
superqode providers list --category local

# Show configured only
superqode providers list --configured

docs.title: Testing Connections
docs.text:
# Test a provider
superqode providers test anthropic

# Test with specific model
superqode providers test anthropic -m claude-sonnet-4

docs.title: In superqode.yaml
docs.text:
default:
  mode: byok
  provider: anthropic
  model: claude-sonnet-4

providers:
  anthropic:
    api_key_env: ANTHROPIC_API_KEY
    recommended_models:
      - claude-opus-4-5
      - claude-sonnet-4

  ollama:
    base_url: http://localhost:11434
    recommended_models:
      - qwen3:8b

docs.title: Per-Role Configuration
docs.text:
team:
  modes:
    qe:
      roles:
        security_tester:
          mode: byok
          provider: anthropic
          model: claude-sonnet-4

        unit_tester:
          mode: local
          provider: ollama
          model: qwen3:8b

docs.title: US Labs
docs.text: Provider API Key Variable Documentation anthropic ANTHROPIC_API_KEY docs.anthropic.com openai OPENAI_API_KEY platform.openai.com google GOOGLE_API_KEY ai.google.dev xai XAI_API_KEY x.ai/api

docs.title: China Labs
docs.text: Provider API Key Variable deepseek DEEPSEEK_API_KEY zhipu ZHIPU_API_KEY alibaba ALIBABA_API_KEY

docs.title: Model Hosts
docs.text: Provider API Key Variable Notes openrouter OPENROUTER_API_KEY 95+ models together TOGETHER_API_KEY Open models groq GROQ_API_KEY Fast inference fireworks FIREWORKS_API_KEY Open models

docs.title: Local Providers
docs.text: Provider Default Port Notes ollama 11434 Easy setup lmstudio 1234 GUI interface mlx 8080 Apple Silicon vllm 8000 Production

docs.title: Free Tiers
docs.text:
Some providers offer free access:

# List free providers
superqode providers list --category free
Provider Free Models Google AI gemini-2.5-flash (limited) Groq llama-3.3-70b (rate limited) OpenRouter Some open models

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• BYOK Providers - Cloud provider setup
  • ACP Agents - Coding agent integration
  • Local Providers - Self-hosted models
  • OpenResponses - Gateway configuration

docs.title: ACP Agents
docs.text: Agent Client Protocol (ACP) mode connects SuperQode to full-featured coding agents.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
ACP agents provide:

  • Full capabilities: File editing, shell execution, MCP tools
  • Structured prompting: Optimized for coding tasks
  • Tool integration: Access to development environment
  • Persistent context: Maintains state across operations

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Connect to OpenCode
superqode connect acp opencode

docs.title: Supported Agents
docs.text: Use superqode agents list --protocol acp to see the current list (it’s driven by the built‑in agent registry and any local agent definitions).

docs.title: OpenCode
docs.text:
OpenCode is the primary ACP agent:

# Install OpenCode
npm i -g opencode-ai

# Verify installation
opencode --version

# Connect via SuperQode
superqode connect acp opencode

docs.title: Capabilities
docs.text: Capability Description file_editing Create, read, edit files shell_execution Run shell commands mcp_tools Use MCP servers git_operations Git commands

docs.title: Other ACP-Compatible Agents
docs.text:
SuperQode includes registry entries for these ACP agents (availability depends on local installation):

  • Claude Code (ACP adapter: claude-code-acp)
  • Codex (ACP adapter: npx @openai/codex-acp or codex-acp)
  • OpenHands (openhands acp)
  • Gemini CLI (gemini --experimental-acp)
  • Goose (goose)
  • Kimi CLI (kimi --acp)
  • Augment Code / Auggie (auggie --acp)
  • Stakpak (stakpak)
  • VT Code (vtcode-acp)
  • fast-agent (ACP entrypoint: fast-agent-acp)
  • LLMling-Agent (llmling-agent)
  • cagent (cagent)
  • Code Assistant (see its agent card for the ACP command)

If an agent requires an ACP adapter, install it first using the setup instructions from superqode agents show <agent>.

docs.title: In superqode.yaml
docs.text:
agents:
  opencode:
    description: "OpenCode coding agent"
    protocol: acp
    command: opencode
    auth_file: ~/.local/share/opencode/auth.json
    capabilities:
      - file_editing
      - shell_execution
      - mcp_tools

docs.title: Per-Role Configuration
docs.text:
team:
  modes:
    qe:
      roles:
        fullstack:
          mode: acp
          coding_agent: opencode
          description: "Senior QE using OpenCode"

docs.title: Agent Properties
docs.text: Property Type Description description string Agent description protocol string Protocol type (always acp) command string Command to run agent args [string] Command arguments auth_file string Path to authentication file capabilities [string] Agent capabilities

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. SuperQode spawns the agent process
  2. Communicates via ACP (JSON over stdin/stdout)
  3. Agent has access to file system and shell
  4. Results streamed back to SuperQode

docs.title: Message Format
docs.text:
{
  "type": "request",
  "id": "req-001",
  "method": "analyze",
  "params": {
    "path": "/src/api/users.py",
    "focus": "security"
  }
}

docs.title: Compared to BYOK
docs.text: Feature BYOK ACP File editing Via prompts Native capability Shell access Via prompts Native capability Context Per-request Persistent Speed Fast May be slower Setup API key only Agent installation

docs.title: When to Use ACP
docs.text:
• Complex multi-step tasks
  • Tasks requiring file manipulation
  • Tasks requiring shell commands
  • Integration with other tools

docs.title: When to Use BYOK
docs.text:
• Simple analysis tasks
  • Quick scans
  • Cost-sensitive workloads
  • Team environments

docs.title: Define a Custom Agent
docs.text:
agents:
  custom_agent:
    description: "My custom ACP agent"
    protocol: acp
    command: /path/to/my-agent
    args:
      - --mode
      - interactive
      - --workspace
      - .
    capabilities:
      - file_editing
      - shell_execution

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
Custom agents must:

  1. Accept ACP messages on stdin
  2. Return ACP responses on stdout
  3. Support the ACP protocol methods defined in the spec (initialize, session/new, session/prompt, session/update, fs/, terminal/)
  4. Handle graceful shutdown

docs.title: Agent Not Found
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] Agent 'opencode' not found

Solution: Install the agent:

npm i -g opencode-ai

docs.title: Connection Failed
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] Failed to connect to agent

Solutions: - Verify agent is installed: which opencode - Check agent version: opencode --version - Run agent manually to check for errors

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] Permission denied: auth_file

Solution: Check auth file permissions:

ls -la ~/.local/share/opencode/auth.json

docs.title: Agent Timeout
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] Agent response timeout

Solutions: - Increase timeout in configuration - Check if agent is busy - Restart the agent

docs.title: 1. Use for Complex Tasks
docs.text:
ACP excels at multi-step tasks:

team:
  modes:
    qe:
      roles:
        fullstack:
          mode: acp
          coding_agent: opencode
          job_description: |
            Perform comprehensive QE review:
            - Analyze code structure
            - Run tests
            - Check security issues
            - Generate fix patches

docs.title: 2. Combine with BYOK
docs.text:
Use ACP for complex roles, BYOK for simple ones:

team:
  modes:
    qe:
      roles:
        security_tester:
          mode: byok
          provider: anthropic
          model: claude-sonnet-4

        fullstack:
          mode: acp
          coding_agent: opencode

docs.title: 3. Monitor Resource Usage
docs.text: ACP agents may use significant resources. Monitor: - Memory usage - CPU usage - Disk I/O

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• BYOK Providers - Cloud provider setup
  • Local Providers - Self-hosted models
  • Team Configuration - Role setup

docs.title: BYOK Providers
docs.text: Bring Your Own Key (BYOK) mode connects to cloud AI providers using your API keys.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
BYOK is the primary mode for production use:

  • Full control: Use your own API keys and quotas
  • Cost management: Pay directly to providers
  • Model selection: Choose specific models for roles
  • Privacy: Data goes directly to your chosen provider

docs.title: Quick Setup
docs.text:
# 1. Set API key
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=sk-ant-...

# 2. Verify configuration
superqode providers test anthropic

# 3. Connect
superqode connect byok anthropic claude-sonnet-4

docs.title: Tier 1 (First-Class Support)
docs.text: Full optimization and testing:

docs.title: Anthropic (Claude)
docs.text:
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=sk-ant-...
superqode connect byok anthropic claude-sonnet-4
Model Best For claude-opus-4-5 Complex analysis claude-sonnet-4-5 Balanced performance claude-sonnet-4 General use claude-haiku-4-5 Fast, cost-effective

Documentation: docs.anthropic.com

docs.title: OpenAI (GPT)
docs.text:
export OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-...
superqode connect byok openai gpt-4o
Model Best For gpt-4o General use gpt-4o-mini Cost-effective o1 Complex reasoning o1-mini Fast reasoning

Documentation: platform.openai.com

docs.title: Google AI (Gemini)
docs.text:
export GOOGLE_API_KEY=AIza...
superqode connect byok google gemini-2.5-pro
Model Best For gemini-2.5-pro Complex tasks gemini-2.5-flash Fast, cost-effective

Documentation: ai.google.dev

docs.title: Tier 2 (Supported)
docs.text: Tested and working:

docs.title: Deepseek
docs.text:
export DEEPSEEK_API_KEY=sk-...
superqode connect byok deepseek deepseek-v3
Model Best For deepseek-v3 General use deepseek-r1 Reasoning

Cost: Very competitive pricing

docs.title: Mistral
docs.text:
export MISTRAL_API_KEY=...
superqode connect byok mistral mistral-large

docs.title: xAI (Grok)
docs.text:
export XAI_API_KEY=...
superqode connect byok xai grok

docs.title: Model Hosts
docs.text: Access multiple models through a single API:

docs.title: OpenRouter
docs.text:
export OPENROUTER_API_KEY=sk-or-...
superqode connect byok openrouter anthropic/claude-sonnet-4
  • 95+ models from various providers
  • Use format: provider/model-name

Documentation: openrouter.ai

docs.title: Together AI
docs.text:
export TOGETHER_API_KEY=...
superqode connect byok together meta-llama/Llama-3.3-70B-Instruct

docs.title: Groq

  • Very fast inference
  • Free tier available

docs.title: Fireworks
docs.text:

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Provider Variable Notes Anthropic ANTHROPIC_API_KEY Required OpenAI OPENAI_API_KEY Required Google GOOGLE_API_KEY Required Deepseek DEEPSEEK_API_KEY Required OpenRouter OPENROUTER_API_KEY Required Together TOGETHER_API_KEY Required Groq GROQ_API_KEY Required Mistral MISTRAL_API_KEY Required xAI XAI_API_KEY Required

  anthropic:
    api_key_env: ANTHROPIC_API_KEY

      - claude-opus-4-5

docs.title: Per-Role Configuration
docs.text:
team:
  modes:
    qe:
      roles:
        security_tester:
          mode: byok
          provider: anthropic
          model: claude-sonnet-4

        performance_tester:
          mode: byok
          provider: openai
          model: gpt-4o

docs.title: Tracking Costs
docs.text:
superqode:
  cost_tracking:
    enabled: true
    show_after_task: true

After each task, you'll see:

Cost Summary:
  Provider: anthropic
  Model: claude-sonnet-4
  Input tokens: 15,234
  Output tokens: 2,456
  Estimated cost: $0.12

docs.title: Cost-Effective Strategies
docs.text:
1. Use appropriate models: Haiku/mini for simple tasks
  2. Use quick mode: Shorter sessions, less tokens
  3. Local fallback: Use local models for high-volume tasks

docs.title: API Key Management
docs.text:
# Don't commit API keys
echo "ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=sk-ant-..." >> .env
echo ".env" >> .gitignore

docs.title: Rotate Keys Regularly
docs.text:
• Anthropic: console.anthropic.com
  • OpenAI: platform.openai.com/api-keys

docs.title: Use Project Keys
docs.text: Where available, use project-specific API keys with limited scope.

docs.title: "Not Configured" Error
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] Provider 'anthropic' is not configured

Solution: Set the API key environment variable.

docs.title: "Invalid API Key"
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] Connection failed: Invalid API key

Solution: Verify your API key is correct and has appropriate permissions.

docs.title: Rate Limiting
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] Rate limit exceeded

Solutions: - Wait and retry - Use a different provider temporarily - Upgrade your API tier

docs.title: Model Not Found
docs.text:
[INCORRECT] Model 'claude-5' not found

Solution: Check available models:

superqode providers show anthropic

docs.title: Provider Comparison
docs.text: Provider Speed Cost Models Best For Anthropic Fast Medium 4 Security, reasoning OpenAI Fast Medium 4 General, reasoning Google Fast Low 2 General, vision Deepseek Medium Low 2 Cost-effective Groq Very Fast Low 3 Speed-critical

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Local Providers - Self-hosted alternatives
  • ACP Agents - Coding agent integration
  • Provider Commands - CLI reference

docs.title: Local Providers
docs.text: Run AI models locally for privacy, cost savings, and offline use.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Local providers offer:

  • Privacy: Data stays on your machine
  • Cost savings: No API fees
  • Offline use: Work without internet
  • Full control: Model selection and tuning

docs.title: Supported Providers
docs.text: Provider Best For Setup Complexity Ollama Easy setup, many models Easy LM Studio GUI interface, beginners Easy MLX Apple Silicon, performance Medium vLLM Production, high throughput Advanced

docs.title: Ollama
docs.text: The easiest way to run local models.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
macOS: 

brew install ollama

Linux: 

curl -fsSL https://ollama.com/install.sh | sh

Windows: Download from ollama.com

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Start Ollama
ollama serve

# Pull a model
ollama pull qwen3:8b

# Connect in SuperQode
superqode connect local ollama qwen3:8b

docs.title: Recommended Models
docs.text: Model Size Best For qwen3:8b ~5GB General use, coding llama3.2:latest ~4GB General use codellama:13b ~7GB Code analysis deepseek-coder:6.7b ~4GB Code tasks

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
providers:
  ollama:
    base_url: http://localhost:11434
    type: openai-compatible
    recommended_models:
      - qwen3:8b
      - llama3.2:latest
      - codellama:13b

docs.title: LM Studio
docs.text: GUI-based local model runner.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
1. Download from lmstudio.ai
  2. Install and open LM Studio
  3. Download a model (search for "qwen" or "llama")
  4. Load the model
  5. Start Local Server (port 1234)

docs.title: Connect
docs.text: superqode connect local lmstudio local-model

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
providers:
  lmstudio:
    base_url: http://localhost:1234
    type: openai-compatible

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Keep LM Studio running in background
  • Load model before connecting
  • Check "Local Server" tab for status

docs.title: MLX (Apple Silicon)
docs.text: Optimized for M1/M2/M3 Macs.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: pip install mlx-lm

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Download model
mlx_lm.download mlx-community/Qwen2.5-Coder-3B-4bit

# Start server (in separate terminal)

docs.title: OpenResponses Provider
docs.text: OpenResponses is a unified API specification that provides a consistent interface across multiple AI providers, with advanced features like streaming, reasoning, and built-in tools.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
OpenResponses provides:

  • Unified API: Single interface for multiple AI providers
  • Streaming: 45+ event types for real-time updates
  • Reasoning: Access to model thinking/reasoning content
  • Built-in Tools: Native support for apply_patch, code_interpreter, file_search
  • Message Conversion: Automatic conversion between messages and items

docs.title: What is OpenResponses?
docs.text:
OpenResponses is an open specification for AI provider APIs that extends beyond basic chat completions. It supports:

  • Structured Outputs: Items-based message format
  • Reasoning Content: Access to model reasoning/thinking
  • Rich Streaming: Detailed streaming events for progress tracking
  • Native Tools: Built-in tool definitions and execution
  • Provider Agnostic: Works with any OpenResponses-compatible provider

docs.title: Supported Providers
docs.text:
OpenResponses works with providers that implement the specification:

  • Ollama: With OpenResponses support enabled
  • vLLM: Via OpenResponses adapter
  • Custom Servers: Any OpenResponses-compatible endpoint
  • Cloud Providers: With OpenResponses-compatible APIs

docs.title: Streaming with 45+ Event Types
docs.text:
OpenResponses supports rich streaming with detailed events:

  • response.created: Response started
  • response.in_progress: Response in progress
  • response.output.text.delta: Text token delta
  • response.reasoning.delta: Reasoning content delta
  • response.function_call.arguments.delta: Tool call arguments
  • response.completed: Response finished
async for chunk in gateway.stream_completion(messages, model):
    if chunk.type == "response.output.text.delta":
        print(chunk.content, end="")
    elif chunk.type == "response.reasoning.delta":
        print(f"[Reasoning: {chunk.content}]", end="")

docs.title: Reasoning/Thinking Content
docs.text:
Access model reasoning alongside output:

response = await gateway.chat_completion(messages, model)
print(f"Output: {response.content}")
print(f"Reasoning: {response.reasoning}")  # Model's thinking process

Reasoning Levels:

  • low: Minimal reasoning (faster, less insight)
  • medium: Balanced reasoning (default)
  • high: Detailed reasoning (slower, more insight)

docs.title: Built-in Tools
docs.text: OpenResponses defines native tools:

docs.title: apply_patch
docs.text:
Apply code patches directly:

{
  "type": "apply_patch",
  "patch": {
    "path": "src/api/users.py",
    "diff": "@@ -42,7 +42,9 @@\n-sql = f\"...\"\n+sql = \"...\"\n+params = (...)"
  }
}

docs.title: code_interpreter
docs.text:
Execute code in isolated environment:

{
  "type": "code_interpreter",
  "code": "def test_api():\n    response = requests.get('...')\n    assert response.status_code == 200"
}

docs.title: file_search
docs.text:
Search and retrieve files:

{
  "type": "file_search",
  "query": "authentication middleware",
  "paths": ["src/"]
}

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
from superqode.providers.gateway import OpenResponsesGateway

gateway = OpenResponsesGateway(
    base_url="http://localhost:11434",
    reasoning_effort="medium"
)

# Chat completion
response = await gateway.chat_completion(
    messages=[
        {"role": "user", "content": "Analyze this code..."}
    ],
    model="qwen3:8b"
)

print(response.content)

docs.title: Streaming
docs.text:
async for chunk in gateway.stream_completion(
    messages=messages,
    model="qwen3:8b"
):
    if chunk.type == "response.output.text.delta":
        print(chunk.content, end="", flush=True)

docs.title: With Tools
docs.text:
tools = [
    {
        "type": "function",
        "function": {
            "name": "read_file",
            "description": "Read a file",
            "parameters": {
                "type": "object",
                "properties": {
                    "path": {"type": "string"}
                }
            }
        }
    }
]

response = await gateway.chat_completion(
    messages=messages,
    model="qwen3:8b",
    tools=tools
)

docs.title: Reasoning Configuration
docs.text:
gateway = OpenResponsesGateway(
    base_url="http://localhost:11434",
    reasoning_effort="high",  # Get detailed reasoning
    truncation="auto"         # Auto-truncate if needed
)

docs.title: SuperQode Configuration
docs.text:
# superqode.yaml
providers:
  openresponses:
    base_url: http://localhost:11434
    reasoning_effort: medium
    truncation: auto
    timeout: 300

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
export OPENRESPONSES_BASE_URL=http://localhost:11434
export OPENRESPONSES_REASONING_EFFORT=medium
export OPENRESPONSES_TRUNCATION=auto

docs.title: Gateway Initialization
docs.text:
from superqode.providers.gateway import OpenResponsesGateway

gateway = OpenResponsesGateway(
    base_url="http://localhost:11434",
    api_key=None,  # Optional for local providers
    reasoning_effort="medium",
    truncation="auto",
    timeout=300.0,
    track_costs=False  # Local providers typically don't charge
)

docs.title: Message ↔ Item Conversion
docs.text: OpenResponses uses an items-based format internally. SuperQode automatically converts:

docs.title: Messages to Items
docs.text:
from superqode.providers.openresponses import messages_to_items

messages = [
    {"role": "user", "content": "Hello"}
]

items = messages_to_items(messages)
# Converts to OpenResponses item format

docs.title: Items to Messages
docs.text:
from superqode.providers.openresponses import items_to_messages

# After receiving OpenResponses response
messages = items_to_messages(response.items)

docs.title: Event Types
docs.text: Event Description response.created Response started response.in_progress Processing in progress response.output.text.delta Text token delta response.output.text.done Text output complete response.reasoning.delta Reasoning content delta response.reasoning.done Reasoning complete response.function_call.arguments.delta Tool arguments delta response.function_call.arguments.done Tool arguments complete response.completed Response finished

docs.title: Processing Events
docs.text:
async for chunk in gateway.stream_completion(messages, model):
    event_type = chunk.type

    if event_type == "response.output.text.delta":
        # Accumulate text
        output_text += chunk.content

    elif event_type == "response.reasoning.delta":
        # Accumulate reasoning
        reasoning += chunk.content

    elif event_type == "response.function_call.arguments.delta":
        # Accumulate tool call
        tool_args += chunk.content

    elif event_type == "response.completed":
        # Process final response
        final_response = chunk.response

docs.title: Tool Conversion
docs.text:
OpenResponses tools are automatically converted:

from superqode.providers.openresponses import (
    convert_tools_to_openresponses,
    convert_tools_from_openresponses
)

# Convert SuperQode tools to OpenResponses
openresponses_tools = convert_tools_to_openresponses(tools)

# Convert OpenResponses tools back
superqode_tools = convert_tools_from_openresponses(openresponses_tools)

docs.title: Low
docs.text:
Minimal reasoning, fastest:

gateway = OpenResponsesGateway(
    reasoning_effort="low"
)

Use when: - Speed is critical - Simple tasks - Reasoning not needed

docs.title: Medium (Default)
docs.text:
Balanced reasoning:

gateway = OpenResponsesGateway(
    reasoning_effort="medium"
)

Use when: - General QE tasks - Need some insight - Balance of speed and detail

docs.title: High
docs.text:
Detailed reasoning, slower:

gateway = OpenResponsesGateway(
    reasoning_effort="high"
)

Use when: - Complex analysis needed - Understanding model logic - Debugging model behavior

docs.title: Auto (Default)
docs.text:
Automatically truncate if needed:

gateway = OpenResponsesGateway(
    truncation="auto"
)

docs.title: Disabled
docs.text:
Never truncate:

gateway = OpenResponsesGateway(
    truncation="disabled"
)

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
from superqode.providers.gateway import (
    GatewayError,
    ModelNotFoundError,
    RateLimitError
)

try:
    response = await gateway.chat_completion(messages, model)
except ModelNotFoundError:
    print(f"Model {model} not found")
except RateLimitError:
    print("Rate limit exceeded")
except GatewayError as e:
    print(f"Gateway error: {e}")

docs.title: 1. Use Appropriate Reasoning Level
docs.text:
# Quick tasks
gateway = OpenResponsesGateway(reasoning_effort="low")

# QE analysis
gateway = OpenResponsesGateway(reasoning_effort="medium")

# Deep investigation
gateway = OpenResponsesGateway(reasoning_effort="high")

docs.title: 2. Handle Streaming Efficiently
docs.text:
async def process_stream(gateway, messages, model):
    output = ""
    reasoning = ""

    async for chunk in gateway.stream_completion(messages, model):
        if chunk.type == "response.output.text.delta":
            output += chunk.content
            # Process incrementally
            process_text_delta(chunk.content)
        elif chunk.type == "response.reasoning.delta":
            reasoning += chunk.content

    return output, reasoning

docs.title: 3. Use Tools for Complex Tasks
docs.text:
tools = [
    {
        "type": "function",
        "function": {
            "name": "analyze_code",
            "description": "Analyze code quality",
            "parameters": {...}
        }
    }
]

response = await gateway.chat_completion(
    messages,
    model,
    tools=tools
)

docs.title: Provider Not Compatible
docs.text:
Problem: Provider doesn't support OpenResponses

Solution: Use standard gateway instead:

from superqode.providers.gateway import LiteLLMGateway

gateway = LiteLLMGateway()  # Standard gateway

docs.title: Reasoning Not Available
docs.text:
Problem: Provider doesn't support reasoning

Solution: Reasoning will be empty; output still works:

response = await gateway.chat_completion(messages, model)
if response.reasoning:
    print(f"Reasoning: {response.reasoning}")
else:
    print("Reasoning not available for this provider")

docs.title: Streaming Errors
docs.text:
Problem: Streaming events not parsed correctly

Solution: Check event parser:

# Enable debug logging
import logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

docs.title: With Ollama
docs.text:
gateway = OpenResponsesGateway(
    base_url="http://localhost:11434"
)

response = await gateway.chat_completion(
    messages=[{"role": "user", "content": "Test"}],
    model="qwen3:8b"
)

docs.title: With vLLM
docs.text:
gateway = OpenResponsesGateway(
    base_url="http://localhost:8000"
)

response = await gateway.chat_completion(
    messages=[{"role": "user", "content": "Test"}],
    model="Qwen/Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct"
)

  • BYOK Providers - Cloud provider setup

docs.title: QE Features
docs.text: SuperQode provides comprehensive quality engineering features for AI-assisted code analysis and testing.

docs.title: Feature Overview
docs.text:
SuperQode OSS ships the core agentic scan + QR workflow. Enterprise adds automated fixes, verified patches, test generation, CI-grade outputs, and curated prompt packs. Contact us for access.

  • Artifacts & Reports

    QRs, patches, generated tests, and other outputs from QE sessions.

    Artifacts

  • Test Generation (Enterprise)

    Automatic generation of regression tests for detected issues.

    Test Generation

  • Noise Filtering

    Configure thresholds to reduce false positives and focus on important findings.

    Noise Filtering

  • Natural Language QE (Enterprise)

    Describe testing needs in plain English - automatic role and scope selection.

    Natural Language QE

  • Constitution System

    Define quality principles, rules, and guardrails for your project.

    Constitution

  • Fix Verifier (Enterprise)

    Automatically verify suggested fixes work before presenting them.

    Fix Verifier

docs.title: QE Session Lifecycle
docs.text:
Every QE session follows this lifecycle:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                    QE SESSION LIFECYCLE                      │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                              │
│  1. SNAPSHOT         Original code preserved                 │
│        ↓                                                     │
│  2. QE SANDBOX       Agents freely modify, inject tests,    │
│        │             run experiments, break things           │
│        ↓                                                     │
│  3. ANALYSIS         Role-specific quality investigation    │
│        ↓                                                     │
│  4. REPORT           Document what was done, what was found │
│        ↓                                                     │
│  5. REVERT           All changes removed, original restored │
│        ↓                                                     │
│  6. ARTIFACTS        Patches, tests, reports preserved      │
│                      (in .superqode/qe-artifacts/)          │
│                                                              │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Quality Reports (QRs)
docs.text:
Research-grade forensic artifacts that document the complete investigation process:

  • Investigation summary and methodology
  • All findings with evidence
  • Root cause analysis
  • Suggested fixes with validation
  • Production readiness verdict

Learn more about QRs

docs.title: Ephemeral Workspace
docs.text:
Safe, isolated testing environment:

  • Original code is always preserved
  • Agents can test destructively
  • Automatic revert after session
  • Artifacts preserved for review

Learn more about Ephemeral Workspace

docs.title: Allow Suggestions Mode
docs.text:
Demonstrated fixes in a sandbox:

  • Agent creates fix in sandbox
  • Runs tests to verify fix works
  • Proves improvement with evidence
  • Reverts all changes
  • User decides to apply or reject

Learn more about Suggestions

docs.title: Quick Scan
docs.text:
Fast, time-boxed analysis for development feedback:

superqe run . --mode quick
  • Duration: ~60 seconds
  • Use case: Pre-commit, developer feedback
  • Depth: Shallow analysis
  • Test generation: Disabled

docs.title: Deep QE
docs.text:
Comprehensive quality investigation:

superqe run . --mode deep
  • Duration: ~30 minutes
  • Use case: Pre-release, nightly CI
  • Depth: Full analysis
  • Test generation: Available

docs.title: Execution Roles
docs.text:
Run existing tests deterministically:

Role Purpose smoke_tester Fast critical path validation sanity_tester Core functionality verification regression_tester Full test suite execution lint_tester Fast static linting across languages

docs.title: Detection Roles
docs.text:
AI-powered issue discovery:

Role Focus security_tester OWASP Top 10, injection, auth api_tester API contracts, validation unit_tester Coverage gaps, edge cases performance_tester Bottlenecks, N+1 queries e2e_tester Workflow integration

docs.title: Heuristic Role
docs.text: Role Purpose fullstack Senior QE comprehensive review

docs.title: Console Output
docs.text: Real-time progress and findings in the terminal.

docs.title: JSONL Streaming
docs.text:
For CI/CD integration:

superqe run . --jsonl

docs.title: JUnit XML
docs.text:
For test reporting integration:

superqe run . --junit results.xml

docs.title: Web Dashboard
docs.text:
Interactive HTML report:

superqe dashboard

docs.title: Output Settings
docs.text:
qe:
  output:
    directory: ".superqode"
    reports_format: markdown  # markdown, html, json
    keep_history: true

docs.title: Mode Settings
docs.text:
qe:
  modes:
    quick_scan:
      timeout: 60
      depth: shallow
      generate_tests: false

    deep_qe:
      timeout: 1800
      depth: full
      generate_tests: true

docs.title: Pre-Commit Check
docs.text: superqe run . --mode quick -r security_tester

docs.title: Security Audit
docs.text: superqe run . --mode deep -r security_tester

docs.title: Full QE Session
docs.text: superqe run . --mode deep --allow-suggestions --generate

docs.title: CI Integration
docs.text: superqe run . --mode quick --jsonl --junit results.xml

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Artifacts - QE output artifacts
  • Test Generation - Automatic test creation
  • Noise Filtering - Reduce false positives
  • CI/CD Integration - Automated quality gates

docs.title: Artifacts & Reports
docs.text: SuperQode generates comprehensive artifacts from QE sessions, preserved in .superqode/qe-artifacts/.

docs.title: Artifact Location
docs.text:
All artifacts are saved to:

.superqode/qe-artifacts/
├── manifest.json                # Index of saved artifacts
├── qr/
│   ├── qr-<date>-<session>.md   # Quality Report (Markdown)
│   └── qr-<date>-<session>.json # Quality Report (JSON)
├── patches/
│   ├── fix-<finding-id>.patch   # Suggested fix patches (when available)
│   └── ...
├── logs/
│   └── ...                       # Execution logs / work logs (if enabled)
├── evidence/
│   └── ...                       # Screenshots, traces, captured outputs
├── coverage/
│   └── ...                       # Coverage outputs (if generated)
└── generated-tests/
    ├── unit/
    ├── integration/
    ├── api/
    ├── fuzz/
    └── ...

docs.title: Quality Report (QR)
docs.text: The primary output is a JSON-formatted QR:

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
{
  "session": {
    "id": "qe-session-20240118-143022",

docs.title: Patches
docs.text:
Suggested fix patches are in unified diff format:

--- a/src/api/users.py
+++ b/src/api/users.py
@@ -40,7 +40,9 @@ def search_users(query: str):
     """Search for users by name."""
     conn = get_db_connection()
     cursor = conn.cursor()
-    sql = f"SELECT * FROM users WHERE name LIKE '%{query}%'"
+    sql = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE name LIKE ?"
+    params = (f"%{query}%",)
-    cursor.execute(sql)
+    cursor.execute(sql, params)
     return cursor.fetchall()

docs.title: Applying Patches
docs.text:
# Preview
cat .superqode/qe-artifacts/patches/fix-sql-injection.patch

# Dry run
git apply --check .superqode/qe-artifacts/patches/fix-sql-injection.patch

# Apply
git apply .superqode/qe-artifacts/patches/fix-sql-injection.patch

# Or use SuperQode
superqode suggestions apply finding-001

docs.title: Generated Tests
docs.text:
Regression tests are generated for verified findings:

# tests/generated/test_sql_injection.py
"""
Regression test for SQL Injection fix (finding-001)
Generated by SuperQode QE
"""

import pytest
from src.api.users import search_users

class TestSqlInjectionPrevention:
    """Tests that SQL injection is properly prevented."""

    def test_normal_search_works(self):
        """Normal search queries work correctly."""
        results = search_users("john")
        assert isinstance(results, list)

    def test_injection_attempt_neutralized(self):
        """SQL injection attempts are safely handled."""
        results = search_users("'; DROP TABLE users; --")
        assert isinstance(results, list)

    def test_special_chars_escaped(self):
        """Special characters are properly escaped."""
        results = search_users("O'Brien")
        assert isinstance(results, list)

Stream events for real-time processing:

superqe run . --jsonl | while read event; do

- name: Check for critical issues

docs.title: Constitution System
docs.text: Define quality principles, rules, and guardrails to enforce project-specific quality standards.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Constitution System provides a declarative way to define quality standards for your project:

  • Principles: High-level quality guidance
  • Rules: Enforcement mechanisms with actions
  • Metrics: Measurement definitions
  • Thresholds: Quality gates and blocking criteria

Constitutions are defined in YAML/JSON and evaluated during QE sessions to ensure code meets your quality standards.

docs.title: Principles
docs.text:
High-level quality guidance that describes what quality means for your project.

principles:
  - id: security-first
    name: Security First
    description: Security vulnerabilities must be addressed before release
    priority: critical
    category: security
    mandatory: true

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
Concrete enforcement mechanisms that define how principles are enforced.

rules:
  - id: no-sql-injection
    name: No SQL Injection
    principle_id: security-first
    conditions:
      - type: finding_type
        operator: equals
        value: "sql_injection"
    action:
      type: block
      severity: critical
    enabled: true

docs.title: Metrics
docs.text:
Measurable quality indicators.

metrics:
  - id: test-coverage
    name: Test Coverage
    description: Percentage of code covered by tests
    unit: percent
    aggregation: average

docs.title: Thresholds
docs.text:
Quality gates that block releases if not met.

thresholds:
  - id: min-coverage
    metric_id: test-coverage
    operator: gte
    value: 80.0
    blocking: true

docs.title: Basic Constitution
docs.text:
name: "My Project Constitution"
version: "1.0"
description: "Quality standards for My Project"

principles:
  - id: security-first
    name: Security First
    description: Security vulnerabilities must be addressed
    priority: critical
    mandatory: true

rules:
  - id: no-critical-security-issues
    name: No Critical Security Issues
    principle_id: security-first
    conditions:
      - type: severity
        operator: equals
        value: "critical"
      - type: category
        operator: equals
        value: "security"
    action:
      type: block
      severity: critical
    enabled: true

thresholds:
  - id: min-test-coverage
    metric_id: test-coverage
    operator: gte
    value: 80.0
    blocking: true

docs.title: Definition
docs.text:
principles:
  - id: unique-identifier
    name: Display Name
    description: Detailed description
    priority: critical | high | medium | low
    category: category-name
    mandatory: true | false
    related_principles: [id1, id2]
    tags: [tag1, tag2]

docs.title: Priority Levels
docs.text: Priority Meaning critical Must be enforced, blocks release high Important, should be enforced medium Recommended low Nice to have

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
principles:
  - id: maintainability
    name: Code Maintainability
    description: Code must be maintainable and readable
    priority: high
    category: code-quality
    mandatory: false
    tags: [maintainability, readability]

docs.title: Definition
docs.text:
rules:
  - id: unique-identifier
    name: Rule Name
    description: Rule description
    principle_id: principle-id
    conditions:
      - type: condition-type
        operator: operator
        value: value
    action:
      type: block | warn | adjust_severity | notify
      severity: severity-level
      notify_channels: [channel1]
    enabled: true | false
    severity: error | warning | info
    tags: [tag1, tag2]
    environments: [production, staging]

docs.title: Condition Types
docs.text:
• finding_type: Finding type (e.g., "sql_injection")
  • severity: Finding severity (e.g., "critical", "high")
  • category: Finding category (e.g., "security")
  • file_path: File path pattern
  • confidence: Confidence threshold

docs.title: Operators
docs.text:
• equals: Exact match
  • not_equals: Not equal
  • contains: Contains substring
  • matches: Regex match
  • gt, gte, lt, lte: Numeric comparison

docs.title: Actions
docs.text: Action Type Description block Block release/deployment warn Warning only adjust_severity Change finding severity notify Send notification

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
rules:
  - id: block-critical-security
    name: Block Critical Security Issues
    principle_id: security-first
    conditions:
      - type: severity
        operator: equals
        value: "critical"
      - type: category
        operator: equals
        value: "security"
    action:
      type: block
      severity: critical
    enabled: true
    severity: error

docs.title: Definition
docs.text:
metrics:
  - id: unique-identifier
    name: Metric Name
    description: Metric description
    unit: unit-name
    aggregation: sum | average | min | max | count

docs.title: Aggregation Types
docs.text: Type Description sum Sum of values average Average value min Minimum value max Maximum value count Count of items

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
metrics:
  - id: test-coverage
    name: Test Coverage
    description: Percentage of code covered by tests
    unit: percent
    aggregation: average

docs.title: Definition
docs.text:
thresholds:
  - id: unique-identifier
    metric_id: metric-id
    operator: gte | gt | lte | lt | equals
    value: threshold-value
    blocking: true | false
    period: time-period  # e.g., "7d"

docs.title: Operators
docs.text: Operator Meaning gte Greater than or equal gt Greater than lte Less than or equal lt Less than equals Equal

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
thresholds:
  - id: min-coverage
    metric_id: test-coverage
    operator: gte
    value: 80.0
    blocking: true

docs.title: During QE Sessions
docs.text:
Constitutions are evaluated automatically during QE sessions:

  1. Findings checked: Each finding checked against rules
  2. Metrics calculated: Metrics computed from session results
  3. Thresholds evaluated: Thresholds checked against metrics
  4. Actions taken: Block, warn, or notify based on rules

docs.title: Evaluation Result
docs.text:
{
  "status": "passed" | "failed" | "warning",
  "rules_checked": 15,
  "rules_violated": 2,
  "thresholds_checked": 5,
  "thresholds_violated": 1,
  "blocking_issues": ["no-critical-security-issues"],
  "warnings": ["low-coverage"]
}

docs.title: Loading Constitution
docs.text:
from superqode.superqe.constitution import load_constitution

constitution = load_constitution("constitution.yaml")

docs.title: Default Constitution
docs.text:
from superqode.superqe.constitution import get_default_constitution

constitution = get_default_constitution()

docs.title: YAML Configuration
docs.text:
# superqode.yaml
qe:
  constitution:
    path: "constitution.yaml"
    enabled: true

docs.title: Security-Focused
docs.text:
name: "Security Constitution"
version: "1.0"

principles:
  - id: security-first
    name: Security First
    priority: critical
    mandatory: true

rules:
  - id: no-sql-injection
    principle_id: security-first
    conditions:
      - type: finding_type
        operator: equals
        value: "sql_injection"
    action:
      type: block
      severity: critical

  - id: no-auth-bypass
    principle_id: security-first
    conditions:
      - type: finding_type
        operator: equals
        value: "authentication_bypass"
    action:
      type: block
      severity: critical

docs.title: Coverage-Focused
docs.text:
name: "Coverage Constitution"
version: "1.0"

metrics:
  - id: test-coverage
    name: Test Coverage
    unit: percent

thresholds:
  - id: min-coverage
    metric_id: test-coverage
    operator: gte
    value: 80.0
    blocking: true

docs.title: Inheritance
docs.text:
Constitutions can extend parent constitutions:

name: "Project-Specific Constitution"
version: "1.0"
extends: "default-constitution.yaml"

# Add additional rules
rules:
  - id: custom-rule
    name: Custom Rule
    # ...

docs.title: 1. Start with Principles
docs.text: Define high-level principles first, then create rules to enforce them.

docs.title: 2. Use Clear IDs
docs.text: Use descriptive IDs like no-sql-injection instead of rule-1.

docs.title: 3. Enable Gradually
docs.text: Start with warnings, then enable blocking rules once validated.

docs.title: 4. Document Intent
docs.text: Include descriptions explaining why rules exist.

docs.title: 5. Version Control
docs.text: Track constitution versions and changes over time.

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• QE Roles - Role-based quality engineering
  • Noise Filtering - Filtering findings

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• QE Features Index - All QE features
  • Configuration Reference - Config options

docs.title: Fix Verifier
docs.text:
Enterprise feature. Fix Verifier validates suggested fixes in a sandbox and reports whether they improve test outcomes and reduce regressions.

This page is a high‑level overview only. Detailed usage is available with the enterprise package.

docs.title: MCP Tools Integration
docs.text: Integrate Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers to extend SuperQode with external tools, resources, and prompts.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: MCP (Model Context Protocol) is a standard protocol for connecting AI applications to external tools and services. SuperQode includes full MCP client support, allowing QE agents to use tools from MCP servers during quality engineering sessions.

docs.title: Capabilities
docs.text:
• Tool Execution: Agents can call tools from MCP servers
  • Resource Access: Read files, databases, APIs via MCP resources
  • Prompt Templates: Use MCP prompt templates in QE workflows
  • Multi-Server: Connect to multiple MCP servers simultaneously
  • Auto-Discovery: Tools, resources, and prompts automatically discovered on connection

docs.title: What is MCP?
docs.text:
MCP is a protocol standard (aligned with Zed editor's implementation) that enables:

  • Tools: Executable functions (e.g., file operations, API calls, code analysis)
  • Resources: Readable data sources (e.g., files, databases, configuration)
  • Prompts: Reusable prompt templates with arguments

MCP servers expose these capabilities, and SuperQode agents can use them during QE sessions.

docs.title: Transport Types
docs.text: SuperQode supports three transport types for MCP servers:

docs.title: stdio (Default)
docs.text:
Local process communication via stdin/stdout:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "filesystem": {
      "transport": "stdio",
      "command": "uvx",
      "args": ["mcp-server-filesystem", "--root", "."]
    }
  }
}

Use case: Local MCP servers installed on your system

docs.title: HTTP
docs.text:
HTTP-based communication with streaming support:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "remote-server": {
      "transport": "http",
      "url": "https://mcp.example.com/api",
      "headers": {
        "Authorization": "Bearer token"
      }
    }
  }
}

Use case: Remote MCP servers accessible via HTTP

docs.title: SSE
docs.text:
Server-Sent Events for real-time streaming:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "realtime-server": {
      "transport": "sse",
      "url": "https://mcp.example.com/sse",
      "sse_read_timeout": 300.0
    }
  }
}

Use case: Real-time updates and streaming responses

docs.title: Config File Location
docs.text:
MCP server configurations are stored in:

  1. .superqode/mcp.json (project directory)
  2. ~/.superqode/mcp.json (user home)
  3. ~/.config/superqode/mcp.json (user config)

SuperQode searches in this order and uses the first file found.

docs.title: Configuration Format
docs.text:
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "server-id": {
      "name": "Server Name",
      "description": "Server description",
      "transport": "stdio",
      "enabled": true,
      "autoConnect": true,
      "command": "command-to-run",
      "args": ["arg1", "arg2"],
      "env": {
        "VAR": "value"
      }
    }
  }
}

docs.title: stdio Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "filesystem": {
      "transport": "stdio",
      "command": "uvx",
      "args": ["mcp-server-filesystem", "--root", "."],
      "env": {
        "LOG_LEVEL": "info"
      },
      "cwd": "/path/to/working/dir",
      "timeout": 30.0
    }
  }
}

Options: - command: Executable command - args: Command arguments - env: Environment variables - cwd: Working directory - timeout: Connection timeout (seconds)

docs.title: HTTP Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "api-server": {
      "transport": "http",
      "url": "https://api.example.com/mcp",
      "headers": {
        "Authorization": "Bearer token",
        "X-API-Key": "key"
      },
      "timeout": 30.0,
      "sse_read_timeout": 300.0
    }
  }
}

Options: - url: HTTP endpoint URL - headers: HTTP headers - timeout: Request timeout (seconds) - sse_read_timeout: SSE read timeout (seconds)

docs.title: SSE Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "streaming-server": {
      "transport": "sse",
      "url": "https://stream.example.com/sse",
      "headers": {
        "Authorization": "Bearer token"
      },
      "timeout": 5.0,
      "sse_read_timeout": 300.0
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Enable/Disable Servers
docs.text:
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "server-id": {
      "enabled": true,  // Enable/disable server
      "autoConnect": true  // Auto-connect on startup
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Multiple Servers
docs.text:
Connect to multiple servers:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "filesystem": {
      "transport": "stdio",
      "command": "uvx",
      "args": ["mcp-server-filesystem"]
    },
    "github": {
      "transport": "stdio",
      "command": "uvx",
      "args": ["mcp-server-github", "--token", "${GITHUB_TOKEN}"]
    },
    "database": {
      "transport": "http",
      "url": "https://db.example.com/mcp"
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Tool Discovery
docs.text:
When an MCP server connects, SuperQode automatically discovers:

  • Tools: Available tool functions
  • Resources: Available resources
  • Prompts: Available prompt templates

Tools are made available to QE agents with the naming convention:

mcp_{server_id}_{tool_name}

For example, mcp_filesystem_read_file or mcp_github_create_issue.

docs.title: Agent Usage
docs.text: Agents automatically see and can use MCP tools during QE sessions. Tools are discovered and listed alongside built-in SuperQode tools.

docs.title: Tool Result Formatting
docs.text:
MCP tool results are automatically formatted for agent consumption:

# Tool executed via MCP
result = await execute_mcp_tool("mcp_filesystem_read_file", {
    "path": "src/api/users.py"
})

# Result formatted for agent
# - Success/failure status
# - Content/error messages
# - Structured data when available

docs.title: Filesystem Server
docs.text:
Access local filesystem:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "filesystem": {
      "transport": "stdio",
      "command": "uvx",
      "args": ["mcp-server-filesystem", "--root", "."],
      "enabled": false  // Disabled by default for security
    }
  }
}

docs.title: GitHub Server
docs.text:
GitHub integration:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "github": {
      "transport": "stdio",
      "command": "uvx",
      "args": ["mcp-server-github", "--token", "${GITHUB_TOKEN}"]
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Database Server
docs.text:
Database access via HTTP:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "database": {
      "transport": "http",
      "url": "https://db.example.com/mcp",
      "headers": {
        "Authorization": "Bearer ${DB_TOKEN}"
      }
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Use environment variables in configuration:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "github": {
      "command": "uvx",
      "args": ["mcp-server-github", "--token", "${GITHUB_TOKEN}"],
      "env": {
        "GITHUB_TOKEN": "${GITHUB_TOKEN}"
      }
    }
  }
}

Variables are resolved from your environment at runtime.

docs.title: Connection States
docs.text:
MCP servers have connection states:

State Description DISCONNECTED Not connected CONNECTING Connection in progress CONNECTED Successfully connected ERROR Connection failed

docs.title: TUI Commands
docs.text:
In the SuperQode TUI, use MCP commands:

:mcp list          # List all MCP servers
:mcp status        # Show connection status
:mcp tools         # List available tools
:mcp connect <id>  # Connect to server
:mcp disconnect <id> # Disconnect from server

docs.title: Capabilities
docs.text:
MCP servers can provide:

  • Tools: Executable functions
  • Resources: Readable data sources
  • Prompts: Prompt templates
  • Completions: Code completion support
  • Logging: Server-side logging
  • Experimental: Experimental features

SuperQode checks server capabilities and enables features accordingly.

docs.title: Resource Access
docs.text:
MCP resources provide read-only access to data:

# Read resource via MCP
content = await manager.read_resource("server-id", "resource://path/to/data")

Resources can be: - File contents - Database queries - API responses - Configuration data

docs.title: Prompt Templates
docs.text:
MCP prompts are reusable prompt templates:

# Get prompt template
prompt = await manager.get_prompt("server-id", "prompt-id", {
    "arg1": "value1"
})

Prompts can include: - System prompts - User message templates - Argument completion - Dynamic content

docs.title: 1. Security
docs.text:
Disable untrusted servers:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "filesystem": {
      "enabled": false  // Disable if not needed
    }
  }
}

docs.title: 2. Environment Variables
docs.text:
Use environment variables for secrets:

{
  "args": ["--token", "${GITHUB_TOKEN}"]
}

Never hardcode secrets in config files.

docs.title: 3. Auto-Connect
docs.text:
Control auto-connection:

{
  "autoConnect": true  // Connect on startup
  "autoConnect": false // Manual connection only
}

docs.title: 4. Error Handling
docs.text:
Check connection status before using tools:

if manager.get_connection_state("server-id") == MCPConnectionState.CONNECTED:
    # Use tools

docs.title: 5. Timeouts
docs.text:
Set appropriate timeouts:

{
  "timeout": 30.0,  // Request timeout
  "sse_read_timeout": 300.0  // SSE read timeout
}

docs.title: Connection Failed
docs.text:
Symptom: Server fails to connect

Solutions: 1. Check command path is correct 2. Verify server is installed 3. Check timeout setting 4. Review server logs

docs.title: Tools Not Available
docs.text:
Symptom: Tools not discovered

Solutions: 1. Verify server is connected 2. Check server capabilities include tools 3. Review tool discovery logs

docs.title: Timeout Errors
docs.text:
Symptom: Requests timeout

Solutions: 

{
  "timeout": 60.0  // Increase timeout
}

docs.title: Integration with QE
docs.text:
MCP tools are automatically available to QE agents:

  1. Tool Discovery: Tools discovered on connection
  2. Agent Access: Agents can call tools during QE
  3. Result Formatting: Results formatted for agent use
  4. Error Handling: Errors handled gracefully

docs.title: Natural Language QE
docs.text:
Enterprise feature. Natural language QE lets you describe testing needs in plain English and have SuperQode choose roles, scope, and intensity automatically.

This page is a high‑level overview only. Detailed usage is available with the enterprise package.

docs.title: Noise Filtering
docs.text: Reduce false positives and focus on important findings with configurable noise controls.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Noise filtering helps reduce false positives and focus on important findings by applying multiple filtering strategies:

  • Confidence thresholds: Filter findings below minimum confidence
  • Deduplication: Remove duplicate or highly similar findings
  • Severity filtering: Only show findings above minimum severity
  • Known risk suppression: Suppress acknowledged risks
  • Rule-based adjustments: Apply severity rules and adjustments
  • Memory-based filtering: Use user feedback to suppress false positives

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Configure noise filtering in superqode.yaml:

qe:
  noise:
    # Minimum confidence threshold (0.0 to 1.0)
    min_confidence: 0.7

    # Enable deduplication
    deduplicate: true

    # Similarity threshold for deduplication (0.0 to 1.0)
    similarity_threshold: 0.8

    # Suppress known/acknowledged risks
    suppress_known_risks: false
    known_risk_patterns:
      - "legacy code pattern"
      - "known false positive"

    # Minimum severity to report
    min_severity: "low"  # low, medium, high, critical

    # Maximum findings per file (0 = unlimited)
    max_findings_per_file: 0

    # Maximum total findings (0 = unlimited)
    max_total_findings: 0

    # Enable rule-based severity adjustments
    apply_severity_rules: true

docs.title: Confidence Threshold
docs.text: Filter findings below a minimum confidence score.

docs.title: Default: 0.7
docs.text: Only findings with confidence ≥ 0.7 are included.

docs.title: Adjusting Threshold
docs.text:
qe:
  noise:
    min_confidence: 0.5  # Lower threshold = more findings
Threshold Effect 0.9 Very strict - only high-confidence findings 0.7 Default - balanced 0.5 Lenient - includes more speculative findings 0.3 Very lenient - includes most findings

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Strict filtering
min_confidence: 0.85

# Balanced (default)
min_confidence: 0.7

# Include more findings
min_confidence: 0.5

docs.title: Deduplication
docs.text: Remove duplicate or highly similar findings to reduce noise.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Fingerprint-based: Exact duplicates are identified by fingerprint
  2. Similarity-based: Fuzzy matching identifies similar findings
  3. Highest severity kept: When duplicates found, keeps highest severity instance

docs.title: Fingerprinting
docs.text: Each finding gets a fingerprint based on: - Title - File path - Line number range - Finding type - Evidence snippet

docs.title: Similarity Threshold
docs.text:
Controls how similar findings must be to be considered duplicates:

qe:
  noise:
    deduplicate: true
    similarity_threshold: 0.8  # 0.0 to 1.0
Threshold Effect 1.0 Only exact duplicates removed 0.8 Default - similar findings merged 0.6 Aggressive - many similar findings merged

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Finding A: "SQL injection in user input"
Finding B: "SQL injection vulnerability in user input"
Finding C: "Potential SQL injection in query"

With similarity_threshold: 0.8
→ A and B merged (similarity ~0.9)
→ C kept separate (similarity ~0.6)

docs.title: Severity Filtering
docs.text: Only report findings above a minimum severity level.

docs.title: Severity Levels
docs.text: Level Priority Description critical 4 Security breaches, data loss risks high 3 Serious bugs, performance issues medium 2 Moderate issues, best practice violations low 1 Minor issues, style inconsistencies info 0 Informational findings

docs.title: Minimum Severity
docs.text:
qe:
  noise:
    min_severity: "medium"  # Only show medium, high, critical

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Only critical and high findings
min_severity: "high"

# Include medium and above
min_severity: "medium"

# Include all findings (default)
min_severity: "low"

docs.title: Known Risk Suppression
docs.text: Suppress findings that match known risk patterns.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
qe:
  noise:
    suppress_known_risks: true
    known_risk_patterns:
      - "legacy authentication code"
      - "intentional backdoor for testing"
      - "approved security exception"

docs.title: Pattern Matching
docs.text: Patterns can be: - Exact strings: Matches if pattern appears in finding title or description - Case-insensitive: Matching is case-insensitive - Partial matches: Matches anywhere in text

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
known_risk_patterns:
  - "legacy code - do not refactor"
  - "approved exception: SEC-2024-001"
  - "intentional for test harness"

docs.title: Rule-Based Severity Adjustments
docs.text: Apply severity rules to adjust finding severity based on context.

docs.title: Default Rules
docs.text: Built-in rules adjust severity based on: - Finding type (security vs. style) - Context (test code vs. production) - Evidence strength

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
qe:
  noise:
    apply_severity_rules: true
    # Uses default rules if not specified

    # Custom rules (advanced)
    severity_rules:
      # Custom rule configuration

docs.title: Example Adjustments
docs.text:
• Security issues in production: low → high
  • Style issues in test code: medium → info
  • Unclear evidence: high → medium

docs.title: Memory-Based Filtering
docs.text: Use feedback from previous sessions to suppress false positives.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
When you mark findings as false positives:

superqe feedback finding-001 --false-positive

The system remembers this and suppresses similar findings in future sessions.

docs.title: Automatic Application
docs.text: Memory-based suppressions are automatically applied if: - Finding matches a previously suppressed pattern - User feedback indicates false positive - Pattern is learned from multiple feedback instances

docs.title: Disable Memory Filtering
docs.text:
qe:
  noise:
    # Memory filtering is enabled by default
    # Controlled by feedback system

docs.title: Finding Limits
docs.text: Limit the number of findings reported to focus on top issues.

docs.title: Per-File Limit
docs.text:
qe:
  noise:
    max_findings_per_file: 5  # Max 5 findings per file

Useful when files have many issues - focuses on top findings.

docs.title: Total Limit
docs.text:
qe:
  noise:
    max_total_findings: 50  # Max 50 total findings

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Focus on top 10 issues per file, max 100 total
max_findings_per_file: 10
max_total_findings: 100

docs.title: Filtering Order
docs.text:
Noise filters are applied in this order:

  1. Confidence threshold: Remove low-confidence findings
  2. Memory suppressions: Remove learned false positives
  3. Known risk patterns: Suppress configured patterns
  4. Deduplication: Merge similar findings
  5. Severity filtering: Remove below minimum severity
  6. Severity rules: Adjust severity based on rules
  7. Finding limits: Apply per-file and total limits

docs.title: Strict Filtering
docs.text:
For production code review:

qe:
  noise:
    min_confidence: 0.85
    min_severity: "medium"
    deduplicate: true
    similarity_threshold: 0.9
    max_total_findings: 20

docs.title: Lenient Filtering
docs.text:
For exploratory analysis:

qe:
  noise:
    min_confidence: 0.5
    min_severity: "low"
    deduplicate: true
    similarity_threshold: 0.7
    suppress_known_risks: false

docs.title: Focus on Security
docs.text:
qe:
  noise:
    min_confidence: 0.7
    min_severity: "high"  # Only high/critical
    deduplicate: true
    apply_severity_rules: true

docs.title: Check Filtered Counts
docs.text:
# View QR to see filtering stats
superqe report

# Check artifacts for filtering details
cat .superqode/qe-artifacts/qr/qr-*.json | jq '.noise_filtering'

docs.title: Adjust Based on Results
docs.text:
1. If too many false positives → increase min_confidence or min_severity
  2. If important findings missing → decrease thresholds
  3. If too many duplicates → adjust similarity_threshold
  4. If specific patterns → add to known_risk_patterns

docs.title: 1. Start Conservative
docs.text:
# Start with default settings
min_confidence: 0.7
min_severity: "low"

docs.title: 2. Tune Based on Feedback
docs.text:
# Mark false positives
superqe feedback finding-001 --false-positive

# System learns automatically

docs.title: 3. Use Known Risk Patterns
docs.text:
# Document acknowledged risks
known_risk_patterns:
  - "legacy component - refactor planned Q2"

docs.title: 4. Set Reasonable Limits
docs.text:
# Avoid overwhelming reports
max_findings_per_file: 10
max_total_findings: 50

docs.title: Too Many Findings
docs.text:
Symptom: Report has hundreds of findings

Solution: 

min_confidence: 0.8
min_severity: "medium"
max_total_findings: 50

docs.title: Important Findings Filtered
docs.text:
Symptom: Critical issues not showing up

Solution: 

min_confidence: 0.6  # Lower threshold
min_severity: "low"   # Include all severities

docs.title: Duplicate Findings
docs.text:
Symptom: Same issue reported multiple times

Solution: 

deduplicate: true
similarity_threshold: 0.7  # More aggressive
